title: Important facts about life in the district of Augsburg
A warm welcome
excerpt:
Dear new citizen,
We are delighted that you have arrived in the district of Augsburg! We warmly welcome you and invite you to get to know the Augsburg region at its best. You will see: the district of Augsburg has a lot to offer! Whether family, leisure or work - our region has a wide range of offers for all walks of life.
It's not easy to keep track of all these offers. That's why we have created the "Integreat" app for you. Here you will find important information, addresses, contacts, tips and tricks to help you find your way around.
I can assure you: There are dedicated and friendly people working in our authorities, organisations and institutions who will be happy to help you! So don't hesitate to get in touch if you need help, don't understand something or want to make a suggestion. Numerous contact persons are available to answer any questions you may have.
I hope you enjoy discovering the district of Augsburg!
Yours

Martin SailerDistrict Administrator

Keywords: Welcome, Arrival, New residents, Augsburg district, Orientation
content:
Dear new citizen,

We are delighted that you have arrived in the district of Augsburg! We warmly welcome you and invite you to get to know the Augsburg region at its best. You will see: the district of Augsburg has a lot to offer! Whether family, leisure or work - our region has a wide range of offers for all walks of life.

It's not easy to keep track of all these offers. That's why we have created the "Integreat" app for you. Here you will find important information, addresses, contacts, tips and tricks to help you find your way around.

I can assure you: There are dedicated and friendly people working in our authorities, organisations and institutions who will be happy to help you! So don't hesitate to get in touch if you need help, don't understand something or want to make a suggestion. Numerous contact persons are available to answer any questions you may have.

I hope you enjoy discovering the district of Augsburg!

Yours

Martin Sailer
District Administrator

Keywords: Welcome, Arrival, New residents, Augsburg district, Orientation

title: To the Integreat app
excerpt:
This guide will support you in your everyday life in the district of Augsburg. You will find here

important addresses
contact persons
Tips and tricks

They can help you find your way around the district of Augsburg.
 
The Integreat app has several chapters. Each chapter deals with a different topic. You can find all chapters in the category "Local information". For example, you will find

Information on medical care
Information about schools
German courses
Helpful offers from institutions in the district of Augsburg

 
The information changes and we update the pages regularly. So please check your app often. 
You don't need internet access to use the app. You can also use the app offline. The app updates itself when you are online again.
 
A few important functions of the app:
 Change language
 The Integreat app is available in many languages. You can change the language here.
 
 Search
 You can enter a search term here.
 
 News
You can find important, current news here.
 
 Print PDF
A page is of particular interest to you? Then you can print the page as a PDF. 
 
Give feedback
 Your feedback is important to us! You can tell us what you think here. 

What do you like? 
What information are you missing?
Is some information not up to date? Then you can also use this function to report it.

 
 
 A tip:
You can also use the Integreat app of the city of Augsburg. Many offers or events in the city of Augsburg are also interesting for citizens of the district of Augsburg. You can switch using this function: 
 Change location
 
We hope that we can provide you with important information with the help of this app. And that the app will make it easier for you to find your way around the district of Augsburg. A warm welcome!
 
Youreducation office in the district of Augsburg
 
Do you have any questions, ideas or comments about the app? Then please contact us:
Education office in the district of AugsburgAnja Fünfer Anja.Fuenfer@LRA-a.bayern.de

title: The district of Augsburg
excerpt:
What is a district? 
A district is an amalgamation of several towns, markets or municipalities. The district of Augsburg comprises a total of 46 towns, markets and municipalities.
 
The district of Augsburg
The district of Augsburg is an attractive place to live and work. That is why more and more people are moving to the district. Just over 250,000 people now live here. This makes the district of Augsburg the third largest district in Bavaria.
The district of Augsburg is very popular with companies, investors and start-ups. For example because of

its central location between Munich and Stuttgart
its proximity to the city of Augsburg
ideal transport connections. 

The district of Augsburg combines an attractive economic area with an excellent quality of life. Here you can enjoy pure joie de vivre in a wonderful natural and cultural landscape.
 
City or countryside?
The district of Augsburg surrounds the city of Augsburg from the north, west and south. Nevertheless, the city of Augsburg and the district of Augsburg are two independent municipalities.
The city and district of Augsburg work closely together in many areas. Together with the district of Aichach-Friedberg, the district and the city of Augsburg form the A3 region: www.region-a3.com.
content:
What is a district?

A district is an amalgamation of several towns, markets or municipalities. The district of Augsburg comprises a total of 46 towns, markets and municipalities.

The district of Augsburg

The district of Augsburg is an attractive place to live and work. That is why more and more people are moving to the district. Just over 250,000 people now live here. This makes the district of Augsburg the third largest district in Bavaria.


The district of Augsburg is very popular with companies, investors and start-ups. For example because of

  • its central location between Munich and Stuttgart
  • its proximity to the city of Augsburg
  • ideal transport connections.

The district of Augsburg combines an attractive economic area with an excellent quality of life. Here you can enjoy pure joie de vivre in a wonderful natural and cultural landscape.

City or countryside?

The district of Augsburg surrounds the city of Augsburg from the north, west and south. Nevertheless, the city of Augsburg and the district of Augsburg are two independent municipalities.

The city and district of Augsburg work closely together in many areas. Together with the district of Aichach-Friedberg, the district and the city of Augsburg form the A3 region: www.region-a3.com.

title: The Augsburg District Office
excerpt:
The Augsburg District Office administers the district of Augsburg.
Mr Martin Sailer has been District Administrator of the district of Augsburg since 2008. The district administrator is elected by the citizens. He heads the district office.
 
The district administration is a district authority. At the same time, it is a state authority of the Free State of Bavaria.
It has various tasks: 

Compulsory tasks (e.g. construction and operation of hospitals, youth welfare, social welfare services, nature conservation).
Voluntary tasks, which are organised at its own discretion depending on financial possibilities (e.g. promotion of cultural or social facilities)

The district office offers many services for citizens. For example, advice centres for families, older people or young people. You can find a good overview on the website (see below). 
 
 Good to know: Friendly people work at the district administration office!
The staff will be happy to help you!

Do you need help?
Don't understand something?
Would you like to suggest something? 

Then get in touch!
 
You will find a contact person for almost every question. They will be happy to help you. 
Augsburg District Office Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg 0821 31020 info@LRA-a.bayern.de Monday to Friday from 7.30 am to 12.30 pm, Thursday additionally from 2 pm to 5.30 pm www.landkreis-augsburg.de
 
 A tip: The district administration office has a virtual citizens' office. This means you can make some appointments online from home. This saves you a trip to the district office. You can find out which services you can use via the virtual citizens' office here. 
What you need to use the virtual citizens' office

Smartphone, laptop or PC with webcam and microphone
Stable internet connection

 
 You can find a summary of all online services of the district administration office here.
content:
The Augsburg District Office administers the district of Augsburg.

Mr Martin Sailer has been District Administrator of the district of Augsburg since 2008. The district administrator is elected by the citizens. He heads the district office.

The district administration is a district authority. At the same time, it is a state authority of the Free State of Bavaria.

It has various tasks:

  • Compulsory tasks (e.g. construction and operation of hospitals, youth welfare, social welfare services, nature conservation).
  • Voluntary tasks, which are organised at its own discretion depending on financial possibilities (e.g. promotion of cultural or social facilities)

The district office offers many services for citizens. For example, advice centres for families, older people or young people. You can find a good overview on the website (see below).

Good to know: Friendly people work at the district administration office!

The staff will be happy to help you!

  • Do you need help?
  • Don't understand something?
  • Would you like to suggest something?

Then get in touch!

You will find a contact person for almost every question. They will be happy to help you.

title: Towns, markets and municipalities in the district
excerpt:
The district of Augsburg comprises 46 towns, markets and municipalities. The district covers a large area. From the northernmost municipality to the southernmost municipality it takes a good 45 minutes by car. Here you can find a map of the district with all the towns, markets and municipalities. 
 
Town, market or municipality? Or a municipality after all?
It is not easy for many people to distinguish between these terms. We would like to briefly explain them to you: 

"Kommune" is a generic term for districts, towns, markets and municipalities. 
"Municipality" is a generic term for towns and markets (not for rural districts, as rural districts are made up of municipalities).
"Towns" are municipalities with more than 5,000 inhabitants. They also fulfil a central function for the surrounding municipalities due to their location.
"Markets" are municipalities with a historical or formally granted market right. The market right certifies the importance of the municipality for the neighbouring municipalities. For example, in terms of location, size or offer (e.g. many shops). The market is an intermediate stage between a municipality and a town. The term "market" is a speciality for Bavaria. There are no markets in most German federal states. 

 
Cities, markets and municipalities in the district of Augsburg at a glance
We would like to introduce you to the towns, markets and municipalities in the district. You can click on the name of your municipality. This will take you to the website. There you will find lots of interesting information about local offers.
 
Six towns:

Bobingen. 
Gersthofen. 
Königsbrunn. 
Neusäß. 
Schwabmünchen. 
Stadtbergen

 
Eight markets:

Seven administrative communities (VG for short):
Some municipalities have joined together to form administrative communities. This means that they work together in the administration of their municipalities. 
- VG Gessertshausen (municipalities of Gessertshausen and Ustersbach)
- VG Großaitingen (municipalities of Großaitingen, Kleinaitingen and Oberottmarshausen)
- VG Langerringen (municipalities of Hiltenfingen and Langerringen)
- VG Lechfeld with headquarters in Untermeitingen (municipalities of Klosterlechfeld and Untermeitingen)
- VG Nordendorf (municipalities of Allmannshofen. Ehingen. Ellgau. Kühlenthal. Nordendorf and Westendorf)
- VG Stauden based in Langenneufnach (municipalities of Langenneufnach. Mickhausen. Mittelneufnach. Scherstetten and Walkertshofen)
- VG Welden (Welden market and the municipalities of Bonstetten, Emersacker and Heretsried)
 
Each municipality in the district has its own website. There you will find all offers and contact persons in your municipality as well as current information. It's worth taking a look. Just have a look!

title: Office for Foreigners and Integration District of Augsburg
excerpt:
Tasks
The Office for Immigration and Integration regulates the residence of foreign nationals whose main place of residence is registered in the district of Augsburg. The Office for Immigration and Integration is also known as the Immigration Office.
 
Making an appointment
To speak to a member of staff at the Office for Foreigners and Integration, you need to make an appointment. You can make an appointment here.

When booking an appointment online, you will first see "Your appointment has expired". You must then click on "Book new appointment".
Then you have to select the "Service". This means: Why do you need the appointment?
Then click on the appropriate box with the first letter of your surname and enter the number of people (including children) who require a residence permit.
The waiting time for an appointment is now at least 4 weeks. You need to be patient because a lot of people need an appointment at the moment.

You can also download many documents from the Foreigners' Registration Office  website .
 
Contact details
OFFICE FOR IMMIGRATION AND INTEGRATION Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg   Auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de www.landkreis-augsburg.de/asyl-auslaenderwesen-integration/amt-fuer-auslaenderwesen-und-integration/
 Opening hours:Mon. to Fri. 07:30 - 12:30Thu. 14:00 - 17:30
 
 
Keywords: residence, registration, immigration office, Office for Immigration and Integration, appointment, make an appointment
content:
Tasks

The Office for Immigration and Integration regulates the residence of foreign nationals whose main place of residence is registered in the district of Augsburg. The Office for Immigration and Integration is also known as the Immigration Office.

Making an appointment

To speak to a member of staff at the Office for Foreigners and Integration, you need to make an appointment. You can make an appointment here.

  • When booking an appointment online, you will first see "Your appointment has expired". You must then click on "Book new appointment".
  • Then you have to select the "Service". This means: Why do you need the appointment?
  • Then click on the appropriate box with the first letter of your surname and enter the number of people (including children) who require a residence permit.
  • The waiting time for an appointment is now at least 4 weeks. You need to be patient because a lot of people need an appointment at the moment.

You can also download many documents from the Foreigners' Registration Office website .

Contact details

OFFICE FOR IMMIGRATION AND INTEGRATION
Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
Auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
www.landkreis-augsburg.de/asyl-auslaenderwesen-integration/amt-fuer-auslaenderwesen-und-integration/

Opening hours:
Mon. to Fri. 07:30 - 12:30
Thu. 14:00 - 17:30

The Central Foreigners Authority of Swabia is responsible for

Asylum seekers in reception centres
asylum seekers in collective accommodation facilities
for rejected asylum seekers.

 
Their tasks include

Establishing identity and nationality
Issuing tolerations
Return counselling and return assistance
Terminating stays

title: Job centre and citizens' income
excerpt:
What does the job centre do? 
The job centre looks after people who receive citizen's allowance. Citizen's allowance is the basic income support for jobseekers.
Jobseekers are supported by the job centre in their search for a job or qualification.  
 
What is the citizen's allowance? 
Citizen's income is basic security for jobseekers. It is a benefit provided by the welfare state. The citizen's income ensures the minimum subsistence level for people who cannot finance their living expenses from their own income or assets. The citizen's allowance must be applied for at the job centre. The citizen's allowance is financed from tax money. 
 
Who receives citizen's allowance? 
Citizen's income is paid to people who are capable of work and entitled to benefits.
These are people who... 

are at least 15 years old and have not yet reached retirement age. 
live in Germany and have their centre of life here. 
can work at least 3 hours a day. 
are in need of assistance. 

 
Asylum seekers do not receive a citizen's allowance. They receive benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act. 
Recognised refugees receive citizen's allowance. 
 
Which job centre should I contact? 
There are many different job centres. Each job centre is responsible for a specific municipality. You can find the job centre for the district of Augsburg here: 
Jobcentre Augsburger Land
 Hermanstr. 11, 86150 Augsburg 0821998880 or 082199888991  J obcente r-Augsburger-Land.Hermanstrasse-11@jobcenter-ge.de  Monday to Friday from 7.30 am to 12 noon, Thursday additionally from 2 pm to 5.30 pm
 
 
Search terms: livelihood security, no money, Hartz IV, unemployment benefit II, unemployment benefit 2,
content:
What does the job centre do?

The job centre looks after people who receive citizen's allowance. Citizen's allowance is the basic income support for jobseekers.

Jobseekers are supported by the job centre in their search for a job or qualification.

What is the citizen's allowance?

Citizen's income is basic security for jobseekers. It is a benefit provided by the welfare state. The citizen's income ensures the minimum subsistence level for people who cannot finance their living expenses from their own income or assets. The citizen's allowance must be applied for at the job centre. The citizen's allowance is financed from tax money.

Who receives citizen's allowance?

Citizen's income is paid to people who are capable of work and entitled to benefits.

These are people who...

  • are at least 15 years old and have not yet reached retirement age.
  • live in Germany and have their centre of life here.
  • can work at least 3 hours a day.
  • are in need of assistance.

Asylum seekers do not receive a citizen's allowance. They receive benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act.

Recognised refugees receive citizen's allowance.

Which job centre should I contact?

There are many different job centres. Each job centre is responsible for a specific municipality. You can find the job centre for the district of Augsburg here:

Jobcentre Augsburger Land

Hermanstr. 11, 86150 Augsburg
0821998880 or 082199888991
J obcente r-Augsburger-Land.Hermanstrasse-11@jobcenter-ge.de
Monday to Friday from 7.30 am to 12 noon, Thursday additionally from 2 pm to 5.30 pm

title: Employment agency and unemployment benefit
excerpt:
What does the Employment Agency do? 
The Employment Agency performs the following tasks for citizens: 

Career counselling for young people, first-year students and university graduates
Placement of apprenticeships or jobs
Promotion of vocational training and further education
Services to promote participation in working life(inclusion)
Payment of unemployment benefit I (ALG I for short): Unemployment benefit I is paid to people who have lost their job. ALG I is an insurance benefit. Only people who have previously paid into the insurance scheme receive ALG I. 
Promotion of equal opportunities for women and men
Information on the labour and training market and on employment promotion services and benefits 
Payment of child benefit

 
Which employment agency can I contact? 
The Augsburg Employment Agency is responsible for the district of Augsburg: 
Augsburg Employment Agency (visitor address)
 Wertachstr. 28, 86153 Augsburg 08004555500 or 08213151125 A ugsburg @arbeitsagentur.de  Monday to Friday from 8 am to 12 pm  w ww.arbe itsagentur.de
content:
What does the Employment Agency do?

The Employment Agency performs the following tasks for citizens:

  • Career counselling for young people, first-year students and university graduates
  • Placement of apprenticeships or jobs
  • Promotion of vocational training and further education
  • Services to promote participation in working life(inclusion)
  • Payment of unemployment benefit I (ALG I for short): Unemployment benefit I is paid to people who have lost their job. ALG I is an insurance benefit. Only people who have previously paid into the insurance scheme receive ALG I.
  • Promotion of equal opportunities for women and men
  • Information on the labour and training market and on employment promotion services and benefits
  • Payment of child benefit

Which employment agency can I contact?

The Augsburg Employment Agency is responsible for the district of Augsburg:

title: Equality between women and men
excerpt:
In purely legal terms, women and men are equal in Germany. This means that women and men have the same rights in Germany. Every person - whether man or woman - is allowed to make decisions about themselves and their own lives. Women and men should have the same opportunities - personally, professionally and within the family. 
 
In everyday life, equality between women and men has not yet been achieved in Germany. This is why the Federal Government is actively promoting equality. For example, through these activities: 

The compatibility of family and career is promoted through measures such as parental allowance, the expansion of childcare and all-day education and childcare programmes in primary schools. 
The federal government is committed to increasing the number of women in management positions. For example, a quota for women on company supervisory boards has been in place since 2016. 
Women still earn less than men. In future, men and women should receive the same salary for equivalent work. The so-called "Remuneration Transparency Act" makes a valuable contribution to this. The law makes it possible for employees to receive information about the criteria and procedures according to which they are paid.
content:
In purely legal terms, women and men are equal in Germany. This means that women and men have the same rights in Germany. Every person - whether man or woman - is allowed to make decisions about themselves and their own lives. Women and men should have the same opportunities - personally, professionally and within the family.

In everyday life, equality between women and men has not yet been achieved in Germany. This is why the Federal Government is actively promoting equality. For example, through these activities:

  • The compatibility of family and career is promoted through measures such as parental allowance, the expansion of childcare and all-day education and childcare programmes in primary schools.
  • The federal government is committed to increasing the number of women in management positions. For example, a quota for women on company supervisory boards has been in place since 2016.
  • Women still earn less than men. In future, men and women should receive the same salary for equivalent work. The so-called "Remuneration Transparency Act" makes a valuable contribution to this. The law makes it possible for employees to receive information about the criteria and procedures according to which they are paid.

title: Freely selectable gender identity / LGBTQIA+
excerpt:
Gender diversity
Sexual orientation is a central aspect of one's personality. In Germany, every person is allowed to choose their own sexual identity. Everyone is free to decide who they are with and who they love. And every person is free to live out their own sexual orientation. Because this is an important right, it is enshrined in law (General Equal Treatment Act).
In Germany, a great deal of effort is being made to break down rigid role models and open up the view to all ways of life. A lot has therefore happened in recent years: 

Since 2011, anyone can have their gender changed in official documents. Regardless of whether a gender reassignment from male to female or from female to male has taken place or is planned.
In addition, since 2013, parents no longer have to ascribe a gender to their children on their birth certificate.
Same-sex couples have been allowed to marry in Germany since 1 October 2017. 

 
What does LGBTQIA+ or LGBT mean?
LGBTQIA+ or LGBT are abbreviations from the English language.In German, the abbreviation LSBTTIQ is often used, which stands for the following terms:L=lesbian - S=gay - B=bisexual - T=transgender - T=transsexual - I=intersexual - Q=queer.

Lesbians are women who love other women.
Gays are men who love other men.
Bisexuals fall in love with people, regardless of gender.
Transgender people are women who were born in a male body or men who were born in a female body.
Like transgender people, transsexuals are also born in the "wrong body" and change their appearance through hormones and operations.
Intersex people have both male and female genitals.
People with asexual orientation have little or no interest in sexual activity. Queer stands for everything that deviates from traditional gender roles and partner models.
The "+" in LGBTQIA+ means that there are even more sexual or gender identities.

 
Support
You will also find acceptance and support in the district of Augsburg. There are organisations that look after the LGBTIQ* scene. In general, this is about

Equal rights and equal treatment
Fighting discrimination and misanthropy
Educating the LGBTIQ* scene

Contact points

Counselling and support for under 27-year-olds can be found with the staff at "In & Out". They speak German and English and can be contacted by telephone on 030-67122671 or by email at help@comingout.de.

More information at: https://comingout.de/

The employees of GLADT e.V. also offer support in German, English, Arabic, Turkish, Farsi, French, Hebrew, Urdu and Punjabi on the telephone number 0152-11859839 or by e-mail at info@gladt.de.

More information at: https://gladt.de/
 
There are the following organisations and associations in the city of Augsburg that look after the LGBTQIA+ scene. They are primarily concerned with equal rights and equal treatment, the fight against discrimination and misanthropy as well as educating the LGBTQIA+ scene.

Queerbeet Augsburg e.V.

Queerbeet Augsburg e.V. is a group for LGBTQIA+ young people aged 14 to 27 in Augsburg and the surrounding area. They organise group evenings, school projects and other activities and are a point of contact for LGBTQIA+ issues.
More information at: www.queerbeet-augsburg.de

CSD Augsburg - Christopher Street Day Augsburg e.V.

The Christopher Street Day Augsburg association organises the well-known CSD in Augsburg, as well as other events such as IDAHIT*. They are particularly committed to the interests of queer people.
More information at: www.csd-augsburg.de

Queer Christians Augsburg

Queer Christians Augsburg is a group of bi-, trans-, asexual, lesbian and gay Christians of all ages. The group meets once a month (Fridays 19:00). The dates can be found at: https://qcaux.de/termine/ The group is open to all queer people who are interested in the Christian faith or who are searching for it.
More information at: https://qcaux.de/

Café Queer at the Moritzpunkt

The Café Queer is open every 1st Tuesday of the month at 19:00. Cultural events and discussions on current socio-political topics take place here. Everyone who wants to meet in a friendly and open atmosphere is welcome.
 Moritzplatz 5, 86150 AugsburgMore information at: https://qcaux.de/cafe/
 
 
 
Keywords: LGBTQ, LGBTQIA+, queer, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual, transgender, intersexual, CSD, equal treatment, equal rights, discrimination

title: Religion
excerpt:
Religion in Germany
Germany is a predominantly Christian country. Many people belong to the Catholic or Protestant faith. Of course, there are also many people who belong to other faiths.
 
Meanwhile, many people no longer have a denomination. This means that they do not belong to any religious community or denomination. 
 
Christianity still plays a major role in Germany. That is why there are also many statutory Christian public holidays. Other religious holidays are also observed at school. Pupils who wish to celebrate religious holidays can be exempted from school. This should be discussed with the school at an early stage. 
 
Faith is a private matter in Germany. State and religion are separate. However, the state and religion work closely together. For example, there are religious education lessons at school. 
 
In Germany, every person is free to choose their own faith. Freedom of religion is a valuable asset.
 

Freedom of religion
Freedom of religion is the law in Germany. Everyone has the right to choose and practise their own faith. The Basic Law must not be violated in the process. 
Freedom of religion includes 

All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom not to be religious. Anyone who does not believe in God may say so publicly.
People with different religions and beliefs may marry each other. A marriage must be performed at the registry office. Only then is it a legally binding marriage. Any person may also marry within the framework of religion. However, this is not legally binding in Germany. 

 
The Basic Law can be read in nine languages(German, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Kurdish-Kurmanci, Russian, Spanish, Turkish): www.bamf.de (search term: "Broschüre: Das Grundgesetz").
 
Religious centres and associations
There are various intercultural associations, religious sites, initiatives and organisations in the district of Augsburg and the city of Augsburg. You can find a list here.
content:
Religion in Germany

Germany is a predominantly Christian country. Many people belong to the Catholic or Protestant faith. Of course, there are also many people who belong to other faiths.
Meanwhile, many people no longer have a denomination. This means that they do not belong to any religious community or denomination.
Christianity still plays a major role in Germany. That is why there are also many statutory Christian public holidays. Other religious holidays are also observed at school. Pupils who wish to celebrate religious holidays can be exempted from school. This should be discussed with the school at an early stage.
Faith is a private matter in Germany. State and religion are separate. However, the state and religion work closely together. For example, there are religious education lessons at school.
In Germany, every person is free to choose their own faith. Freedom of religion is a valuable asset.

Freedom of religion

Freedom of religion is the law in Germany. Everyone has the right to choose and practise their own faith. The Basic Law must not be violated in the process.

Freedom of religion includes

  • All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
  • All people have the freedom not to be religious. Anyone who does not believe in God may say so publicly.
  • People with different religions and beliefs may marry each other. A marriage must be performed at the registry office. Only then is it a legally binding marriage. Any person may also marry within the framework of religion. However, this is not legally binding in Germany.

The Basic Law can be read in nine languages(German, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Kurdish-Kurmanci, Russian, Spanish, Turkish): www.bamf.de (search term: "Broschüre: Das Grundgesetz").

Religious centres and associations

There are various intercultural associations, religious sites, initiatives and organisations in the district of Augsburg and the city of Augsburg. You can find a list here.

title: First steps
excerpt:
Registration in your municipality
Are you new to the district of Augsburg? Have you moved into your room, flat or house?
Then you must register with the residents' registration office within two weeks. You will find the residents' registration office in the town hall in your municipality. Children aged 15 and over must come with you to register. 
 
 You must always re-register if you move house and change your place of residence and address.
 
What do you need to register? 

Your passport
if available: Residence permit / Aufenthaltsgestattung / Duldung
if you are moving into a rented flat: confirmation from the landlord; 
Persons moving into asylum accommodation: Allocation certificate

 
You can obtain the form for the Wohnungs-Geber-Bestätigung from the town hall or online. The form is filled out by your landlord. Housing providers are, for example, landlords and landladies. For people in asylum centres, it is the social workers. 
 
Questions about the right of residence
The Office for Immigration and Integration is there to answer any questions you may have about residence law. For example, for questions about

Residence permit
Visa procedure
work permit 
etc. 

 
Office for Foreigners and Integration
 Augsburg location for EU citizens and persons with residence permits: Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
 Schwabmünchen location for asylum seekers in the ongoing asylum procedure and persons with tolerated status: Fuggerstraße 10, 86830 Schwabmünchen
 0821 31020
 auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
 
 
Keywords: registration, re-registration, relocation, municipality, right of residence
content:
Registration in your municipality

Are you new to the district of Augsburg? Have you moved into your room, flat or house?

Then you must register with the residents' registration office within two weeks. You will find the residents' registration office in the town hall in your municipality. Children aged 15 and over must come with you to register.

You must always re-register if you move house and change your place of residence and address.

What do you need to register?

  • Your passport
  • if available: Residence permit / Aufenthaltsgestattung / Duldung
  • if you are moving into a rented flat: confirmation from the landlord;
  • Persons moving into asylum accommodation: Allocation certificate

You can obtain the form for the Wohnungs-Geber-Bestätigung from the town hall or online. The form is filled out by your landlord. Housing providers are, for example, landlords and landladies. For people in asylum centres, it is the social workers.

Questions about the right of residence

The Office for Immigration and Integration is there to answer any questions you may have about residence law. For example, for questions about

  • Residence permit
  • Visa procedure
  • work permit
  • etc.

Office for Foreigners and Integration

Augsburg location for EU citizens and persons with residence permits: Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg

Schwabmünchen location for asylum seekers in the ongoing asylum procedure and persons with tolerated status: Fuggerstraße 10, 86830 Schwabmünchen

0821 31020

auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de

Keywords: registration, re-registration, relocation, municipality, right of residence

title: Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
excerpt:
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) can stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
You can find more informationhere (also in English)
Please note that you must leave the country again within the period of validity of your visa. You must leave the Schengen area to do so.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany. However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa. The application must be justified. These reasons can be

force majeure,
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.

If you do not have your visa extended by the foreigners authority and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law. The foreigners authority will then check whether your stay must be terminated. Re-entry would only be possible if there is no ban on re-entry. There may also be criminal proceedings in court.
Keywords: visitor visa, visitor visa, visa, Schengen visa, visa extension, Schengen area
content:
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)

Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) can stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.

You can find more informationhere (also in English)

Please note that you must leave the country again within the period of validity of your visa. You must leave the Schengen area to do so.

A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany. However, the requirements for this must still be met.

It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa. The application must be justified. These reasons can be

  • force majeure,
  • humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.

If you do not have your visa extended by the foreigners authority and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law. The foreigners authority will then check whether your stay must be terminated. Re-entry would only be possible if there is no ban on re-entry. There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

Keywords: visitor visa, visitor visa, visa, Schengen visa, visa extension, Schengen area

title: Entry - visa procedure
excerpt:
Entry as part of a visa procedure
If you are travelling to Germany on a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:
Firstly, you must register at your chosen place of residence. German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this. In the district of Augsburg, you register at the residents' registration office in your town hall.  Here you will  find a list of all municipalities and town halls in the district.
Once you have registered, you will receive a registration certificate.
The second step is to apply for a residence permit:

The national visa (category D) will be issued to you for entry. It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay. You therefore need a residence permit.
You must apply for the residence permit at the immigration office.
It is important that you apply for the residence title while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
Depending on the reason for your entry, the residence permit also regulates
whether you are allowed to work or not,
what work you are allowed to accept and
whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.



Extension of the residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit 6 to 8 weeks before it expires.Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider. You can also obtain this information from the Immigration Office.
Keywords: entry, arrival, registration, registration certificate, residence permit, visa procedure, D visa, national visa, extension of residence permit
content:
Entry as part of a visa procedure

If you are travelling to Germany on a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:

Firstly, you must register at your chosen place of residence. German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this. In the district of Augsburg, you register at the residents' registration office in your town hall. Here you will find a list of all municipalities and town halls in the district.

Once you have registered, you will receive a registration certificate.

The second step is to apply for a residence permit:

  • The national visa (category D) will be issued to you for entry. It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay. You therefore need a residence permit.
  • You must apply for the residence permit at the immigration office.
  • It is important that you apply for the residence title while your visa is still valid.
  • The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
  • Depending on the reason for your entry, the residence permit also regulates
    • whether you are allowed to work or not,
    • what work you are allowed to accept and
    • whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.

Extension of the residence permit:

Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit 6 to 8 weeks before it expires.
Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider. You can also obtain this information from the Immigration Office.

Keywords: entry, arrival, registration, registration certificate, residence permit, visa procedure, D visa, national visa, extension of residence permit

title: Entry without a visa
excerpt:
Third-country nationals from so-called privileged states - stay without a visa
Citizens of certain countries may enter the  Schengen area without a visa. This applies to persons from:

Australia
New Zealand
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
Israel
Japan
Canada
Republic of Korea
United States of America

These persons may stay in Germany or the Schengen area for a maximum of 90 days within 180 days. You must take this into account if you are planning multiple entries or longer stays. You may not exceed the maximum permitted length of stay. You must set your departure date accordingly.
 
List of countries with or without a visa requirement for Germany / Schengen area
 
Attention: 
You must leave Germany once the maximum length of stay has expired. But also from the Schengen states.
 
Do you want to stay or work here for longer than three months? Then you must apply for a residence permit at the immigration office.
Or you cannot leave the country within the time limit? Then you must also contact the Foreigners' Registration Office before your stay expires. For some reasons, they may allow you to stay longer.
For example in the case of 

force majeure
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.

 
You must adhere to these rules! Otherwise it is an offence against the law. The foreigners authority can terminate your stay. You may also be subject to criminal proceedings in court. You may also be banned from re-entering the country. You will then not be allowed to re-enter Germany.
 
 
 
Keywords: entry, entry, entry without visa, no visa, third-country nationals, privileged states, Schengen area, visa requirement, duration of stay, departure, Schengen states, residence permit, stay

Attention:

Keywords: entry, entry, entry without visa, no visa, third-country nationals, privileged states, Schengen area, visa requirement, duration of stay, departure, Schengen states, residence permit, stay

title: Permanent residence
excerpt:
What residence titles are there for permanent residence?
Settlement permit according to § 9 of the Residence Act
With a settlement permit, you can live and work in Germany. Without time and place restrictions.
 
Prerequisites are, for example

Legal residence in Germany for at least 5 years (previous periods of study and training are counted at 50%)
Valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (studies) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure means of subsistence
Proof of secure accommodation
Proof of sufficient pension provision (at least 60 months of compulsory or voluntary contributions to statutory pension insurance in Germany)
Sufficient German language skills and basic knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany - usually proven by
successful participation in an integration courseor
certificates and proof of study relating to vocational training completed in Germanyor
other language certificates



 
In individual cases, you may need additional documents.
 
You can find more information on the requirements here.
 
Permanent residence - EU
Permanent residence - EU is an unlimited residence title.
It offers the same rights as the settlement permit. With this permit, you can live and work in Germany. Without any time or place restrictions. 
 
You can also live, work or study in other EU countries. Exceptions are Ireland and Denmark. Special regulations apply for individual countries.
 
You can find information on the requirements here.
 
Which residence permit is right for you?
That depends on your individual circumstances.
The  Immigration Office will be happy to advise you.
 
 
 
Keywords: residence title, permanent residence, settlement permit
content:
What residence titles are there for permanent residence?

Settlement permit according to § 9 of the Residence Act

With a settlement permit, you can live and work in Germany. Without time and place restrictions.

Prerequisites are, for example

  • Legal residence in Germany for at least 5 years (previous periods of study and training are counted at 50%)
  • Valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (studies) or for humanitarian reasons
  • Proof of secure means of subsistence
  • Proof of secure accommodation
  • Proof of sufficient pension provision (at least 60 months of compulsory or voluntary contributions to statutory pension insurance in Germany)
  • Sufficient German language skills and basic knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany - usually proven by
    • successful participation in an integration course
      or
    • certificates and proof of study relating to vocational training completed in Germany
      or
    • other language certificates

In individual cases, you may need additional documents.

You can find more information on the requirements here.

Permanent residence - EU

Permanent residence - EU is an unlimited residence title.

It offers the same rights as the settlement permit. With this permit, you can live and work in Germany. Without any time or place restrictions.

You can also live, work or study in other EU countries. Exceptions are Ireland and Denmark. Special regulations apply for individual countries.

You can find information on the requirements here.

Which residence permit is right for you?

That depends on your individual circumstances.

The Immigration Office will be happy to advise you.

Keywords: residence title, permanent residence, settlement permit

title: Family reunification
excerpt:
Marriage and family are under special protection in Germany. This is why certain people can bring their family members abroad to Germany. These people usually need a visa to do so. Therefore, contact the foreigners authority and seek advice. 
 
Which people are allowed to bring family members to Germany? 

People with German citizenship
Persons residing in Germany who are foreign nationals with a
settlement permit
Permanent residence permit - EU
residence permit
EU Blue Card
ICT card
Mobile ICT card



 
Family reunification is excluded for the following groups of persons: 

Persons with tolerated stay
Asylum seekers in the ongoing asylum procedure
Persons with temporary residence status

 
Which family members can be brought to Germany?  

Wife and husband
Partner from a registered civil partnership
own underage children

Other family members can only be brought to Germany in exceptional cases of hardship. The requirements are very high. These include, for example: uncles, aunts, grandparents, grandchildren. 
Unaccompanied refugee minors can be joined by their parents. This applies up to the age of 18. 
 
What requirements must be met? 
In principle, the following applies:

The purpose of family reunification is to bring the family together. The aim is therefore to form a family or partnership.
Spouses must be at least 18 years old.
The marriage or registered civil partnership must have already existed in the country of origin.

 
All other requirements vary depending on the group of people. It will be checked whether the requirements are met. You will need to submit various documents.
 
It is best to seek advice from the migration counselling service or the foreigners authority .
 
Simplified family reunification for persons with protection status
Have you been granted protection status in an asylum procedure? And you would like to bring family members to join you? Then simplified family reunification applies. 
This means that some requirements are waived. 
 
What do you have to do? You must submit the application for family reunification within three months of being recognised. 
 
Did you miss the deadline? Then a discretionary decision applies. This means that the authorities will make a decision based on certain criteria. 
 
Further information on family reunification for persons with protection status can be found on the website of the Federal Foreign Office in German, English and Arabic.
 
 
 
Keywords: family reunification, requirements for family reunification, family members, family, spouse, children, simplified family reunification, family reunification, persons with protection status

All other requirements vary depending on the group of people. It will be checked whether the requirements are met. You will need to submit various documents.

Have you been granted protection status in an asylum procedure? And you would like to bring family members to join you? Then simplified family reunification applies.

Keywords: family reunification, requirements for family reunification, family members, family, spouse, children, simplified family reunification, family reunification, persons with protection status

title: Spousal residence - independent right of residence
excerpt:
Foreign spouses or partners can move to Germany. Different regulations apply. 
 
After entering the country
New arrivals must register at the residents' registration office in the town hall within 14 days. The town hall will issue a registration certificate. 
 
You will receive a national visa (category D) for travelling to Germany or other Schengen states. For your future stay in Germany, you must apply for a residence permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
 
You can find more informationhere.
 
Integration course
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF ) offers integration courses for people with a valid residence permit and little knowledge of German.
 
In many cases, language skills are a prerequisite for a settlement permit.
Are you applying for a residence permit for the first time? Then the Office for Immigration and Integration may require you to attend an integration course if you do not yet speak German well. 
 
You can find more informationhere .
 
Access to the labour market
People who have a residence permit for family reunification are allowed to work. The work permit is also linked to the residence permit. You have unrestricted access to the German labour market. You may work for a company as an employee. Or become self-employed. 
 
Independent right of residence
Have you been living together for at least 3 years? Then spouses receive an independent right of residence. 
 
For victims of violence
In certain cases, an independent right of residence can be granted earlier. For example, if it is no longer reasonable to remain in the marital partnership due to violence. 
There may then be an exception.

You will receive a national visa (category D) for travelling to Germany or other Schengen states. For your future stay in Germany, you must apply for a residence permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.

You can find more informationhere.

In many cases, language skills are a prerequisite for a settlement permit.

For victims of violence

In certain cases, an independent right of residence can be granted earlier. For example, if it is no longer reasonable to remain in the marital partnership due to violence.

There may then be an exception.

title: Right of residence opportunities
excerpt:
Right of residence by opportunity
Since 31 December 2022, the Right of Residence by Opportunity has been in force. The aim is to give people who have been living in Germany for a long time a legal residence permit.
 
The requirements are:

People with a tolerated stay permit who have been living in Germany since at least 31 October 2017 can obtain a residence permit for 18 months. You must have entered the country before 01 November 2017.

Applying for the right to stay : If you fulfil the necessary requirements within the 18 months, you can apply for the right to stay in accordance with § 25a AufenthG or § 25b AufenthG. The requirements are



Securing your livelihood
Clarification of identity,
Knowledge of the German language#



 

For adolescents and young adults between 14 and 26 years of age: Tolerated persons or holders of the right of residence between the ages of 14 and 26 can receive a residence permit if they have integrated well .

 

For tolerated persons or holders of an opportunity residence permit (§ 104c AufenthG): Tolerated persons or holders of the right of residence (§ 104c AufenthG) can obtain a residence permit if they have integrated well .

If you fulfil the requirements, you can fill out the application for a residence permit, print it out and send it to the following address:
 
Office for Immigration and Integration Augsburg District Office Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de Opening hours: Monday - Friday: 7.30 am - 12.30 pm and additionally Thursday: 2 pm - 5.30 pm
 
 
 
Keywords: opportunities - right of residence, opportunities - right of residence, toleration, tolerated persons, residence permit, application for right of residence, application for residence permit, requirements for residence permit
content:
Right of residence by opportunity

Since 31 December 2022, the Right of Residence by Opportunity has been in force. The aim is to give people who have been living in Germany for a long time a legal residence permit.

The requirements are:

  • People with a tolerated stay permit who have been living in Germany since at least 31 October 2017 can obtain a residence permit for 18 months. You must have entered the country before 01 November 2017.

Applying for the right to stay : If you fulfil the necessary requirements within the 18 months, you can apply for the right to stay in accordance with § 25a AufenthG or § 25b AufenthG. The requirements are

    • Securing your livelihood
    • Clarification of identity,
    • Knowledge of the German language#

  • For adolescents and young adults between 14 and 26 years of age: Tolerated persons or holders of the right of residence between the ages of 14 and 26 can receive a residence permit if they have integrated well .

  • For tolerated persons or holders of an opportunity residence permit (§ 104c AufenthG): Tolerated persons or holders of the right of residence (§ 104c AufenthG) can obtain a residence permit if they have integrated well .

If you fulfil the requirements, you can fill out the application for a residence permit, print it out and send it to the following address:

Office for Immigration and Integration
Augsburg District Office
Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
Opening hours: Monday - Friday: 7.30 am - 12.30 pm and additionally Thursday: 2 pm - 5.30 pm

Keywords: opportunities - right of residence, opportunities - right of residence, toleration, tolerated persons, residence permit, application for right of residence, application for residence permit, requirements for residence permit

title: Asylwegweiser - Multilingual information videos
excerpt:
Online videos on the asylum procedure in various languages
There are videos explaining the asylum procedure. They are provided by the Bavarian and Munich Refugee Councils.
The videos are a guide to the asylum procedure. Refugees can thus complete their asylum procedure in an informed and independent manner.
 
The videos provide basic information. They do not replace detailed counselling.
Make sure you get advice! This way you can avoid serious mistakes and omissions. 
 
To the videos

title: Registration
excerpt:
Have you just arrived in Germany? And you want to apply for asylum? Then you must register with one of the state authorities immediately after your arrival:

Border authority
the police
Immigration office
Reception centre for refugees
Branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)

 
Your personal data will be registered and stored centrally.
It will be checked whether

You are applying for asylum in Germany for the first time
you have already applied for asylum in another European country
the Federal Criminal Police Office has data about you

 
You will then receive proof of arrival as proof of registration.
 
Only at this point does the asylum procedure begin.
 
Applying for asylum in the district of Augsburg
Would you like to apply for asylum in the district of Augsburg? Then contact the responsible authority:
 
Government of Swabia
Central Immigration Office Swabia
Kobelweg 8286156 Augsburg 0821327698 zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de 
 
You will then be sent to another initial reception centre. Or you can initially stay in the initial reception centre in the district of Augsburg.
The law requires asylum seekers to live in an initial reception centre for up to three months.
The reception centre in which you are accommodated depends on your country of origin. Asylum applications from different countries of origin are processed in the various BAMF branch offices. All asylum seekers are distributed evenly among the various federal states in Germany.
 
 
Keywords: registration, arrival, asylum application, asylum procedure, asylum, proof of arrival, initial reception centre, reception centre
content:
Have you just arrived in Germany? And you want to apply for asylum? Then you must register with one of the state authorities immediately after your arrival:

  • Border authority
  • the police
  • Immigration office
  • Reception centre for refugees
  • Branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)

Your personal data will be registered and stored centrally.

It will be checked whether

  • You are applying for asylum in Germany for the first time
  • you have already applied for asylum in another European country
  • the Federal Criminal Police Office has data about you

You will then receive proof of arrival as proof of registration.

Only at this point does the asylum procedure begin.

Applying for asylum in the district of Augsburg

Would you like to apply for asylum in the district of Augsburg? Then contact the responsible authority:

Government of Swabia

Central Immigration Office Swabia

Kobelweg 82
86156 Augsburg
0821327698
zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de

You will then be sent to another initial reception centre. Or you can initially stay in the initial reception centre in the district of Augsburg.

The law requires asylum seekers to live in an initial reception centre for up to three months.

The reception centre in which you are accommodated depends on your country of origin. Asylum applications from different countries of origin are processed in the various BAMF branch offices. All asylum seekers are distributed evenly among the various federal states in Germany.

Keywords: registration, arrival, asylum application, asylum procedure, asylum, proof of arrival, initial reception centre, reception centre

title: Application for asylum
excerpt:
After registration and accommodation in the reception centre, you will have to apply for asylum in person.
 
Are you accommodated in the reception centre in the district of Augsburg?
Then you will be given an appointment to make an application at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees - Augsburg branch office:
 
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Augsburg branch office August-Wessels-Straße 27, 86156 Augsburg 091194328655 service@bamf.bund.de www.bamf.de (multilingual)
 
An interpreter will also come for this appointment. You will submit your asylum application. And you will receive important information about the asylum procedure.
 
Have you submitted your application for asylum? Then you will receive a residence permit. This is proof of your legal residence in Germany and your application for asylum.
 
As long as you are accommodated in a reception centre, the government of Swabia is responsible for questions relating to immigration and residence law:
 
Government of Swabia
Central Immigration Office Swabia
 Kobelweg 82, 86156 Augsburg 0821327698 zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de
 
Residence obligation
The residence permit is initially associated with spatial restrictions. This means that you may only stay in the district of your reception centre.
 
Would you like to leave the area temporarily within the first three months? Then you need a permit from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
 
After the three months, you will need a permit from the relevant immigration authority.
 
Depending on your country of origin and the course of your asylum procedure, this spatial restriction applies for different lengths of time.
 
Change of address - important note!
Are you in the asylum procedure and have been authorised or obliged to move?
Then you must inform the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees of your new address yourself.
 
 
Keywords: personal application, residence permit, new address, relocation

title: Dublin procedure
excerpt:
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland. The Dublin procedure determines which country is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure. As a rule, it is the country in which you were registered for the first time. This is done with an electronic data comparison.
It is possible that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure. If Germany is not responsible, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you can seek counselling. You can seek professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to lodge a complaint with the administrative court.
Further information about the Dublin Agreement in German and English
Keywords: Dublin procedure, Dublin procedure, asylum procedure, counselling, implementation of asylum procedure

Dublin procedure
