title: Offers for Children
content:
Deutsch mit Socke

Deutsch mit Socke is a film series that helps children between the ages of 5 and 10 take their first steps in the German language. In each short video, Esther (a young woman) and Socke (a red sock) talk about all kinds of things – just like in real life. Socke is red, imaginative, a bit cheeky and full of energy. This leads to many situations in which Esther and Socke speak and interact in German together. Children can easily identify with Socke. The material is also about this: The children should - like Socke - be able to speak and interact in the foreign language. The videos are accompanied by activities and a student booklet.

 

Die Bienenretter

With this free app, children from the age of three can learn German in a playful way. With no previous knowledge of the language, they leave the protection of the forest together with a squirrel and a bear and embark on an exciting journey to save the sick bees. On their way through the snow-covered mountains where a lynx, the guardian of the medicinal plant, lives, they encounter animals that help them and teach them more than 900 German words. "Die Bienenretter" can be played on two different levels of difficulty and offers up to six hours of fun.

 

Vocabulary app for children

With the app "phase6 hallo Deutsch", school-aged children (and young people too) can learn German in a playful way while building up a sound basic vocabulary of over 1300 important words and phrases. Each word is first introduced and then practised with different exercises. Illustrations and educational games help with this.

 

Die Sendung mit dem Elefanten

The little blue elephant and his friends offer stories to discover, marvel and laugh along with, for children between the ages of 3 and 6. Each programme lasts about 25 minutes and is also very suitable for language training.

 

Kid's channel WDR Maus

The page with the mouse (Maus) offers educational programmes – in which, for example, the production or function of an everyday object is explained – as well as audio stories, games or even handicraft tips. Each "Sendung mit der Maus" presents complex issues in an entertaining and understandable way for children between the ages of 6 and 9 and lasts about 30 minutes. It is also suitable for language support for children with some previous knowledge.

 

Lingo für Kids

With Lingo, children between the ages of 8 and 12 can practise German and learn new things. There are exciting texts for reading and listening, experiments and handicraft tips.

 

Key words: German course, learn German online, learn German for free, learn German yourself, German for kids, learn German playfully, learn German on the Internet

title: Other language learning opportunities
excerpt:
In Augsburg and the surrounding area, there are several free offers for learning German.
Often there are also small German courses run by volunteers or meeting places where you can practise German in libraries or volunteer centres and agencies. It is best to ask directly in your municipality.
 
For example, there are the following offers: 
German Café at DieZ in Diedorf 
In the German Café in the Diedorf Centre for Encounters, volunteers help people learn German every Tuesday from 4 to 6 pm.
 Tuesdays: 4 - 6 p.m. 
 DieZ - Diedorf Centre for Encounter    Bahnhofstr. 18, 86420 Diedorf
 
Learning Café in Schwabmünchen 
Learning café for learning German every Monday from 6 to 7.30 pm in the middle school in Schwabmünchen. Volunteers support you in learning German. The offer is open to all. 
 Mondays: 6.00 - 7.30 p.m.
 Leonhard Wagner Secondary School Schwabmünchen     Breitweg 16A, 86830 Schwabmünchen     at the side entrance
 
Volunteer German courses at the multi-generation house in Königsbrunn 
Volunteers offer German practice courses for beginners at the multi-generation house in Königsbrunn. 
Registration with: Ramona MarkmillerTelephone: 0160 98 41 01 81
 Multigenerational House Königsbrunn     Bürgermeister-Wohlfarth-Strasse 98, 86343 Königsbrunn, Germany
 
Café Mosaik in the multi-generation house in Königsbrunn 
At Café Mosaik in the multi-generation house in Köngisbrunn, people meet to talk, get to know each other and make friends. There are films, games, music and international food. The intercultural meeting place takes place every Thursday from 4 to 7 pm and is open to everyone.  
 Thursdays: 4 - 7 pm 
 Multigenerational House Königsbrunn    Bürgermeister-Wohlfarth-Straße 98, 86343 Königsbrunn 
 
Café International in Bobingen
At Café International people meet to talk, get to know each other and make friends. Sometimes there are special events such as cooking together, theatre afternoons or cinema evenings. 
The café is open every second Friday (even calendar week) from 4 to 6 pm. Current dates can be found on the homepage here. 
 Fridays (every fortnight): 16 - 18 h 
 Café International     Pestalozzistraße 1, 86399 Bobingen, Germany      Alte Mädchenschule Bobingen, ground floor on the left
 
German courses at Tür an Tür in Augsburg
German courses will be held at Tür an Tür from 16 October 2023 to 16 February 2024. The courses are 3 times a week for 1.5 hours each.
You can register until 12 September 2023. The courses are for refugees without access to the integration course or for people who have already used up all the hours in the integration course.
Cost of the course: 10€.
 16 October 2023 to 16 February 2024 
 Door to door     Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Augsburg, Germany.
Registration with: Katharina Stark Katharina.stark@tuerantuer.de 0157 80612685  Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Aug sburg, Germany 
 
German Café at Tür an Tür in Augsburg
At the German Café, volunteers help people learn German. The German Café takes place every Wednesday from 9am to 11am and from 3pm to 5pm. The offer is open to everyone. 
 Wednesdays: 9 - 11 a.m. and 3 - 5 p.m.
 Café Tür an Tür    Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Augsburg, Germany
Please send questions to: fernanda.kerckhoff@tuerantuer.de
 
German Café in the multi-generation house in Augsburg
In the German Café, volunteers and learners practise German together. The German Café takes place every Friday from 3 to 5 pm. The offer is open to all. 
 Fridays: 3 - 5 p.m.
 Multigenerational House Hochfeld Römerhof    Hochfeldstraße 52, 86159 Augsburg, Germany 
Please send questions to: fernanda.kerckhoff@tuerantuer.de
 
German Café at Moritzpunkt in Augsburg
In the German Café, volunteers and learners practise German together. The German Café takes place every Saturday from 10 am to 12 pm. The offer is open to everyone. 
You can also bring your children. 
 Saturdays: 10 a.m. - 12 p.m.
 Moritzpunkt   Maximilianstraße 28 , 86150 Augsburg, Germany
Please send questions to: fernanda.kerckhoff@tuerantuer.de
 
German regulars' table at the Neruda in Augsburg
Conversations in German on various topics. 
 Mondays: from 6 pm
 Neruda Cultural Café    Alte Gasse 7, 86152 Augsburg
 
German Café for Women in Augsburg (Project Take Off!)
Come along and speak German together with other women and a teacher. 
At the Tante Emma Café in Augsburg, women can practise German together on Mondays from 9 to 11 am and Wednesdays from 2 to 4 pm. 
For women who have a migration history and who want to enter the labour market. 
 Mondays: 9 - 11 a.m.      Wednesdays: 2 - 4 p.m.
 Aunt Emma Café    Am Fischertor 2, 86152 Augsburg, Germany 
Contact and more information: 
 https://tuerantuer.de/takeoff/
 
Language tandem 
What is a tandem? Two people with different mother tongues meet. They want to learn each other's language. At the meetings, they can talk in both languages. This way they both learn from each other. 
There are various online platforms where you can find tandem partners. For example, you can find a person for a tandem on the following platforms: 

Sprachtandem-Börse der Hamburger Volkshochschule. You can find more information here. 
Sprachtandem-Börse "Tandempartner" (language tandem exchange) You might find a suitable person for Augsburg here. 
Tandem "Start with a Friend People who are new to Augsburg meet people who have lived in Augsburg for a long time. You can get to know each other and do things together. You can find more information here. 

 
Digital language tandems

Learn and practise German
Communicate via video chat or online platforms
Exchange about interests, hobbies etc.

 
Contact and more information:
Katharina Stark katharina.stark@tuerantuer.de 015780612685 Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Augsburg, Germany
 
Perhaps there is also an offer in your community. You are welcome to ask the Integration Helper for the district of Augsburg. 
She is the contact person for volunteers and support groups in the district of Augsburg:
Integration helper in the district of AugsburgDiakonie AugsburgAstrid Zimmermann Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Augsburg, Germany 082349591896 or 01741315515  zimmermann.a@diakonie-augsburg.de
 
You can also improve your German online. Tips for free offers can be found here.
 
 
 
Keywords: learn German, language support, conversation course, learn language, speak German, German café, learn language, language mentors, German free of charge, language learning offers

title: Professional interpreting and translation by specialised staff
excerpt:
You don't speak German very well yet? Then an interpreter can help you with appointments. For example, at the immigration office or the education authority. But also at parents' evenings at school or kindergarten.
Some authorities and organisations will provide you with an interpreter free of charge. Ask when you make an appointment. 
Some authorities and organisations do not offer interpreting free of charge. In this case, you will need to bring your own interpreter. And pay for it. 
 
Who can interpret and translate for you? 
Interpreters and interpreters: 
Interpreters speak several languages. They translate from the source language into the target language and vice versa. 
 
Language and cultural mediators: 
People with a migration background work in language and cultural mediation. They have been specially trained. These people not only mediate linguistically. They also mediate between cultures. They ensure that no misunderstandings arise due to cultural differences.
 
Augsburg interpreter pools
If you are looking for an interpreter, you can use the Augsburg interpreter pools: 
 
Interpreter pool "Babel" Barfüßerstraße 4, 86150 Augsburg 0821/152062 Mon - Fri from 10.00 - 13.00 hrs babel@assyrer-augsburg.de
 
"kunterMund" language and cultural mediators Oberbürgermeister-Dreifuß-Str. 1, 86153 Augsburg 0821/597760 eb@diakonie-augsburg.de
 
"SprInt" (language and integration mediator)Anne Pawletta Wertachstr. 29, 86153 Augsburg 0821/9079942 anne.pawletta@tuerantuer.de
 
You can find more detailed information on all interpreter pools at www.tuerantuer.de/sprach-und-kulturmittlung.
 
Having documents translated
Official documents in Germany may only be translated by state-certified translators. For example 

Certificates
Marriage certificates
birth certificates

These translations can be expensive. It is best to check carefully beforehand whether you really need such a certified translation.
If you need a certified translation, you can contact the Augsburg interpreter pools. They will provide you with a qualified translator.
 
 
 
Keywords: translate documents, interpreter, translator, translation, interpreting
content:

title: Translation with the help of a smartphone or laptop (free of charge)
excerpt:
Don't speak German very well yet? Then these free translation tools can help you in everyday life. You can use them on your smartphone or laptop.
 

Google Translate: Translates the text you enter, but also images of texts that you have taken with your camera. 
DeepL: Translates written and spoken text - so you can type or speak a text. Also translates images of texts that you have taken with the camera. 
PONS: Translates the text you enter. A dictionary also helps you learn German. 
Microsoft Translator: Translates written and spoken text and reads out the translation. 
Reverso: Translates the text you enter. You can also upload documents and have them translated.
Speak & Translate: The free app recognises spoken language and translates into over 100 target languages. The app also works in offline mode. Download it from your app store. 

 
 Note: You can't always rely on the tools. You should always get professional help with important documents!
content:
Don't speak German very well yet? Then these free translation tools can help you in everyday life. You can use them on your smartphone or laptop.

  • Google Translate: Translates the text you enter, but also images of texts that you have taken with your camera.
  • DeepL: Translates written and spoken text - so you can type or speak a text. Also translates images of texts that you have taken with the camera.
  • PONS: Translates the text you enter. A dictionary also helps you learn German.
  • Microsoft Translator: Translates written and spoken text and reads out the translation.
  • Reverso: Translates the text you enter. You can also upload documents and have them translated.
  • Speak & Translate: The free app recognises spoken language and translates into over 100 target languages. The app also works in offline mode. Download it from your app store.

Note: You can't always rely on the tools. You should always get professional help with important documents!

title: Bavarian school system and compulsory education
excerpt:
The Bavarian school system enables every child to follow an individualised educational path. Various qualifications can be achieved at all schools. With every school-leaving qualification achieved, the path to the next higher qualification is open.
 
The Bavarian education and school system is partly different to that of other federal states. There is an explanatory film in German and English about the school system in Bavaria.
 
The following overview should make it easier for you to find your way around. It is available in these languages: 

English 
Spanish
Arabic
Arabic French
Italian
Czech
Ukrainian
Turkish
Russian

 

(Source: Bavarian State Ministry of Education and Cultural Affairs)
 
Compulsory schooling
School attendance is compulsory for every child from the age of six. Compulsory schooling lasts twelve years in Bavaria. Compulsory schooling is divided into

Compulsory full-time schooling (nine years) and
compulsory vocational schooling (three years).

 
Compulsory schooling ends with the completion of vocational training or on reaching the age of 21.
There may be consequences (e.g. fines) if compulsory schooling is not adhered to.
 
 
Keywords: school system in Bavaria, Bavarian school system, compulsory schooling, individualised education, full-time compulsory schooling, compulsory vocational schooling

title: General schools
excerpt:
In Bavaria, there are different types of schools. All children start primary school. This is followed by a visit to one of the various secondary schools.  The decision as to which type of secondary school they attend depends on their academic ability and the vocational goals they have.
A list of all schools in the district of Augsburg including contact details can be found on the education portal A3 (www.bildungsportal-a3.de) under "Places of education".

title: Grundschule
excerpt:
Duration: 4 years
Goal: The children learn reading and writing as well as basic mathematics.
At present, there are 46 state-run primary schools (staatliche Grundschulen) in the district of Augsburg, teaching children basic knowledge and skills.
Afterwards, the children go to a secondary school. There are three differentsecondary schools, which lead to different leaving certificates: Mittelschule, Realschule or Gymnasium. The district of Augsburg also has a broad offering for these types of school: 15 basic secondary schools, six standard secondary schools and five grammar schools.
Good to know: When choosing a primary or basic secondary school, it is important to note what is known as the “Sprengel Principle”. In other words: Every primary school or basic secondary school is responsible for a certain area (referred to as: “Sprengel”). Children must then attend a certain school. You can find more detailed information with a school search at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schulsuche.html.

title: Secondary schools
excerpt:
Secondary school
Duration: 5–6 years
Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship / profession
Degree: Qualifying basic secondary school diploma (“Quali”), basic secondary school diploma, “Mittlere Reife” (equivalent to the British GCSE qualification) – for higher-performing pupils by attending the M-BranchBasic secondary schools in the district of Augsburg: 15 Mittelschulen (basic secondary schools).
Good to know: When choosing a Grundschule (primary school) or Mittelschule (basic secondary school), it is important to bear in mind what is known as the “Sprengel Principle”. In other words: Every primary school or basic secondary school is responsible for a certain area (referred to as: “Sprengel”). Children must then attend a certain school. You can find more detailed information with a school search at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schulsuche.html.
Realschule
Duration: 6 years
Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship in any profession, or transfer to a specialised secondary school (Fachoberschule – FOS)
Degree: Secondary school degree (Mittlere Reife / Mittlerer Schulabschluss)Realschulen (standard secondary schools) in the district of Augsburg: 6 Realschulen.
Grammar school
Duration: 8–9 years
Goal: Preparation for higher education
Degree: General higher education entrance qualification (Abitur; entitlement to study at universities and colleges)Gymnasien (grammar schools) in the district of Augsburg:  5 Gymnasien
Special needs centres and schools
Duration: Special needs schools are available for all age groups.
Goal: Individual support and training for children with special learning needs (e.g. severe difficulty reading, delayed development, disabilities)Degree: Secondary school leaving certificate or qualifying (Quali)Special needs centres and special needs schools in the district of Augsburg: 3 state-run and 2 private schools.
Private schools
There are also two public schools in the district of Augsburg: an International School (1st-12th grade) and an International School (2nd-12th grade). Class) and a Montessori school (1st-10th class). Year). You can find more information on these websites:

International School www.isa-augsburg.com
Montessori School Dinkelscherben www.montessoridinkelscherben.de
content:
Secondary school

Duration: 5–6 years

Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship / profession

Degree: Qualifying basic secondary school diploma (“Quali”), basic secondary school diploma, “Mittlere Reife” (equivalent to the British GCSE qualification) – for higher-performing pupils by attending the M-Branch
Basic secondary schools in the district of Augsburg: 15 Mittelschulen (basic secondary schools).


Good to know: When choosing a Grundschule (primary school) or Mittelschule (basic secondary school), it is important to bear in mind what is known as the “Sprengel Principle”. In other words: Every primary school or basic secondary school is responsible for a certain area (referred to as: “Sprengel”). Children must then attend a certain school. You can find more detailed information with a school search at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schulsuche.html.

Realschule

Duration: 6 years

Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship in any profession, or transfer to a specialised secondary school (Fachoberschule – FOS)

Degree: Secondary school degree (Mittlere Reife / Mittlerer Schulabschluss)
Realschulen (standard secondary schools) in the district of Augsburg: 6 Realschulen.

Grammar school

Duration: 8–9 years

Goal: Preparation for higher education

Degree: General higher education entrance qualification (Abitur; entitlement to study at universities and colleges)
Gymnasien (grammar schools) in the district of Augsburg:  5 Gymnasien

Special needs centres and schools

Duration: Special needs schools are available for all age groups.

Goal: Individual support and training for children with special learning needs (e.g. severe difficulty reading, delayed development, disabilities)
Degree: Secondary school leaving certificate or qualifying (Quali)
Special needs centres and special needs schools in the district of Augsburg: 3 state-run and 2 private schools.

Private schools

There are also two public schools in the district of Augsburg: an International School (1st-12th grade) and an International School (2nd-12th grade). Class) and a Montessori school (1st-10th class). Year). You can find more information on these websites:

  • International School www.isa-augsburg.com
  • Montessori School Dinkelscherben www.montessoridinkelscherben.de

title: Costs for the route to school
excerpt:
In the district of Augsburg, the costs for the route to school are covered by the district administration (Landratsamt) of Augsburg, the local authority (Gemeinde) or the school association (Schulverband), if certain criteria are met.
You can find more information on the cost exemption at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/schuelerbefoerderung.

title: Vocational schools
excerpt:
Training at a vocational school
Duration: 2–3 years
Goal: completed vocational education
Qualification: Berufsabschluss (Professional qualification), Mittlerer Schulabschluss (intermediate school leaving qualification)
Young people who are doing an apprenticeship and are between 16 and 21 years old must go to vocational school.
In the district of Augsburg there are many schools that can prepare you for a career, or where you can attain a higher qualification: Berufsschule (vocational school), Berufsfachschule (vocational schools for specific professions), Fachschule (preparatory training school), Fachoberschule (technical college) and Berufsoberschule (upper secondary vocational school).
There are also other schools in the vicinity of the district (e.g. in the city of Augsburg), which are classified as business schools or specialist academies. You can find more information in the "Jobs and careers" section.
Learning German at a vocational school
Young adults aged between 16 and 21, who do not yet have a strong command of the German language and who still are required to attend school, can visit the “Vocational Integration Class” (in German: “Berufsintegrationsklasse” [in short – BIK]), which is held at the Vocational School Centre (in German: “Staatliches Berufliches Schulzentrum” [in short: BSZ]) in the town of Neusäß.
For young people who cannot yet read and write (well), there are "Intensive Language Classes" (SIK; Sprachintensivklassen). You can obtain information directly from the BSZ.
State Vocational School Centre Neusäß (BSZ)
 Landrat-Dr. Frey-Strasse 12, 86356 Neusäß
 0821 3102 4201
  sekretariat@bszneusaess.de

title: Vocational school
excerpt:
Germany is well known for its dual training system. Vocational schools are part of the dual training system. 
 
Who attends a vocational school?
Some young people have to attend a vocational school. These are young people who...

are doing an apprenticeship and
are between 16 and 21 years old. 

They are subject to compulsory vocational school attendance. 
Trainees with an Abitur or Fachhochschulreife are not required to attend vocational school. They may still attend vocational school. 
 
Duration and aim of vocational school
Duration: two to three years
Goal: Completed vocational training
Qualification: Vocational qualification, intermediate school leaving certificate
 
What do you learn at vocational school? 
The task of the vocational school is to impart theoretical knowledge for the respective profession. Practical knowledge is learnt in the training company. 
However, there are also other subjects. For example 

German
social studies
Religious education
Sport (partially)
Foreign languages (partially) 

There are also optional subjects (e.g. data processing, English). You can take electives voluntarily. But you do not have to. 
 
How and when do lessons take place? 
Vocational school lasts as long as your training in the company. The times are organised differently. There are 

Part-time lessons on individual days of the week (1-2 days each week)
Part-time teaching as block teaching; usually for training occupations with small numbers of trainees (e.g. nine weeks in the company, followed by three weeks of vocational school) 
Full-time instruction (only in the basic vocational school year and vocational preparation year; see below: "Young people without a training place") 

 
What can I do afterwards? 
You have these options after completing vocational school:

Work in your profession
Attend a technical college or academy
Attend a vocational secondary school (BOS)

  
Young people without an apprenticeship
Young people do not always find a training place. If they have not yet completed compulsory schooling, they are required to attend vocational school. 
 
They have two options: 
1. basic vocational school year (BGJ-s for short)
The basic vocational school year is aimed at young people who have not yet found a training place. The vocational school also provides practical training in the first year of the programme. After successfully completing the programme, the trainee immediately enters the 2nd year of training.
However, there are also areas of training in which the BGJ is compulsory. These include 

Professions involving wood (e.g. carpentry)
Professions in agriculture
Professions in home economics 

 
2. vocational preparation year (BVJ for short)
The BVJ prepares young people for an apprenticeship or vocational activity within one year. Compulsory vocational school attendance is deemed to have been fulfilled upon successful completion of the BVJ. If vocational training is subsequently undertaken, the person is again considered to be required to attend vocational school. 
More information is available from the Neusäß State Vocational School Centre: 
Neusäß State Vocational School Centre (BSZ) Landrat-Dr. Frey-Straße 12, 86356 Neusäß  0 8213102 4201  s ekretar iat@bszneusaess.de 
 
 
Search terms: learning for the job, no training place, help with training
content:
Germany is well known for its dual training system. Vocational schools are part of the dual training system.

Who attends a vocational school?

Some young people have to attend a vocational school. These are young people who...

  • are doing an apprenticeship and
  • are between 16 and 21 years old.

They are subject to compulsory vocational school attendance.

Trainees with an Abitur or Fachhochschulreife are not required to attend vocational school. They may still attend vocational school.

Duration and aim of vocational school

Duration: two to three years

Goal: Completed vocational training

Qualification: Vocational qualification, intermediate school leaving certificate

What do you learn at vocational school?

The task of the vocational school is to impart theoretical knowledge for the respective profession. Practical knowledge is learnt in the training company.

However, there are also other subjects. For example

  • German
  • social studies
  • Religious education
  • Sport (partially)
  • Foreign languages (partially)

There are also optional subjects (e.g. data processing, English). You can take electives voluntarily. But you do not have to.

How and when do lessons take place?

Vocational school lasts as long as your training in the company. The times are organised differently. There are

  • Part-time lessons on individual days of the week (1-2 days each week)
  • Part-time teaching as block teaching; usually for training occupations with small numbers of trainees (e.g. nine weeks in the company, followed by three weeks of vocational school)
  • Full-time instruction (only in the basic vocational school year and vocational preparation year; see below: "Young people without a training place")

What can I do afterwards?

You have these options after completing vocational school:

  • Work in your profession
  • Attend a technical college or academy
  • Attend a vocational secondary school (BOS)

Young people without an apprenticeship

Young people do not always find a training place. If they have not yet completed compulsory schooling, they are required to attend vocational school.

They have two options:

1. basic vocational school year (BGJ-s for short)

The basic vocational school year is aimed at young people who have not yet found a training place. The vocational school also provides practical training in the first year of the programme. After successfully completing the programme, the trainee immediately enters the 2nd year of training.

However, there are also areas of training in which the BGJ is compulsory. These include

  • Professions involving wood (e.g. carpentry)
  • Professions in agriculture
  • Professions in home economics

2. vocational preparation year (BVJ for short)

The BVJ prepares young people for an apprenticeship or vocational activity within one year. Compulsory vocational school attendance is deemed to have been fulfilled upon successful completion of the BVJ. If vocational training is subsequently undertaken, the person is again considered to be required to attend vocational school.

More information is available from the Neusäß State Vocational School Centre:

title: Vocational school
excerpt:
Vocational schools provide school-based vocational training.
School-based vocational training is offered for more than 80 professions. The most important fields include, for example, professions... 

in the healthcare sector
in trade
in foreign languages
in the commercial sector
in the areas of housekeeping, social care, childcare or catering
in technology
in music

Depending on the occupational field, there are different admission requirements for vocational schools. 
Duration and aim of the vocational school
Duration: one to three years (depending on the vocational field)
Goal: completed vocational training
Qualification: Vocational qualification, intermediate school leaving certificate, possibly Quabi (qualified vocational qualification), possibly entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences (for special dual qualification programmes)
 
What do you learn at the vocational school? 
The lessons include 

general education subjects
vocational subjects
practical part of vocational training (in some cases this part takes place at co-operating institutions) 

 
How and when do the lessons take place? 
Lessons take place full-time at the vocational college. 
 
What can I do afterwards? 
You have these options after completing vocational school:

Work in your profession
Attending a technical college or academy
Attend vocational college (BOS)

title: Fachoberschule (FOS) and Berufsoberschule (BOS)
excerpt:
Fachoberschule (FOS for short) and Berufsoberschule (BOS for short) both belong to the Berufliche Oberschule Bayern (BOB for short). 
 
Fachoberschule (FOS)
Who attends the FOS? 
To attend the Fachoberschule, you need a secondary school leaving certificate with an average grade of at least 3.5 in German, maths and English. 
 
Duration and aim of the FOS
Duration: two to three years (depending on the qualification) 
Goal: To achieve a higher education qualification (see "Possible qualifications")
Possible qualifications: Fachhochschulreife, subject-restricted higher education entrance qualification, general higher education entrance qualification
The FOS makes it possible to study. 
 
What does the FOS teach?
The FOS provides theoretical knowledge in the following subjects: 

Technology
Business and administration
Social work
Agriculture, biotechnology and environmental technology
Design
Healthcare
International Business

FOS students also complete a 6-month practical training programme. 
 
 Tips for the FOS 

There is a preliminary class for the FOS. The preliminary class prepares students for attending the FOS in one year. More information can be found here. 
There is an application period for the FOS. Please note the deadlines for admission to the FOS! 

 
Vocational secondary school (BOS)
Who attends the BOS? 
For the BOS, you need a secondary school leaving certificate with an average grade of at least 3.5 in German, maths and English. You also need to have completed vocational training. 
 
Duration and aim of the BOS
Duration: one to two years (depending on the qualification)
Goal: To achieve a higher education qualification (see "Possible qualifications")
Possible qualifications: Fachhochschulreife, subject-restricted higher education entrance qualification or general higher education entrance qualification
This enables the BOS to study. 
 
What does the BOS teach? 
The BOS provides a general and specialised theoretical education in the following subjects: 

Technology
Business and administration
Social work
Agriculture, biotechnology and environmental technology
Health
International Business

 
  Tips for BOS 

The BOS can also be attended part-time. 
There are programmes that prepare students for the BOS: Part-time preliminary courses and full-time preliminary classes. More information can be found here. 
The BOS is also available online: The Virtual Vocational High School Bavaria (VIBOS) allows you to combine work and school in the best possible way. The online programme is designed so that you can complete it while working. More information can be found here.
content:
Fachoberschule (FOS for short) and Berufsoberschule (BOS for short) both belong to the Berufliche Oberschule Bayern (BOB for short).

Fachoberschule (FOS)

Who attends the FOS?

To attend the Fachoberschule, you need a secondary school leaving certificate with an average grade of at least 3.5 in German, maths and English.

Duration and aim of the FOS

Duration: two to three years (depending on the qualification)

Goal: To achieve a higher education qualification (see "Possible qualifications")

Possible qualifications: Fachhochschulreife, subject-restricted higher education entrance qualification, general higher education entrance qualification

The FOS makes it possible to study.

What does the FOS teach?

The FOS provides theoretical knowledge in the following subjects:

  • Technology
  • Business and administration
  • Social work
  • Agriculture, biotechnology and environmental technology
  • Design
  • Healthcare
  • International Business

FOS students also complete a 6-month practical training programme.

Tips for the FOS

  • There is a preliminary class for the FOS. The preliminary class prepares students for attending the FOS in one year. More information can be found here.
  • There is an application period for the FOS. Please note the deadlines for admission to the FOS!

Vocational secondary school (BOS)

Who attends the BOS?

For the BOS, you need a secondary school leaving certificate with an average grade of at least 3.5 in German, maths and English. You also need to have completed vocational training.

Duration and aim of the BOS

Duration: one to two years (depending on the qualification)

Goal: To achieve a higher education qualification (see "Possible qualifications")

Possible qualifications: Fachhochschulreife, subject-restricted higher education entrance qualification or general higher education entrance qualification

This enables the BOS to study.

What does the BOS teach?

The BOS provides a general and specialised theoretical education in the following subjects:

  • Technology
  • Business and administration
  • Social work
  • Agriculture, biotechnology and environmental technology
  • Health
  • International Business

Tips for BOS

  • The BOS can also be attended part-time.
  • There are programmes that prepare students for the BOS: Part-time preliminary courses and full-time preliminary classes. More information can be found here.
  • The BOS is also available online: The Virtual Vocational High School Bavaria (VIBOS) allows you to combine work and school in the best possible way. The online programme is designed so that you can complete it while working. More information can be found here.

title: Technical college
excerpt:
Who are technical colleges suitable for?
Vocational schools are for people who

have completed vocational training 
who have professional experience. 

 
What does a technical college offer? 
The technical college offers in-depth vocational training. Graduates of the technical college would like to take on management tasks in the future. Or set up their own company or self-employment. 
 
Duration and goal
Duration:

Up to two years full-time, depending on the specialisation;
part-time or part-time up to 4 years

Qualifications:

State final examination or master craftsman examination,
Secondary school leaving certificate,
general higher education entrance qualification,
entrance qualification for universities of applied sciences (after a supplementary examination)

 
Types of technical colleges in Bavaria 
Technical colleges
approx. 26 training programmes e.g:

Ophthalmic optics,
metal construction technology,
automotive engineering and electromobility,
more here

 
Master schools 
approx. 28 training programmes e.g.

building trades,
hairdresser,
gas and water fitter,
confectioner,
painters and varnishers,
more here

 
Commercial colleges
3 training programmes:

Wood business management,
Textile business management,
Business informatics

 
Home economics and social care technical colleges
4 training programmes:

Family care,
curative education care,
curative education care assistant,
Hotel and catering industry

 
Other specialised schools 
Training programmes e.g:

Floral art,
product design,
product design glass,
Teachers in the social sector

 
Agricultural and forestry college
You can find more information here.

title: Specialised academy
excerpt:
The specialised academy prepares students for a higher professional career. 
 
Duration, degrees and admission requirements
Duration: at least 2 years 
 
Degrees:

State-defined professional qualification,
general higher education entrance qualification,
Fachhochschulreife (after supplementary examination),
with a very good overall grade in both certificates: subject-specific higher education entrance qualification

 
Admission requirements:

Admission requirements vary. Please enquire directly at the respective specialised academy.
As a rule, you need an intermediate school-leaving certificate and previous vocational training (e.g. apprenticeship or work experience). 

 
Training specialisations

Brewing and beverage technology
Performing arts
Foreign language professions
Nutrition and supply management
Curative education
Interior and object design
Medical technology
Restoration training
Social pedagogy
Economy

 
Prospects afterwards
The university of applied sciences can be attended with a supplementary examination.
content:
The specialised academy prepares students for a higher professional career.

Duration, degrees and admission requirements

Duration: at least 2 years

Degrees:

  • State-defined professional qualification,
  • general higher education entrance qualification,
  • Fachhochschulreife (after supplementary examination),
  • with a very good overall grade in both certificates: subject-specific higher education entrance qualification

Admission requirements:

  • Admission requirements vary. Please enquire directly at the respective specialised academy.
  • As a rule, you need an intermediate school-leaving certificate and previous vocational training (e.g. apprenticeship or work experience).

Training specialisations

  • Brewing and beverage technology
  • Performing arts
  • Foreign language professions
  • Nutrition and supply management
  • Curative education
  • Interior and object design
  • Medical technology
  • Restoration training
  • Social pedagogy
  • Economy

Prospects afterwards

The university of applied sciences can be attended with a supplementary examination.

title: Learning German at a vocational school
excerpt:
Young people who do not yet speak German well have the opportunity to learn German at a vocational school.
In the district of Augsburg, all of these courses take place at the Neusäß State Vocational School Centre. 
 
If you have any questions, please contact: 
State Vocational School Centre NeusäßBarbara Dilberowic 0 8213102 4219  B arbara. Dilberowic@bszn.bayern  
 
Co-operative vocational integration class (BIK-K)
The BIK-K is especially for young people with a migration background. There is increased language support. 
The BIK-K includes 

general education subjects
specialised theoretical content 
familiarisation with areas of work in practice
work placements 

Lessons take place on 2 days at the vocational school. On 2 days, the young people are on the premises of a co-operation partner. 
 
Pre-vocational integration class (BIK-V)
The BIK-V prepares students for the BIK-K. It is suitable for young people who require special support in German. Lessons take place full-time at the vocational school. 
 
Vocational school German class (DK-BS-A) 
This class is for young people who have just arrived in Germany. The DK-BS-A is intended for literacy training. 
Young people learn everything about 

the Latin alphabet, 
the German language
and the German school system.

 
 
Search terms: young people learn German, bad German, learn German, no German
content:
Young people who do not yet speak German well have the opportunity to learn German at a vocational school.

In the district of Augsburg, all of these courses take place at the Neusäß State Vocational School Centre.

If you have any questions, please contact:

State Vocational School Centre Neusäß
Barbara Dilberowic
0 8213102 4219
B arbara. Dilberowic@bszn.bayern

Co-operative vocational integration class (BIK-K)

The BIK-K is especially for young people with a migration background. There is increased language support.

The BIK-K includes

  • general education subjects
  • specialised theoretical content
  • familiarisation with areas of work in practice
  • work placements

Lessons take place on 2 days at the vocational school. On 2 days, the young people are on the premises of a co-operation partner.

Pre-vocational integration class (BIK-V)

The BIK-V prepares students for the BIK-K. It is suitable for young people who require special support in German. Lessons take place full-time at the vocational school.

Vocational school German class (DK-BS-A)

This class is for young people who have just arrived in Germany. The DK-BS-A is intended for literacy training.

Young people learn everything about

  • the Latin alphabet,
  • the German language
  • and the German school system.

Search terms: young people learn German, bad German, learn German, no German

title: Graduate from senior school
excerpt:
There are many opportunities to obtain a graduation certificate in Germany, even after the end of regular schooling:
General information on repeating school diplomas
Education advice
Petra Renger
 Volkhartstr. 4-6, 86152 Augsburg
 0821 31022813
 bildungsberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de
International Class at the Evening School for Professionals
For migrants who are already employed, aged between 17 and approx. 30, to achieve a German school-leaving certificate.
Services:

Intensive support in improving the German language
In addition, instruction in a normal evening school class with all regular subjects (German, mathematics, English, physics, history, geography as well as subjects of the compulsory elective subject group economics (business administration/accounting, social studies) or Social (social studies, biology)
Regular classes from 17:30 to 21:05, starting at 16:45: Possibility of study groups, working in the PC room
Support in the search for meaningful professional activities (possibly internship)

Requirements:

Mittelschulabschluss (basic secondary school certificate)
Basic knowledge of German and English (German language level B1, English A2), both spoken and written.
Several years of previous school education in the country of origin or in Germany
Admission interview with school management and / or teacher

Goals:

Advancement to the higher classes of the Abendrealschule with the aim of obtaining a Realschulabschluss (secondary school leaving certificate)
Consolidation of the German language (language level B2)

Evening school for employed persons (in the 1st year). Floor of the Agnes Bernauer School)
 Auf dem Kreuz 36, 86152 Augsburg
 0821-32418410
 abendrealschule@augsburg.de
 www.abendrealschule-augsburg.de
Realschulabschluss (Realschule graduation certificate) at evening Realschule
The following requirements apply to all people who want to catch up on the Realschulabschluss:

Mittelschulabschluss (basic secondary school certificate)
Minimum age of 17
Compulsory education fulfilled, no QA necessary
Parallel employment, but also possible during unemployment
No admission directly from secondary school

Services:

Repeating the Realschulabschluss (Realschule graduation certificate) in three years
Many opportunities for professional advancement
Elective subject group II (BwR, SK, WiR) and III (social studies, biology) possible. Other subjects: German, Maths, English, Physics, History and Geography
Qualification to enter Fachoberschule, Berufsoberschule and Bayernkolleg.

Evening school for working people
(in 1. Floor of the Agnes Bernauer School)
 Auf dem Kreuz 36, 86152 Augsburg
 0821 32418410
 abendrealschule@augsburg.de
 Information is availablehere .
Bayernkolleg Augsburg - Gymnasium des Zweiten Bildungswegs (Gymnasium for Continuing Education)
For all people who are pursuing the Allgemeine Hochschulreife (general qualification for university entrance) (Abitur) and fulfil the following conditions:

Minimum age of 18
Level B1 German language skills and level A1 English language skills
Work experience or training (including in country of origin)

Services:

Preparation for the Allgemeine Hochschulreife (general qualification for university entrance) incl. final exam
Pre-course for refugees and pupils with non-German mother tongue (from language level B1 in German and A1 in English)
Entry stage for refugees and students with mother tongues that are not German (from language level B2 (German) and B1 (English))
The course German as an Education Language in order to prepare for the preparatory course (4 weeks in July).  Note: The language course is subject to a fee.
School counselling
Student halls of residence

Information and registration:
Bavarian College Augsburg
 Schillstraße 94, 86169 Augsburg
 0821 747760
 beratung@bayern-kolleg.de
 www.bayernkolleg-augsburg.de

title: Lifelong Learning
excerpt:
Education is more than just school knowledge. School is an important part of life, but it is not the only place where we learn. That is why the district of Augsburg is just as committed to education outside of the classroom. There is something of interest for every age group, e.g.:

the interesting offer of the Adult Education Centre (VHS) Augsburger Land e.V. with its 34 facilities on site. Here you can find the offers www.vhs-augsburger-land.de
numerous activities for children and young people, for example by the Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land or in the youth centres: You can read everything here.
Offers from the family offices and volunteer centres: all further information under "Family"
You can find offers from other institutions, for example educational institutions, clubs or associations, on the education portal www.bildungsportal-a3.de under"Course search" or under "Education locations"

Guidance on lifelong learning
Education advicePetra Renger Volkhartstr. 4-6, 86152 Augsburg 0821 31022813 bildungsberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de
content:
Education is more than just school knowledge. School is an important part of life, but it is not the only place where we learn. That is why the district of Augsburg is just as committed to education outside of the classroom. There is something of interest for every age group, e.g.:

  • the interesting offer of the Adult Education Centre (VHS) Augsburger Land e.V. with its 34 facilities on site. Here you can find the offers www.vhs-augsburger-land.de
  • numerous activities for children and young people, for example by the Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land or in the youth centres: You can read everything here.
  • Offers from the family offices and volunteer centres: all further information under "Family"
  • You can find offers from other institutions, for example educational institutions, clubs or associations, on the education portal www.bildungsportal-a3.de under"Course search" or under "Education locations"

content:
Educational counselling at the Augsburg District Office

The educational counselling service advises all citizens in the district of Augsburg on vocational topics. For example

  • professional (re)orientation
  • Further training opportunities
  • funding opportunities
  • professional re-entry.

You can contact us about all of these topics:

Educational counselling of the Augsburg District Office
Petra Renger
0 8213102 2813
P etra.Re nger@LRA-a.bayern.de
Volkhartstr. 4-6, 86152 Augsburg
w ww.land kreis-augsburg.de/bildungsberatung

Migration counselling for adults

Target group:

  • Germans with a migration background
  • EU citizens
  • Recognised refugees
  • quota refugees from the age of 27
  • Family members of these groups


Counselling on the following topics:

  • Where can I learn German?
  • How do I apply for a German course?
  • How do I find a flat?
  • Where can I apply for financial aid?
  • Who can help me find a job?
  • Can my degree be recognised in Germany?
  • Which doctor can I go to?
  • Who will help me during my pregnancy?
  • If necessary, accompaniment to offices and authorities by volunteers

title: Education portal A3
excerpt:
Would you like to continue your professional training and are looking for a suitable programme? Are you looking for a language course and don't know where? Would you like to attend a yoga course? Or do you want to do further training to become a business administrator?
Or are you wondering: Where are there libraries in the district? Or kindergartens?
 
Then the A3 education portal is the right place for you!
 
What is the A3 education portal? 
The A3 education portal is a joint project of the city of Augsburg, the district of Augsburgand the district of Aichach-Friedberg. The portal presents all education and counselling services in the region. There is also a lot of up-to-date information on the subject of education and further education.
 
 
What can I find on the A3 education portal? 

Course search: Search for the right educational programme for you.
Counselling services: There is a counselling service in the region for almost every topic in life. You can use the education portal to find the right one for you.
Providers: There are many education providers in the region. You can use the portal to get an overview and search for specific providers.
Funding: The portal provides information on the possibilities of financial support for your further vocational training.
Dates: You can find regional events relating to education and further training on the education portal.

 
Where can I find the A3 education portal? 
Click on this link:
 w ww.bild ungsportal-a3.de

title: What do I need to know?
Multi-lingual information
excerpt:
What industries and companies are there in the district and wider region of Augsburg? Where can I find appealing jobs and the latest vacancies? And how about if I am looking to pursue an entirely new career path? You can find answers to these and other questions on the portal of Regio Augsburg Wirtschaft GmbH at www.region-a3.com/karriere. The regional jobs portal is a particular highlight. This portal collects all regional job offers from the Augsburg area and presents them clearly for you!
You can find very helpful information on finding a job, applying for a job and working in Germany here:

The “Make it in Germany“ portal (in 15 languages): Make it in Germany – The German government’s portal for professionals from abroad:On this platform, the German government provides foreign professionals with information on vocational training and provides help with planning.
Info brochure “Rechte auf dem Arbeitsmarkt” (“Your rights in the job market” – in 5 languages)
You can also find a lot of information about finding a job on the website of the Employment Agency. Multilingual information (in German, English, Arabic and easy language) can be found here.

title: What am I allowed to do? (Employment law)
excerpt:
The requirements you have to fulfil to work in Germany depend on whether you are a national of a member state of the European Union (EU), the European Economic Area (EEA), Switzerland or a citizen of a third country.
EU citizens  / EEA citizens / Swiss citizens have unlimited access to the German job market. You do not need a special permit for employment in Germany.
Citizens from a non-member state need permission to stay long-term in Germany. This is called a residence permit. The residence permit states which access to the labour market is possible for you.
For certain groups, there are special regulations (skilled workers, highly qualified professionals, holders of the EU Blue Card, researchers, self-employed people, jobseekers, employees who come to Germany as part of internal transfers). You can find more information on the subject of residence and work on the BAMF website (www.bamf.de search term "Access to the labour market").
If you have any questions about the right of residence (e.g. residence permit, visa procedure) and work permit, the Office for Foreigners and Integration is there for you:
Office for Foreigners and Integration
Augsburg location: Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg, Schwabmünchen location (Team Asylum): Fuggerstraße 10, 86830 Schwabmünchen
 0821 3102 0
 auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de

title: Writing a cover letter
excerpt:
If you have found an interesting job advertisement, you have to write an application. An application consists of three parts:

Cover letter
Curriculum vitae
Certificates and references

The following office will support you in writing your application:

Employment Agency (BfA) – Career Information Centre (BIZ) Wertachstraße 28, 86153 Augsburg Monday until Wednesday: 7.30 a.m. to 4 p.m., Thursday: 7.30 am till 6 pm; Friday: 7.30 am till 12 pm

There are plenty of examples on how to complete an application available on the Internet:

Make it in Germany (in 14 foreign languages)
Just landed (in six foreign languages)
Planet-Beruf

Writing an unsolicited application
There is no specific job you would like to apply for? But you would like to work in a certain company? Then you can write a speculative application to this company.
That is because vacancies become available all the time in companies. In such cases, companies often first go to the applications they have already received. That is why unsolicited applications are well worth it!
An unsolicited application consists of the same component parts as a normal application. However, there are certain details that need to be noted. You can find tips on the internet, for example at:

www.bewerbung.com/initiativbewerbung
www.azubiyo.de/bewerbung/initiativbewerbung
www.karrierebibel.de/initiativbewerbung

  1. Cover letter

  3. Certificates and references

  • Employment Agency (BfA) – Career Information Centre (BIZ)

     Monday until Wednesday: 7.30 a.m. to 4 p.m., Thursday: 7.30 am till 6 pm; Friday: 7.30 am till 12 pm

An unsolicited application consists of the same component parts as a normal application. However, there are certain details that need to be noted. You can find tips on the internet, for example at:

title: Important information on internships
excerpt:
What is an internship?
An internship is a temporary position. In other words: Interns work for a business for a limited period of time. An internship can be done in almost every profession.
An internship helps you to…

... get to know a new profession,
... get to know a work environment in practice,
... and / or deepen theoretical knowledge through practical (professional) experience.

What are the advantages of an internship?
Doing an internship before embarking on your career can be very helpful.

Interns become familiar with professions and areas of work. They learn which career is the right one for them.
Interns get to know companies and businesses. They find out whether of not they wish to work there.
Interns establish contacts which may be useful when they first embark on their careers.
The company or business gets to know the intern. After the internship, this can end up turning into a paid position or an apprenticeship.

Who benefits from doing an internship?
An internship can be beneficial to anyone. For example, employers consider interns when employing new staff. Internships are particularly useful to:

Pupils,
students,
those who are embarking on their careers (to gain professional experience),
those who wish to change their careers,
people who have been out of work for some time.

The most important kinds of internships
Compulsory internship:

Internship for school pupils:

At school, pupils often have to do a work placement. An internship for school pupils often takes just one or two weeks. The idea is for school pupils to get an idea of what working life is like and get some initial ideas about what direction their careers should take.

Internships whilst at university:

In order to graduate, it is often necessary to do an internship. The schedule and duration are usually determined by academic regulations. The compulsory internships allow students to acquire their first professional experience.
Voluntary internship:
Anyone can do a voluntary internship – whether a school pupil, a student or an adult. The intern and the company or business determine the duration of the internship together.
Payment
During their internships, interns are sometimes paid. But not always. This depends on many factors. For example, the type of internship, the duration, and the sector.
Interns have a right to be paid if

the internship lasts for more than three months
and it is voluntary.

This regulation does not apply to compulsory internships which take place in the context of academic studies. The rule also does not apply to trainees under the age of 18.
content:
What is an internship?

An internship is a temporary position. In other words: Interns work for a business for a limited period of time. An internship can be done in almost every profession.

An internship helps you to…

  • ... get to know a new profession,
  • ... get to know a work environment in practice,
  • ... and / or deepen theoretical knowledge through practical (professional) experience.

What are the advantages of an internship?

Doing an internship before embarking on your career can be very helpful.

  • Interns become familiar with professions and areas of work. They learn which career is the right one for them.
  • Interns get to know companies and businesses. They find out whether of not they wish to work there.
  • Interns establish contacts which may be useful when they first embark on their careers.
  • The company or business gets to know the intern. After the internship, this can end up turning into a paid position or an apprenticeship.

Who benefits from doing an internship?

An internship can be beneficial to anyone. For example, employers consider interns when employing new staff. Internships are particularly useful to:

  • Pupils,
  • students,
  • those who are embarking on their careers (to gain professional experience),
  • those who wish to change their careers,
  • people who have been out of work for some time.

The most important kinds of internships

Compulsory internship:

  • Internship for school pupils:

At school, pupils often have to do a work placement. An internship for school pupils often takes just one or two weeks. The idea is for school pupils to get an idea of what working life is like and get some initial ideas about what direction their careers should take.

  • Internships whilst at university:

In order to graduate, it is often necessary to do an internship. The schedule and duration are usually determined by academic regulations. The compulsory internships allow students to acquire their first professional experience.

Voluntary internship:

Anyone can do a voluntary internship – whether a school pupil, a student or an adult. The intern and the company or business determine the duration of the internship together.

Payment

During their internships, interns are sometimes paid. But not always. This depends on many factors. For example, the type of internship, the duration, and the sector.

Interns have a right to be paid if

  • the internship lasts for more than three months
  • and it is voluntary.

This regulation does not apply to compulsory internships which take place in the context of academic studies. The rule also does not apply to trainees under the age of 18.

title: Important rights and duties when doing an internship
excerpt:
Internship contract:
You do not have to have an internship contract. It is a good idea to have an internship contract, however. This is because it specifies the rules of the internship.
Hours of work:
Depending on your age, there are different regulations about working hours during an internship:

For children and adolescents under the age of 15, it is forbidden to work, generally. Examples of exceptions include work experience for school pupils or, from the age of 13, easy tasks, such as delivering newspapers or providing private tutoring. For adolescents below the age of 15, there is special protection: They are only allowed to work for 7 hours per day, and for no more than 35 hours per week.
For teenagers between 15 and 18 years of age, the rule is: They are only allowed to work for 8 hours per day, and for no more than 40 hours per week.
For interns who are older than 18, standard working hours of 8 hours per day apply. However, standard means: It does not always have to be the case. If there is lots to do, interns are allowed to work for more than 8 hours. It is not allowed to work for more than 10 hours per day.

Breaks:
Interns can, and must, have breaks too. For interns below the age of 18, the rule is: For working hours of between 4.5 and 6 hours, interns must have a break of 30 minutes. For more than 6 working hours, it has to be 60 minutes.
Interns who are older than 18 must have a break of 30 minutes if their working hours exceed 6 hours. For working hours of more than 9 hours, it has to be 45 minutes.
Confidentiality:
During an internship, interns learn a lot about how a business or a company is run. Much of this information is confidential. In other words: Interns are not allowed to mention any of this information to anyone. This is known as “Schweigepflicht” (confidentiality).
For example:
Somebody might be doing an internship at a doctor’s surgery. There, they will learn a lot about the patients. The patients’ names and the illnesses they have, for example. They are not allowed to mention any of this information to anyone.
Illness:
If an intern falls ill, the business providing the internship must be told straight away. Interns often need a medical certificate from their doctor. Interns should ask the company they are doing the internship with whether they need a medical certificate.
Days off:
During a compulsory internship, interns have no entitlement to days off.
During a voluntary internship, it is possible to have days off. This only applies to internships which last for longer than 4 weeks. The number of days off depends on the age of the intern and the length of the internship.
Behaviour in the workplace:
Hosting interns involves a lot of time and work for the host business. Interns ought to be aware of this. They should behave accordingly. You can find tips on this under “Ten tips for interns”.
Entitlement to an internship certificate
Interns have a right to a Praktikumszeugnis (internship certificate). In other words: The company or business must provide an internship certificate.
The internship certificate is important for the intern. It will help when applying for an apprenticeship or work later on.

For adolescents below the age of 15, there is special protection: They are only allowed to work for 7 hours per day, and for no more than 35 hours per week.
  • For teenagers between 15 and 18 years of age, the rule is: They are only allowed to work for 8 hours per day, and for no more than 40 hours per week.
  • For interns who are older than 18, standard working hours of 8 hours per day apply. However, standard means: It does not always have to be the case. If there is lots to do, interns are allowed to work for more than 8 hours. It is not allowed to work for more than 10 hours per day.

Interns have a right to a Praktikumszeugnis (internship certificate). In other words: The company or business must provide an internship certificate.

The internship certificate is important for the intern. It will help when applying for an apprenticeship or work later on.

title: Finding an internship
excerpt:
Finding an internship/ applying for an internship
There are many ways of finding an internship:

You can ask at a business or company in person.
You can send a letter of application to a business or a company.
You can apply online for internships advertised on websites. E.g.:


The Agentur für Arbeit’s (Federal Employment Agency) Jobbörse (job board)
IHK Praktikumsportal (internship portal)
HWK Schwaben Praktikumsbörse (internship board)
content:
Finding an internship/ applying for an internship

There are many ways of finding an internship:

  • You can ask at a business or company in person.
  • You can send a letter of application to a business or a company.
  • You can apply online for internships advertised on websites. E.g.:
  1. The Agentur für Arbeit’s (Federal Employment Agency) Jobbörse (job board)

title: Vocational training
excerpt:
In Germany, you have a better chance of getting a job if you have a suitable education. There are professions for which you need a degree from a university. Other professions can be learned during a vocational apprenticeship.
In Germany, there is an excellent system that provides vocational apprenticeships. A vocational apprenticeship in Germany is very valuable. Many employers look for individuals who have completed a vocational apprenticeship. Those who complete an apprenticeship have excellent prospects in the job market.
There are two different types of vocational apprenticeship: the dual apprenticeship and the school-based apprenticeship.
content:
In Germany, you have a better chance of getting a job if you have a suitable education. There are professions for which you need a degree from a university. Other professions can be learned during a vocational apprenticeship.

In Germany, there is an excellent system that provides vocational apprenticeships. A vocational apprenticeship in Germany is very valuable. Many employers look for individuals who have completed a vocational apprenticeship. Those who complete an apprenticeship have excellent prospects in the job market.

There are two different types of vocational apprenticeship: the dual apprenticeship and the school-based apprenticeship.

title: Dual apprenticeship
excerpt:
How does a dual apprenticeship work?

Candidates learn the theory at a vocational school (1 to 2 days per week) and the practical part at a company (3 to 4 days per week). The training lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
Candidates receive a salary (just how much a person earns depends on the industry, company and year of the apprenticeship).
There are roughly 330 professions for which a candidate can undertake a dual apprenticeship.
Just how a dual apprenticeship works is explained in information films provided by the Bundesinstitut für Berufsbildung (Federal Institute for Vocational Education and Training) in 10 languages (Arabic, Chinese, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish).
How do I find an apprenticeship place?

If you want to complete a dual training programme, you first have to find a training place. You are applying for a training place at a company (enterprise, firm, institution). "training place" means: You have a job in a company, in which you learn the practical work for the profession. Only then comes the registration for the vocational school. The company takes care of the registration.
The following online job exchanges will help you find an apprenticeship:

Job exchange of the employment agency www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
IHK apprenticeship exchange www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de
HWK apprenticeship exchange: www.hwk-schaben.de/lehrstellenb örse 
Azubiyo apprenticeship exchange www.azubiyo.de/ausbildung
Training market www.ausbildungsmarkt.de
AUBI-Plus www.aubi-plus.de
Apprenticeship radar www.lehrstellen-radar.de

In addition to these trainee platforms , there are also other options available online. You can also use these.
You will also find training places

through the "AzubiWelt" app of the Federal Employment Agency (www.arbeitsagentur.de/azubiwelt)
in newspapers,
on company websites,
through unsolicited applications.

Which vocational school should I attend?

In most cases, vocational schools have specialised in what they offer. In the district of Augsburg there are, for example, two subject areas at the vocational school Staatliches Berufliches Schulzentrum Neusäß: Business and Administration (office, industry, retail, wholesale) and Agricultural Economics (agriculture, landscaping, floristry). If you want to do dual training in a different field, you will attend a different vocational school.
Who can help me to look for an apprenticeship?
There are numerous businesses which are on the lookout for candidates who wish to do an apprenticeship. The following pages will help you with your search:

www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de
www.hwk-schwaben.de/lehrstellenboerse

In many countries, the concept of a dual apprenticeship does not exist. This means that many people arriving in Germany from abroad find it difficult to understand the principle of the German dual apprenticeship. The KAUSA service point helps with information and provides intensive support in the search for an apprenticeship, with applications and with all questions during the apprenticeship:
KAUSA Service Point
 Provinostraße 52, Building B6, 86153 Augsburg
 0821 6505 4993
 info@aau-augsburg.de
Good to know: Many businesses put a lot of effort into finding apprentices early on, meaning that apprenticeship places are often fully subscribed and occupied a year in advance.

Which vocational school should I attend?

In most cases, vocational schools have specialised in what they offer. In the district of Augsburg there are, for example, two subject areas at the vocational school Staatliches Berufliches Schulzentrum Neusäß: Business and Administration (office, industry, retail, wholesale) and Agricultural Economics (agriculture, landscaping, floristry). If you want to do dual training in a different field, you will attend a different vocational school.

Who can help me to look for an apprenticeship?

There are numerous businesses which are on the lookout for candidates who wish to do an apprenticeship. The following pages will help you with your search:

  • www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
  • www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de
  • www.hwk-schwaben.de/lehrstellenboerse

In many countries, the concept of a dual apprenticeship does not exist. This means that many people arriving in Germany from abroad find it difficult to understand the principle of the German dual apprenticeship. The KAUSA service point helps with information and provides intensive support in the search for an apprenticeship, with applications and with all questions during the apprenticeship:

KAUSA Service Point
 Provinostraße 52, Building B6, 86153 Augsburg
 0821 6505 4993
 info@aau-augsburg.de

Good to know: Many businesses put a lot of effort into finding apprentices early on, meaning that apprenticeship places are often fully subscribed and occupied a year in advance.

title: Full-time education
excerpt:
How does a school-based apprenticeship work?

You learn a profession primarily in theory at school, depending on the profession at a vocational school, technical college or vocational college. You learn the practical side during the internships. The training lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession. During an apprenticeship, in the majority of cases no salary is paid.
Certain professions in Germany can only be learned as part of a school-based apprenticeship, e.g. a dietician or health and nursing carer.

How do I find an apprenticeship place?

If you want to do a school-based apprenticeship, you apply directly to the school. In the district of Augsburg, you can complete school-based training at five vocational schools (BFS for short):

BFS for Nutrition and Supply, BFS for Child Care and  BFS for Dietary Assistance at the Vocational School Centre / Neusäß
BFS for Nursing / Bobingen
BFS for emergency paramedics / Schwabmünchen (private)

title: An apprenticeship in the public sector
excerpt:
Maybe you are interested in an apprenticeship in the public service? Even if you hold an international passport or were born abroad, you can still start a career in the public sector in Germany. The German civil service is keen to attract committed applicants from all nationalities!
Find out more on the homepage "Wir sind bund" (in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French, Polish and Arabic). Even municipal administrative bodies (e.g. city, community and county government administration bodies) offer apprenticeship places.

title: The German higher education system and helpful links
excerpt:
To be able to study in Germany, you need the school-leaving certificate "Abitur" or "Fachabitur". Usually, you need to speak and write German at level C1 in order to study at university.
You can also start studying in Germany without a university entrance qualification. However, you must have your university admission from your home country recognised as soon as possible.
Different types of universities
In Germany, there are different types of higher education institutions that lead to different degrees and career paths:

Universities: strongly scientifically oriented; suitable if you want to do a doctorate (make the doctorate)
Universities of applied science: very practically focused
Universities of art, film and music: The focus is on artistic subjects such as fine arts, drama, illustration, instrumental music or modern media (direction, camerawork, screenwriting etc.)

All higher education institutions offer Bachelor's and Master's degree programmes.
There are both state and private universities. Most universities in Germany are funded by the state. Private universities sometimes impose high tuition fees.
University of Augsburg and the Augsburg University of Applied Science
In Augsburg, you can either study at the University (www.uni-augsburg.de), at the University of Applied Sciences (www.hs-augsburg.de/international) or at the private University of Applied Sciences for Economics and Management (FOM) for working people (www.fom.de/hochschulzentren/augsburg) .
Advice for people interested in studying
Are you interested in studying in Germany? Then there are agencies and offices that can help you. The advice centres in Germany are known as the “International Office” (“Akademisches Auslandsamt”). There you can get advice on all formalities and questions about studying. These offices also organise numerous intercultural activities. This makes it easier for you to get to know German and other foreign students in Augsburg.
Interesting links for studying in Germany


General information about studying in Germany can be found here www.daad.de/de/ (also in English)
www.study-in-germany.de (in German and English)
Free preparatory course for university studies in Germany: Ready for Study
Free online university for refugees: Kiron Open Higher Education

  • Universities of applied science: very practically focused
  • Universities of art, film and music: The focus is on artistic subjects such as fine arts, drama, illustration, instrumental music or modern media (direction, camerawork, screenwriting etc.)

title: Becoming self-employed – starting your own business
excerpt:
If you do not want to be employed by an employer, you can start your own business (also called "business start-up"). You should inform yourself well in advance.
The portal “Wir gründen in Deutschland!” (“We’re starting a business in Germany!”) provides lots of helpful information on starting a business, and is available in 14 languages (Arabic, Bosnian, Chinese, Dari, German, English, French, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Tigrinya, Turkish, Ukrainian, Vietnamese).
Advice Centre at the district administration of Augsburg
Business development support is regularly offered by the district administration of Augsburg in collaboration with the association Aktivsenioren Bayern e.V. and Digitales Zentrum Schwaben. You can find more detailed information at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/existenzgruenderberatung. If you have any questions, please contact:
Business start-ups in IT, new media and digitisation:
Mr Herwig Leiter
 0821 3102 2198
 herwig.leiter@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
Advice from the Swabian Chamber of Industry and Commerce
The Augsburg District Office works together with the Swabian Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK Schwaben), particularly on issues relating to start-ups, financing and subsidies. There are experts here who can help you with different questions.
Mr Jürgen Wager
 Stettenstraße 1+3, 86150 Augsburg
 08213162255
