title: Vocational further education
excerpt:
Would you like to develop professionally, catch up on a degree or move up the career ladder? In the district of Augsburg you have many opportunities!
Preparatory training school (Fachschule) in the district of Augsburg
There are three preparatory training schools (Fachschulen), which can prepare you for taking on managerial tasks or even self-employed work:

Landwirtschaftsschule (Agricultural college) / Schwabmünchen
Landwirtschaftsschule (Agricultural college) / Stadtbergen

Fachoberschule (Technical College – FOS) and Berufsoberschule (Vocational High School – BOS)
At the Fachoberschule (FOS) and Berufsoberschule (BOS) (with the specialisations social work, business and administration, agricultural economics, biotechnology and environmental technology) at the Staatliche Berufliche Schulzentrum Neusäß you can acquire the higher education entrance qualification. The higher education entrance qualification is required if you want to study.
Qualifications
Many institutions offer different qualifications. Through these qualifications you can expand your knowledge and skills. As partners for vocational further education, you can pursue your learning objectives at the Adult Education Centre (Volkshochschule [VHS] Augsburger Land e.V.) with its 34 regional locations in the district, or the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK) as well as the Chamber of Trade (HWK) for Swabia where students have many different further education options to choose from.
You can find detailed information here:

www.bildungsportal-a3.de
www.arbeitsagentur.de/karriere-und-weiterbildung
www.region-a3.com/karriere/bildung-plus/weiterbildung

Qualification counselling
You have a degree or vocational qualification and would like to develop professionally? Are you looking for a suitable qualification measure? Do you have questions about financing the qualification? Then contact the qualification counselling service:
Qualification Advice Centre at Tür an Tür e.V.
 Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Augsburg
 0821 90799 14
 qualifizierungsberatung@tuerantuer.de
 
Education advice
Do you want to reorientate yourself professionally or get ahead? Are you looking for a suitable further education programme? Would you like to find out about your possible educational pathways? Then contact the educational counselling service of the Augsburg district:
Petra Renger
 Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
 0821 31022813
  petra.renger@LRA-a.bayern.de

title: Labour law and advice on unfair treatment
excerpt:
Advice on labour law
MigraNet - Fair integration
Target group

Refugees
Migrants from third countries in employment, training or internships who want to find out about their rights as employees 

Counselling content:

Rights as employees
Questions about the employment contract
Questions about pay
Unfair treatment in the workplace
Uncertainty as to whether your rights as an employee
are being respected 

Languages:

German
English, German
Arabic 

European Association for Migrant Workers' Issues Mr Mustafa Alia Wertachstraße 29, 86153 Augsburg  0 1755355 867  m ustafa. alia@emwu.org  w ww.fair e-integration.de 
 
Fair mobility
Target group: 
Workers from a Central or Eastern European country
 
Counselling content:

Wages and minimum wage
Dealing with overtime
Holiday entitlement
Work and health
Accident and health insurance
Close cooperation with advice centres
Enforcement of rights

Counselling is free of charge!
Languages

German
Bulgarian
Romanian
Romanian
French 

 Counselling hours:
Tuesday, 9 am to 12 noon + Thursday, 10 am to 12 noon and 2 pm to 4 pmor by prior appointment by telephone
 
 Telephone consultation hours:
Monday, 2 pm to 4 pm + Tuesday and Wednesday, 10.30 am to 12.30 pm
 
German Trade Union Confederation (DBG) Bavaria
 Mrs Nadia Kluge DBG Trade Union Centre, House C 5.12, Schwanthalerstraße 64, 80336 Munich  0 8951399 018  k luge@fa ire-mobilitaet.de  w ww.fair e-mobilitaet.de 
or:
 Mrs Sevghin Mayr 0 8951242 772  m ayr@fai re-mobilitaet.de 
 
Equal treatment centre for employees from the EU
EU citizens have the right to free movement of labour. This means that they can work in any EU country. They do not need a special work permit to do so.
All employees should have the same rights in EU countries. The Equal Treatment Office informs EU workers and their families about their rights in Germany.
Do you have questions about your rights? Then ask at:
Equal Treatment Centre for EU Workers
Staff of the Federal Government Commissioner for Migration, Refugees and Integration Federal Chancellery, 11012 Berlin  i nfo@eu- gleichbehandlungsstelle.de 
Or via the counselling form: w ww.eu-g leichbehandlungsstelle.de 
 
You can find lots of information on the website of the Equal Treatment Office. And also advice centres in your area. The information is available in 11 languages.

title: By women for women: Take Off! Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women
excerpt:
By women for women: The project "Take Off! Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women" project supports women with their own migration experience. They discover their skills and develop further: linguistically, professionally and personally. In doing so, they find their way to combine family and job. The women receive confidential counselling and professional support. The programme is free of charge.
 
The services: 
Counselling and support

Training or further education
Job search and applications
Internships and career entry
All about education and childcare 
Training courses and workshops

Understanding Germany and the labour market better
Improve your German language skills
Get to know and use computers 
Network and exchange

Women's get-together - support with everyday issues
Events in Augsburg and the region 
Individual and group coaching sessions

Uncovering competences
Activating resources
Developing personal goals
Job application coaching  

Who is part of the project?
In "Take Off! Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women", Tür an Tür-Integrationsprojekte gGmbH works in a project network with BIB Augsburg gGmbH, Eckert Schulen, Visiones e.V. and Diakonie Augsburg.
It also cooperates with the Jobcenters Augsburg Stadt, Augsburg Land and Wittelsbacher Land as well as the Augsburg Employment Agency.
 
How is the project funded?
The project is part of MyTurn - Women with migration experience get started. "MyTurn" is a nationwide programme.
Funding comes from Germany and Europe. In Germany from the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS), in the European Union (EU) from the European Social Fund (ESF Plus).
 
Where can I find more information?
Since May, there has been a central contact point at Wertachstraße 29 for the project "Take Off! Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women". Interested parties can get information about the programmes here. Personal counselling (without an appointment) is available on Thursdays between 10am and 12pm and between 2pm and 4pm.
 
Door to doorProject "Take off! Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women" Wertachstr. 29, 86153 Augsburg Thursday from 10 am to 12 pm and from 2 pm to 4 pm (without appointment)
 
You can also find all the latest information on the programmes on  Instagram and Facebook.

title: Skilled Labour Immigration Act
excerpt:
What is the Skilled Labour Immigration Act?
Skilled workers can immigrate to Germany more easily. This applies to skilled workers with 

vocational training lasting at least two years or a university degree.
a university degree. 

The Skilled Labour Immigration Act sets out the rules.
There will be changes to the Skilled Immigration Act from November 2023. You can find out more here.
 
Criteria for skilled workers
The following three criteria are generally considered: 
 
1) Qualification
With the EU Blue Card, skilled workers with a recognised qualification can come to Germany. 
2) Experience
People with professional experience may come to Germany. This applies to people who...


have acquired a recognised professional qualification abroad and
can prove at least 2 years of professional experience. 



A salary threshold applies to these people. This means that they must earn more money than the specified minimum amount. People without a professional qualification recognised abroad must have their professional qualification recognised in Germany. 
 
3) PotentialPeople without a concrete job offer can also work in Germany. The opportunity card was introduced for them. It is based on a points system. These criteria are taken into account: 

Qualifications
German and English language skills
work experience
Relevance to Germany
Age
Potential of spouses and partners

 
An important innovation for asylum seekers
Are you an asylum seeker? And you arrived before 29 March 2023? Then you can apply for a residence permit as a skilled worker. You do not have to leave the country. And you do not have to go through a visa procedure. You must withdraw your application for asylum.
That's what you need: 

a recognised qualification 
a job offer or an existing employment relationship

 
Hotline for individual counselling
You can obtain individual counselling in German and English via the Federal Government's hotline: 
 
Hotline "Working and living in Germany" +493018151111  w ww.make -it-in-germany.com/de/service/kontakt/hotline
content:
What is the Skilled Labour Immigration Act?

Skilled workers can immigrate to Germany more easily. This applies to skilled workers with

  • vocational training lasting at least two years or a university degree.
  • a university degree.

The Skilled Labour Immigration Act sets out the rules.

There will be changes to the Skilled Immigration Act from November 2023. You can find out more here.

Criteria for skilled workers

The following three criteria are generally considered:

1) Qualification
With the EU Blue Card, skilled workers with a recognised qualification can come to Germany.

2) Experience
People with professional experience may come to Germany. This applies to people who...
    • have acquired a recognised professional qualification abroad and
    • can prove at least 2 years of professional experience.

A salary threshold applies to these people. This means that they must earn more money than the specified minimum amount. People without a professional qualification recognised abroad must have their professional qualification recognised in Germany.

3) Potential
People without a concrete job offer can also work in Germany. The opportunity card was introduced for them. It is based on a points system. These criteria are taken into account:

  • Qualifications
  • German and English language skills
  • work experience
  • Relevance to Germany
  • Age
  • Potential of spouses and partners

An important innovation for asylum seekers

Are you an asylum seeker? And you arrived before 29 March 2023? Then you can apply for a residence permit as a skilled worker. You do not have to leave the country. And you do not have to go through a visa procedure. You must withdraw your application for asylum.

That's what you need:

  • a recognised qualification
  • a job offer or an existing employment relationship

Hotline for individual counselling

You can obtain individual counselling in German and English via the Federal Government's hotline:

Hotline "Working and living in Germany"
+493018151111
w ww.make -it-in-germany.com/de/service/kontakt/hotline

title: Recognition of foreign professional qualifications
excerpt:
Certificates play an important role in Germany for school, university or work. They are proof of what you have already learnt and achieved. Certificates of school-leaving qualifications or professional qualifications are the decisive prerequisite for getting a job, a training place or a place at university.
If you have already obtained qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or at university abroad, it often makes sense for the certificates to be recognised in Germany. This means that it will be checked what you are qualified to do with your certificates in Germany.
It may be that you no longer have your certificates. In this case, you can try to prove your work experience and professional skills by taking tests.
 
IQ recognition and qualification counselling
Have you gained a vocational qualification abroad? Have you already gained work experience abroad? Then the Recognition and Qualification Counselling Service is the right place for you. 
The counselling centre will look at your documents. It then compares your qualification with the German qualification. For example, the duration or content is compared. Relevant work experience is also taken into account. 
At the end, you will receive an assessment of whether you can get your qualification recognised or not. Sometimes there are too many differences between the foreign and German qualifications. 
 
Because there are many factors to consider when recognising professional qualifications, it is best to seek advice: 
Door to door - Recognition and qualification counselling  a nerkenn ungsberatung@tuerantuer.de  0 8214551 090  w ww.migr anet.org/angebote/ratsuchende/anerkennungsberatung  Telephone consultation hours: Monday and Thursday from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m., Tuesday from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. 
 
Recognition grant
Recognising a foreign qualification costs money. The costs vary depending on the profession. Some people can apply for a recognition grant.
This applies to people who

live permanently in Germany,
have a low income and
are working below their professional qualification.

 
Get advice directly by email or phone:
Research Institute for Vocational Education and Training (f-bb) gGmbH 0 3714331 1222  a nerkenn ungszuschuss@f-bb.de 
 
Further detailed information
You can also find detailed information on the "Recognition in Germany" portal in eleven languages at www.anerkennung-in-deutschland.de.
The portal also offers a recognition app in German, English, Arabic, Dari, Farsi, Pashto and Tigrinya.

title: Family, children, young people and the elderly
Orientation for families
excerpt:
Family guide
Are you pregnant and would like some advice? Are you looking for a competent contact person for questions about parenting? Or do you need holiday care for your child? There is a contact point for every question in the district of Augsburg.
The Augsburg District Office has compiled all the services, advice centres and contact persons for you in the "Family Guide" brochure. Just take a look!
 
Helpful information on family topics
The Federal Ministry for Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth provides information on family topics from A to Z at: www.familienportal.de.
 
Parents' guide in 16 languages
Parenting prepares children for their future lives. Parenting lays the foundation for your child to develop into a strong and self-confident personality. Raising children well is therefore a challenge.
The guidebook "Strong through education" aims to support all parents in this challenge.
The guide is available in 16 foreign languages(Albanian, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Croatian, Portuguese, Russian, Serbian, Somali, Spanish, Tamil, Thai, Tigrinya, Turkish)
 
Information portal "Parents on the Net"
The online portal "Parents on the Net" also provides answers to many specific questions, for example about parenting or starting school. You can also find letters for parents there. These letters support you in the first 18 years of your child's life with practical tips and information. Just take a look at www.elternimnetz.de.
 
Children have rights too
The rights of children can be found in various languages. It is important that children and young people know their rights too. That is why there is also a child-friendly version in various languages:

www.unicef.de (search term: "Convention on the Rights of the Child")
www.bmfsfj.de (search term: "The rights of the child")

 
 
Keywords: Help for parents, help for families, information for parents, family counselling, raising children, children's rights, children's rights

The Augsburg District Office has compiled all the services, advice centres and contact persons for you in the "Family Guide" brochure. Just take a look!

Helpful information on family topics

These letters support you in the first 18 years of your child's life with practical tips and information. Just take a look at www.elternimnetz.de.

Children have rights too

title: Counselling for pregnant women and "new" parents
excerpt:
The birth of a child is a special experience for every mum and dad. Parenthood brings new and sometimes difficult situations. Parents can receive professional support.
 
Pregnancy counselling
Pregnancy counselling advises you on questions relating to pregnancy. Pregnancy counselling helps: 

With questions about financial aid
When women want to terminate the pregnancy ("pregnancy conflict counselling")
If no one should know about the birth ("confidential birth")
For questions about prenatal diagnostics (tests for diseases in the unborn child)
Questions about becoming a parent or being a father
Questions about the unfulfilled desire to have children

Counselling is free of charge. Counselling is anonymous on request.
 
You can contact the pregnancy counselling service in the district of Augsburg:
Susanne Kierok 0821 3102 2103 Susanne.kierok@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
Sybille Weiß 0821 3102 2110 Sybille.weiss@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
 Appointments can also be made via the virtual citizens' office. 
 
More information at:  www.landkreis-augsburg.de/soziales-gesundheit/staatliches-gesundheitsamt/schwangerenberatung/
 
The state-recognised advice centre for pregnancy issues pro familia Augsburg e.V. can also help you with any questions you may have:
 Hermanstraße 1, 86150 Augsburg 0821 4503620 augsburg@profamilia.de www.profamilia.de/augsburg
Counselling is free, anonymous, non-binding and impartial.
 
 
Early Childhood Network - KoKi 
The Early Childhood Network - KoKi offers parents early and uncomplicated help. The specialists provide support in difficult situations. They help with questions about parenting. They provide information about help options. You can trust the specialists. The professionals are bound to confidentiality. They are therefore not allowed to talk to others about your conversation. Counselling is free of charge.
Network KoKi 0821 3102 2339 Fruehehilfen-koki@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
Further contact points
You can find further counselling centres here.
 
 
 
Keywords: counselling for pregnant women, counselling for parents, help during pregnancy, unintentionally childless, childlessness, no children, abortion,

title: Important information on pregnancy and birth
excerpt:
Pregnant women are under special protection in Germany. They are entitled to counselling and medical care.
 
Guide "Maternal health"
The "MaternalHealthGuide" provides answers to many specific questions. It is available in seven languages:

English 
Kurdish
Russian 
Turkish 
Arabic 
Serbo-Croatian

 
 
Pregnant - and now?
If you are pregnant, you must first go to the gynaecologist (gynaecologist). Have the check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass. The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child. Always take your maternity record with you in case of emergencies.
 
 During pregnancy and in the postnatal period, pregnant women can be accompanied by a midwife. Would you like support from a midwife? Then it's best to look early! Each midwife can only look after a few pregnant women. They are therefore fully booked early. You can find a midwife, for example, via the midwife list of the pregnancy counselling centre at Augsburg District Office. 
 
For medical questions about family planning, pregnancy and birth
On the "Zanzu" portal, you can find information in 13 languages on topics such as family planning and pregnancy. There is also a dictionary of medical terms.
The health project MiMi (With migrants for migrants) offers information on the individual stages of pregnancy in the "Guide to maternal health".
The guide (search term: maternal health) is available at

Arabic
German 
English 
Kurdish 
Russian
Serbo-Croatian
Turkish 

 
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women enjoy special protection - known as maternity protection. Maternity protection begins six weeks before the birth and ends eight weeks afterwards.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany. During this time, pregnant women are generally not allowed to work. Your job remains the same. You can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women are not allowed to work more than 8.5 hours a day. You are also not allowed to do any heavy physical labour.
You can find out more about this from your employer, from one of the advice centres listed below or here.
 
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or social assistance. After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the job centre or social welfare office will then pay expectant mothers additional needs. And also the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
 
Delivery and aftercare
Your gynaecologist will refer you to a maternity clinic. Ask there for a midwife for aftercare. If the clinic does not provide a midwife, contact "Frühe Hilfen/ KoKi".
You will receive a birth certificate from the clinic. You will need a birth certificate from the registry office to apply for a birth certificate for your child. You will also need the birth certificate if you apply for parental allowance.
 
Notification to the registry office
Newborn children must be registered at the registry office. The maternity clinic is responsible for registering the birth with the registry office.
You need the following for the birth certificate: 

Your identity card
the birth certificate from the clinic
Your marriage certificate (if available)

 
What to do in the event of an unwanted pregnancy?
Pregnancy is not always wanted. There are support options in the district.
The pregnancy counselling service provides advice if

women want to terminate the pregnancy ("pregnancy conflict counselling") or
nobody should know about the birth ("confidential birth").

 
Counselling is free of charge and anonymous if desired.
 
Pregnancy counsellingSusanne Kierok 0821 3102 2103 Susanne.kierok@LRA-a.bayern.de
Sybille Weiß 0821 3102 2110 Sybille.weiss@LRA-a.bayern.de

 
 Appointments can also be made via the  Virtual Citizens' Office. 
 
Helpline for pregnant women in need
The helpline helps pregnant women when

they are in difficult life situations or
no longer know what to do
want to hide their pregnancy. 

The helpline is anonymous and free of charge. The counselling is confidential. This means that no other person will find out about the telephone call. 
Counselling is available in 18 languages.
Helpline for pregnant women in need 08004040020
 
Termination of pregnancy (abortion)
Sometimes women want to terminate a pregnancy. This can be carried out without penalty up to the end of the 12th week of pregnancy.
 
The following conditions must be met for this:

Counselling at a state-recognised counselling centre that issues a counselling certificate
Three-day waiting period between counselling and abortion
The abortion is performed by a doctor. 

 
Here you will find brief information on abortion in several languages.
 
State-recognised pregnancy counselling centres in Augsburg
At pro familia you can get counselling on these topics: 

Pregnancy and birth (until the child is three years old)
Considerations regarding abortion
Family planning and contraception
Sex education
Partnership and sexuality
Separation and divorce

 
State-recognised advice centre for pregnancy issues pro familia Augsburg e.V. Hermanstraße 1, 86150 Augsburg 0821 4503620 augsburg@profamilia.de www.profamilia.de/augsburg
 
The following applies to asylum seekers:
Notify the forthcoming birth to the Office for Social Benefits and your accommodation service. The accommodation service will check whether there is enough space for the child in the accommodation. A baby cot will also be ordered. 
 
Newborn children must be reported to the accommodation management. Please give your accommodation manager a copy of the birth certificate. Your child will then be registered.
 
 
 
Keywords: pregnant, pregnancy, maternity protection, family planning, birth, childbirth, help for pregnant women, abortion, financial support for pregnant women, counselling for pregnant women
content:
Pregnant women are under special protection in Germany. They are entitled to counselling and medical care.

Guide "Maternal health"

The "MaternalHealthGuide" provides answers to many specific questions. It is available in seven languages:

  • English
  • Kurdish
  • Russian
  • Turkish
  • Arabic
  • Serbo-Croatian

Pregnant - and now?

If you are pregnant, you must first go to the gynaecologist (gynaecologist). Have the check-ups carried out there.

You will then receive a maternity pass. The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child. Always take your maternity record with you in case of emergencies.

During pregnancy and in the postnatal period, pregnant women can be accompanied by a midwife. Would you like support from a midwife? Then it's best to look early! Each midwife can only look after a few pregnant women. They are therefore fully booked early. You can find a midwife, for example, via the midwife list of the pregnancy counselling centre at Augsburg District Office.

For medical questions about family planning, pregnancy and birth

On the "Zanzu" portal, you can find information in 13 languages on topics such as family planning and pregnancy. There is also a dictionary of medical terms.

The health project MiMi (With migrants for migrants) offers information on the individual stages of pregnancy in the "Guide to maternal health".

The guide (search term: maternal health) is available at

  • Arabic
  • German
  • English
  • Kurdish
  • Russian
  • Serbo-Croatian
  • Turkish

Maternity protection for working pregnant women

Working pregnant women enjoy special protection - known as maternity protection. Maternity protection begins six weeks before the birth and ends eight weeks afterwards.

This protection is regulated by law in Germany. During this time, pregnant women are generally not allowed to work. Your job remains the same. You can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.

In addition, pregnant women are not allowed to work more than 8.5 hours a day. You are also not allowed to do any heavy physical labour.

You can find out more about this from your employer, from one of the advice centres listed below or here.

Financial support

If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or social assistance. After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the job centre or social welfare office will then pay expectant mothers additional needs. And also the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.

Delivery and aftercare

Your gynaecologist will refer you to a maternity clinic. Ask there for a midwife for aftercare. If the clinic does not provide a midwife, contact "Frühe Hilfen/ KoKi".

You will receive a birth certificate from the clinic. You will need a birth certificate from the registry office to apply for a birth certificate for your child. You will also need the birth certificate if you apply for parental allowance.

Notification to the registry office

Newborn children must be registered at the registry office. The maternity clinic is responsible for registering the birth with the registry office.

You need the following for the birth certificate:

  • Your identity card
  • the birth certificate from the clinic
  • Your marriage certificate (if available)

What to do in the event of an unwanted pregnancy?

Pregnancy is not always wanted. There are support options in the district.

The pregnancy counselling service provides advice if

  • women want to terminate the pregnancy ("pregnancy conflict counselling") or
  • nobody should know about the birth ("confidential birth").

Counselling is free of charge and anonymous if desired.

Pregnancy counselling
Susanne Kierok
0821 3102 2103
Susanne.kierok@LRA-a.bayern.de

Sybille Weiß
0821 3102 2110
Sybille.weiss@LRA-a.bayern.de

Appointments can also be made via the Virtual Citizens' Office.

Helpline for pregnant women in need

The helpline helps pregnant women when

  • they are in difficult life situations or
  • no longer know what to do
  • want to hide their pregnancy.

The helpline is anonymous and free of charge. The counselling is confidential. This means that no other person will find out about the telephone call.

Counselling is available in 18 languages.

Helpline for pregnant women in need
08004040020

Termination of pregnancy (abortion)

Sometimes women want to terminate a pregnancy. This can be carried out without penalty up to the end of the 12th week of pregnancy.

The following conditions must be met for this:

  • Counselling at a state-recognised counselling centre that issues a counselling certificate
  • Three-day waiting period between counselling and abortion
  • The abortion is performed by a doctor.

Here you will find brief information on abortion in several languages.

State-recognised pregnancy counselling centres in Augsburg

At pro familia you can get counselling on these topics:

  • Pregnancy and birth (until the child is three years old)
  • Considerations regarding abortion
  • Family planning and contraception
  • Sex education
  • Partnership and sexuality
  • Separation and divorce

State-recognised advice centre for pregnancy issues pro familia Augsburg e.V.
Hermanstraße 1, 86150 Augsburg
0821 4503620
augsburg@profamilia.de
www.profamilia.de/augsburg

The following applies to asylum seekers:

Notify the forthcoming birth to the Office for Social Benefits and your accommodation service. The accommodation service will check whether there is enough space for the child in the accommodation. A baby cot will also be ordered.

Newborn children must be reported to the accommodation management. Please give your accommodation manager a copy of the birth certificate. Your child will then be registered.

Keywords: pregnant, pregnancy, maternity protection, family planning, birth, childbirth, help for pregnant women, abortion, financial support for pregnant women, counselling for pregnant women

title: Childcare
excerpt: In the district of Augsburg, day care is available for children in publicly run institutions (such as nurseries and kindergartens). There are also many different schools that are run to a very high degree of quality. In addition to children's day care centres and schools, there are also many educational offers available for children, young people and adults.
content: In the district of Augsburg, day care is available for children in publicly run institutions (such as nurseries and kindergartens). There are also many different schools that are run to a very high degree of quality. In addition to children's day care centres and schools, there are also many educational offers available for children, young people and adults.

title: Essential information about child care
excerpt:
In Germany, there are numerous offers of child care at child day care centres and with childminders. Childcare has many advantages for you. The child key workers (“Erzieher”) are very highly qualified and undertake interesting projects with the children. This way, your children learn a lot of new things in a positive atmosphere. Above all, your children learn the German language very quickly. They also create friendships with other children. That is very important. This is because children need other children to play with, to learn with and to build friendships with.
All of these benefits are shown in several short films on childcare in Germany (available in German, English, French, Russian, Arabic, Farsi, Dari, Turkish, Kurdish, Tigrinya). You can also see how children learn and play best in their first years of life. Look at both sides:
 www.kita.bayern.de
 www.bvktp.de/themen/kinder-mit-fluchthintergrund

title: Types of child care
excerpt:
Depending on the child’s age, Germany offers different types of child day care:

Nursery for children under the age of three
Kindergarden for children from the age of three up to school age
“Häuser für Kinder” for ages 1 to 12 (child day care centres with mixed age groups)
After-schoolcare for children from school until the age of 14. Year of life

Another option is childminding (Kindertagespflege). In this form, your child is cared for by a qualified and certified day care worker (also known as a "childminder"). This form of day care typically takes place with the day carer at home. In the district of Augsburg, the Expert Centre for Childminding (Fachstelle Kindertagespflege) is on hand to help you find a day carer.
Child day care centre
Petra Hetzner
 0821 3102 2644
 petra.hetzner@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can find more information on the website of the district of Augsburg.
 
 Are you in search of suitable child care?
Are you looking for childcare for your child? Your child is already being looked after, but you have further questions? Then contact our specialist office at the Augsburg District Office:
Child Day Care and Child Day Care Unit
Petra Hetzner
 0821 3102 2644
 petra.hetzner@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
Child day care in your community
You want to know: What types of child care are there in my community? Then look at the education portal a3 (www.bildungsportal-a3.de) under "Places of education".

title: Care for schoolchildren
excerpt:
For many parents it is important to be able to balance family and work life. The district of Augsburg offers many options to make this possible. This includes school-based services (such as all-day classes or lunch-time supervision at schools) and out-of-school services (such as after-school care for children from school until the age of 14). Year of life).
You can find more detailed information at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schule-und-familie/ganztagsschule.html and on the page of the district office under www.landkreis-augsburg.de/ganztagsschulen.

This includes school-based services (such as all-day classes or lunch-time supervision at schools) and out-of-school services (such as after-school care for children from school until the age of 14). Year of life).

You can find more detailed information at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schule-und-familie/ganztagsschule.html and on the page of the district office under www.landkreis-augsburg.de/ganztagsschulen.

title: Costs for day care
excerpt:
If you want your child to be looked after in an institution or by a childminder, you have to pay a fee. The fee depends on the facility or the childminder, but also, for example, on your income and the weekly care time. If you have a low income, you can be exempted from the costs www.landkreis-augsburg.de/uebernahme-kitabeitrag.
Financial support for child care, if your child is under three years of age
As an "indirect reduction" of the Kita fees, all parents with children in the second and third year of life (i.e. from the 13th to the 36th year of life) receive a discount on the Kita fees. Month of life) the Bavarian family allowance. You automatically receive the family allowance if you have already applied for parental allowance.
Do you have questions about the Bavarian family allowance? Then contact:
Centre Bavaria Family and Social Affairs
Swabia region
 Morellstraße 30, 86159 Augsburg
 0821 5709 3202
 poststelle.schw@zbfs.bayern.de
 
Financial support for child care for children from the age of three
Since 1 April 2019, parents in Bavaria have been receiving help with the cost of kindergarten. Parents receive a subsidy of 100 euros per month and per child (from 1 September of the year in which the child turns three, and up to when they begin school). Parents do not have to apply for this. The kindergarten fee is then automatically reduced on the part of the child care provider.
You can find more information here.
The costs of care for children of school age

School services are offered free of charge. Only smaller sums of money (e.g. for lunchtime meals) must be paid. Any out-of-school offers are, however, subject to a charge. The costs can vary depending on the institution. Therefore, ask the institution directly.

title: Holiday child care
excerpt:
Holidays are, without doubt, the most wonderful time of year for children. But for working parents, the school holidays often present an organisational challenge. If relatives, friends or neighbours are unable to help when it comes to child care, the situation is difficult.
In many towns and communities, that is why there is also child care available during the holidays. Holiday offers from the youth associations and the Augsburg District Youth Ring are also open to your children. Find out more at:

Your municipality or the town hall
via the education portal a3 www.bildungsportal-a3.de
the Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land www.kjr-augsburg.de/#holidayprogramme.

Is your child looked after by an institution (e.g. after-school care) during school hours? Then there are also offers available during the school holidays here. Ask your institution directly.
You can find an overview of all public holidays and school holidays in the "Everyday life" section under "Public holidays, school holidays and time changeover".

  • Your municipality or the town hall
  • via the education portal a3 www.bildungsportal-a3.de
  • the Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land www.kjr-augsburg.de/#holidayprogramme.

You can find an overview of all public holidays and school holidays in the "Everyday life" section under "Public holidays, school holidays and time changeover".

title: Activities for children and teenagers
excerpt:
Offers by the Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land (District Youth Group)
The Kreisjugendring (district youth group) has numerous offers for children and adolescents, e.g. child and adolescent free time activities. Find out more under www.kjr-augsburg.de.
Youth centres
Children and adolescents can spend their free time at youth centres, youth houses and youth meeting points, where they can work on activities together, cook together or simply chat and relax. The pedagogical professionals at the youth centres are on hand to support and advise young people in a range of different situations. There are full-time youth centres in Bobingen, Diedorf, Gersthofen, Graben, Königsbrunn, Neusäß, Schwabmünchen, Stadtbergen, Untermeitingen, Welden.

title: Youth and Family Office (Amt für Jugend und Familie)
excerpt:
The Office for Youth and Family (Youth Welfare Office) supports parents and their children 
The Office for Youth and Family Affairs (known as the Youth Welfare Office for short)  supports parents and guardians in the upbringing, care and education of children and young people. For this, it provides preventative, family-friendly services that help to create positive living conditions for families. It is the point of contact for all questions, uncertainties and issues relating to this topic. The following also applies: Better to be too early than too late!
If you have any questions, feel free to contact the staff at the Youth and Family Office. The professionals there are happy to help you and only want the best for you and your family!
The task of the Youth and Family Office is also to protect children and adolescents. This is because they also have a right to grow up in a healthy and protected environment (please see the information section entitled “Children also have rights” [“Auch Kinder haben Rechte”]). The members of staff will also investigate any indication that a child could be in danger.
The Youth and Family Office therefore fulfils the tasks set out under the Child and Adolescent Protection Act (Kinder- und Jugendhilfegesetz). Questions and answers on child and youth welfare in German and English can be found under www.bmfsfj.de (search term "Questions and answers on child and youth welfare").
Who can contact the Youth and Family Office?

Parents
Children and adolescents 
People who notice that a child or a family requires support

For which issues can I turn to the youth welfare office?

Counselling and support, from the very beginning
Adoption and foster care
Paternity, maintenance and parental care
Family education – “being a parent, made easy”
Counselling and support in certain life situations
Questions about parenting
Separation and divorce
Adolescents involved in criminal proceedings
Financial support
Offers for young people
Legal advice for young people
Special topics and tasks
Child and youth protection

You can find more information here.
Social Services in the Youth and Family Office
Social Services support children, adolescents, young adults and adults with advice, information and help.
Social Services (Sozialer Dienst) 0821 3102 2215 jugend.familie@LRA-a.bayern.de

title: Financial benefits of families
excerpt:
Gaining an overview

Families can receive financial support. In addition to direct financial benefits such as parental or child benefit, families also enjoy tax breaks. At www.familienportal.de  you can find out about cash benefits and tax advantages. This info tool also offers help www.infotool-familie.de.
Financial assistance through the Education and Participation Package (Bildungs- und Teilhabepaket)

Your child wants to participate in sports, games or culture? Would your child like to go on a school or daycare trip or have lunch with the other children? Or does your child need help with learning or new items for school? The Education and Participation Package (Bildungs- und Teilhabepaket) helps families on a very limited budget. Your contact person in the district of Augsburg:
Thomas Geldhauser
 0821 3102 2495
 thomas.geldhauser@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can also use the citizens' hotline on the education and participation package:
 030 221 911 009

title: Senior citizens
excerpt: Now that professional life is over, senior citizens can spend their free time differently. To prevent boredom from setting in, the district of Augsburg has many leisure time and educational offers in place for its senior citizens. Getting older often involves making changes, and sometimes means dealing with issues. That is why there are special support options in place for senior citizens.
content: Now that professional life is over, senior citizens can spend their free time differently. To prevent boredom from setting in, the district of Augsburg has many leisure time and educational offers in place for its senior citizens. Getting older often involves making changes, and sometimes means dealing with issues. That is why there are special support options in place for senior citizens.

title: Counselling and contact points for senior citizens
excerpt:
A new phase of life also brings challenges. You may have to change as you get older or reorganise your everyday life. Or you may need support from others.
Changes are often associated with uncertainty. That's why you can find help from several centres in our district.
 
Counselling for senior citizens
Do you have questions about getting older? For example, about care, financing, assistance or applications?
The senior citizens' counselling service at Augsburg District Office helps with questions and concerns from senior citizens and their relatives.
 
Advice for senior citizens - specialist centre for caring relatives Bismarckstraße 62, 86391 Stadtbergen 0821 3102 -2718, -2719, -2707, -2705 seniorenberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
You can find the contact person responsible for you here. 
Counselling is also possible via the Virtual Citizens' Office. 
 
Housing counselling
The housing counselling service advises and supports senior citizens on how to 

make life in their own home easier. 
how life in the home can be organised safely. 

Senior citizens should be able to stay in their own homes for as long as possible.
 
Housing counselling - Accessibility Bismarckstraße 62, 86391 Stadtbergen 0821 3102 2707 wohnberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
In the area of housing and care, the district of Augsburg provides valuable tips and information via the "Guide for family carers and senior citizens".
Further information can be found here.
 
Directly in the municipalities: Representatives for senior citizens
There are senior citizens' representatives directly in the municipalities. The senior citizens' representatives are a point of contact for older people with wishes, suggestions and concerns.
They also organise events and activities. For example, excursions.
 
There are senior citizens' representatives in 34 municipalities. You can find out exactly where at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/seniorenvertretungen.
You can obtain exact contact details from your municipality.
 
Help with old age and care
There are many facilities in the district offering further assistance with old age and care. The district of Swabia has summarised these services for you here.
 
 
Keywords: Help for senior citizens, Help for the elderly, Help with old age, Help with care, Advice for senior citizens, Housing advice, Growing older, Care for relatives

excerpt:
"You never stop learning" - true to this motto, you can look forward to the numerous offers of the Augsburger Land Adult Education Centre (VHS).  You are guaranteed to find something for you, because there are many different courses and events. One major advantage: With a total of 34 institutions in the district, you will be sure to find an offer to suit you right on your doorstep. title: General information
excerpt:
“It is normal to be different. Everyone is welcome." (Aktion Mensch on the inclusive society)
Inclusion means: Every person is naturally considered to be part of the whole, and is allowed to participate in all the activities of life. This applies above all to people with a disability. The concept of inclusion is very important in the district of Augsburg. Therefore, there are numerous offers for people with disabilities.
Even in the foyer to the district administration of Augsburg you can see that the topic is extremely important for the district: The CABito system clearly sets out the services provided by the district administration. Information can be accessed in text, image or audio form. Just try it out!

title: Education and Inclusion
excerpt:
For children from 0 to 6 years of age
There are different measures in the early years of life. Children with (impending) disabilities can receive targeted early intervention. You can find more information at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/fruehfoerderung.
All day care centres in the district are oriented towards the guiding idea of inclusion. However, there are also special facilities for children with disabilities. Parents decide for themselves whether to register their child there or in a regular day care centre.
If you have any questions, please contact:
Child Day Care UnitPetra Hetzner Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg 0821 3102 2644 petra.hetzner@LRA-a.bayern.de
For school-age children
Six general education schools in the district maintain an “inclusion profile”. "Inclusion profile" means: the schools teach children with and without disabilities together in regular classes.There are also three state and two private support centres / special schools specifically for children with disabilities. Parents decide for themselves whether to enrol their child there or in a regular school.
If you have any questions about inclusion in schools, please contact:
State Education Authority (Staatliches Schulamt)Inclusion Advisory Service 0821 3102 2790 beratung-inklusion@LRA-a.bayern.de
Vocational training and studies
In vocational education and training, all paths are open to persons with disabilities. At the same time, there are special offers for people who cannot participate in the regular training.
For those interested in studying, Hochschule Augsburg (Augsburg University of Applied Sciences) and the Studentenwerk (Student Union) are great sources of help and support. The handbook "Study and Disability" helps with many practical tips and information www.studierendenwerke.de/themen/studieren-mit-behinderung/handbuch-studium-und-behinderung.
You can find facilities and services in the virtual guide for people with disabilities of the Augsburg District Office at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/wegweiser-fuer-menschen-mit-behinderung.
Outside the classroom or seminar room
The district of Augsburg is equally committed to education and leisure activities outside the classroom or seminar room. People with disabilities can make social contacts with both people with and without disabilities in this way. For example, through different cultural attractions, sports activities or leisure activities offered by associations and clubs.
The Kreisjugendring offers places in its holiday programme for children and young people with disabilities. Your contact person:
Sophie Kraftsik 0821 450 795 130 s.kraftsik@kjr-al.de

title: Work, employment and inclusion
excerpt:
People with a disability can, of course, find work in the wider job market – unless their disability makes this impossible. That is why the district of Augsburg has created special employment opportunities for people with disabilities. You can find detailed information in the signpost of the district office.
The following sources are available to help you in your search for the right job. You can find an overview of at  www.landkreis-augsburg.de/begleitung-arbeitsplatzsuche.
content:

The following sources are available to help you in your search for the right job. You can find an overview of at  www.landkreis-augsburg.de/begleitung-arbeitsplatzsuche.

title: Living

Housing Advice Centre – Barrier-free access
People with disabilities often have special housing needs. There are volunteer housing advisors in the district for this purpose. Voluntary housing advisors can give you tips and ideas and show you how to adapt your home to your own abilities and needs using certain aids or conversion measures.
Housing advice - accessibility
 Bismarckstraße 62, 86391 Stadtbergen
 0821 31022707
 wohnberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de
Financial support
You can get financial help from the department "Housing, Housing Allowance" for a new building / purchase or for the necessary adaptation of the flat or house.
Living arrangements
In the district of Augsburg there are, in addition to traditional housing offers, special housing options such as shared apartments (WG). More specific information is available via the Guide by the district administration of Augsburg (Wegweiser des Landratsamtes Augsburg). This is how people with disabilities find a home worth living in our district!

title: The German healthcare system
excerpt:
There are many institutions in Germany that are part of the healthcare system. The healthcare system comprises three different areas:

Outpatient medical care by doctors and pharmacies ("outpatient" means: patient goes home after care)
Inpatient medical care through acute care in hospitals ("inpatient" means: patient stays in hospital for treatment)
Health protection of the population through offers of the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive offers ("preventive" means: offers to maintain health and not to get sick)

Outpatient and inpatient care provide medical treatment for sick people. Every person can decide for himself to which doctor or medical institution they would like to go (freedom of choice).
The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfils many different tasks. You can find a list here. The health office also fulfils preventive tasks (for example: information and counselling on health). The aim is to ensure that all citizens in the district enjoy a healthy life. For example, numerous projects are organised in schools. These projects take a playful look at the topic of “health”, thus raising awareness of the importance of healthy living. You can find more information about the health department at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/gesundheitsamt.
You can find health promotion and prevention offers in the district of Augsburg and informative articles here.
 
Good to know:Hospitals treat those individuals who are suffering from acute illness or who have life-threatening injuries. For minor injuries or illnesses that are not emergencies, it is best to go to a doctor's surgery. You will be well helped there!
You need a doctor at night or at the weekend - but it's not an emergency? Then you can call here and find out which doctor's practice is currently open:
Medical on-call serviceonly evenings and weekends 116 117
Emergency Dental Serviceonly evenings and weekends www.notdienst-zahn.de (also in English)
Apothekennotdienst (emergency pharmacy service) 0800 00 22 8 33 (free of charge) from your mobile phone: 22 8 33 (max. 69 cent/min.)
The German healthcare system in 14 languages
In the brochure "Gesundheit für alle - Ein Wegweiser durch das deutsche Gesundheitswesen" you will find all important information in 14 languages.

  3. Health protection of the population through offers of the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive offers ("preventive" means: offers to maintain health and not to get sick)

Outpatient and inpatient care provide medical treatment for sick people. Every person can decide for himself to which doctor or medical institution they would like to go (freedom of choice).

The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfils many different tasks. You can find a list here. The health office also fulfils preventive tasks (for example: information and counselling on health). The aim is to ensure that all citizens in the district enjoy a healthy life. For example, numerous projects are organised in schools. These projects take a playful look at the topic of “health”, thus raising awareness of the importance of healthy living. You can find more information about the health department at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/gesundheitsamt.

You can find health promotion and prevention offers in the district of Augsburg and informative articles here.

title: Health insurance is mandatory
excerpt:
Every person in Germany must have health insurance.
 
Statutory or private health insurance?
You have the option of taking statutory or private health insurance. Most people have statutory health insurance - unless they earn a lot at work and exceed a certain amount. When you work, health insurance is paid by you (the employee) and the employer. In order to qualify for private health insurance, a person must meet certain criteria (e.g. a predefined gross income threshold).
 
Health insurance
You take out health insurance with a health insurance company. There are many different health insurance providers in Germany. Every person has the right to choose their health insurer. Here, you will find an overview of the health insurance providers in Germany.
 
Insurance card
You will receive an insurance card from your health insurance company. With the insurance card of a health insurance company, you can receive medical services throughout Germany. On the rear side of card is also the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC). This means you are also well covered in all EU countries as well as many other European countries and even some non-European territories.
Note:Please always remember to take your insurance card with you when you are treated by doctors, in hospitals or by accredited therapists.
 
Note for asylum applicants
There are different rules for asylum seekers. Read more in the section "Information for asylum seekers".
 
Health promotion and prevention offers
Most health insurance companies cover the costs of health promotion and prevention services that their members take advantage of. Health promotion and prevention services are designed to help maintain and care for health. The idea is to avoid illnesses and health problems, reducing the risk of becoming ill, or delaying the onset of illness. Therefore, most health insurance companies pay at least a part of health promotion and prevention offers or they cover the entire costs. Health promotion and prevention offers can be e.g. yoga courses, back training, nutrition courses and much more.
Take advantage of health promotion and prevention offers and ask your health insurance company! This way you can protect and maintain your health.
You can find health promotion and prevention offers in the district of Augsburg on the health portal.
You can find more informationhere: .
Here you will find information for children and young people.

In order to qualify for private health insurance, a person must meet certain criteria (e.g. a predefined gross income threshold).

You will receive an insurance card from your health insurance company. With the insurance card of a health insurance company, you can receive medical services throughout Germany. On the rear side of card is also the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC). This means you are also well covered in all EU countries as well as many other European countries and even some non-European territories.

Note:
Please always remember to take your insurance card with you when you are treated by doctors, in hospitals or by accredited therapists.

There are different rules for asylum seekers. Read more in the section "Information for asylum seekers".

 

Health promotion and prevention offers

Most health insurance companies cover the costs of health promotion and prevention services that their members take advantage of. Health promotion and prevention services are designed to help maintain and care for health. The idea is to avoid illnesses and health problems, reducing the risk of becoming ill, or delaying the onset of illness. Therefore, most health insurance companies pay at least a part of health promotion and prevention offers or they cover the entire costs. Health promotion and prevention offers can be e.g. yoga courses, back training, nutrition courses and much more.

Take advantage of health promotion and prevention offers and ask your health insurance company! This way you can protect and maintain your health.

title: Visiting a doctor
excerpt:
Free choice of doctor
There are many different medical professions in Germany. Every person is free to choose his or her doctor .
 
General practitioner and paediatrician
If you do not feel mentally or physically well, first go to a general practitioner.  Children should be taken to the children's doctor (paediatrician). This doctor provides basic care and is the first point of contact for all illnesses.
She or he carries out an initial examination and decides on further treatment. If treatment by a specialist is necessary, you will receive a referral. In this context, a “referral” means: The general practitioner or paediatrician will refer you to a specialist.
 
Specialists / Specialists
A specialist doctor has extensive knowledge in a certain medical field. They take over responsibility for any further treatment from the general practitioner after the referral.
 
Doctor’s surgery open hours
Doctors' practices are usually open from Monday to Friday. Each doctor’s surgery has different opening hours. It is best to make an appointment beforehand.
You need a doctor at night or at the weekend - but it's not an emergency? Then you can call here and find out which doctor's practice is currently open:
Medical on-call service
only evenings and weekends
 116 117
Emergency Dental Service
only evenings and weekends
 www.notdienst-zahn.de (also in English)
 
Arranging appointments
You have statutory health insurance and need an appointment with a specialist or psychotherapist? A service point makes sure that you get an appointment with a doctor's office.
Terminservicestelle Bayern
 0921 7877 65 550 20 (Appointments with specialist doctors)
 0921 880 99 404 10 (appointments with psychotherapists)
 Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays: 8 am till 5 pm, Wednesdays and Fridays: 8 am till 1 pm
 
Homeopathy for refugees in Germany

In the case of physical and mental complaints, you will receive free naturopathic treatment. Please make an appointment in advance.
Appointments and Information:

Wertachstraße 29, rear building, 86153 Augsburg
 Fridays, 2 pm to 7 pm

title: Vaccinations
excerpt:
Why are vaccinations important?
Vaccinations are amongst the most effective ways of reducing infectious diseases.
You can find more information about vaccinations here:
www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de/schutzimpfungen
Measles vaccination
In Germany, there is a compulsory vaccination for children attending school and kindergarten. The Masern-Schutz-Gesetz (measles protection law) has been in force since 1 March 2020. School pupils and children attending kindergarten have to be effectively protected against measles.
The law stipulates that, after their first birthday all children need to be able to show that they have received the recommended measles vaccinations. Generally, proof of measles vaccination must also be provided when the child is cared for by a day-care worker.
You can find more information here:
www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de/masern

You can find more information about vaccinations here:

Measles vaccination

In Germany, there is a compulsory vaccination for children attending school and kindergarten. The Masern-Schutz-Gesetz (measles protection law) has been in force since 1 March 2020. School pupils and children attending kindergarten have to be effectively protected against measles.
The law stipulates that, after their first birthday all children need to be able to show that they have received the recommended measles vaccinations. Generally, proof of measles vaccination must also be provided when the child is cared for by a day-care worker.

You can find more information here:
www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de/masern

title: Medication and pharmacies/chemists
excerpt:
If you need medication, you will get a prescription from your doctor. You can get your medication with this prescription at any pharmacy. Even with a prescription, not all medicines are free. Therefore, ask your doctor about it. If you don't have a prescription, you always have to pay for the medication. Some medicines, such as antibiotics, require a prescription. That means you can't buy them without a prescription.
Opening hours
Pharmacies are usually open from Monday to Saturday. The opening hours for pharmacies can vary (in most cases: from 9 am until 6 pm).
On-call service
If you need medication urgently at night or at the weekend, you will find a sign at every pharmacy with the name and address of the pharmacy that is open for emergency service. You can also find this information on the Internet at  www.lak-bayern.notdienst-portal.de/blakportal/.
Apothekennotdienst (emergency pharmacy service) 0800 00 22 8 33 (free of charge) from your mobile phone 22 8 33 (max. 69 cent/min.)
content:
If you need medication, you will get a prescription from your doctor. You can get your medication with this prescription at any pharmacy. Even with a prescription, not all medicines are free. Therefore, ask your doctor about it. If you don't have a prescription, you always have to pay for the medication. Some medicines, such as antibiotics, require a prescription. That means you can't buy them without a prescription.

Opening hours

Pharmacies are usually open from Monday to Saturday. The opening hours for pharmacies can vary (in most cases: from 9 am until 6 pm).

On-call service

If you need medication urgently at night or at the weekend, you will find a sign at every pharmacy with the name and address of the pharmacy that is open for emergency service. You can also find this information on the Internet at  www.lak-bayern.notdienst-portal.de/blakportal/.

Apothekennotdienst (emergency pharmacy service)
 0800 00 22 8 33 (free of charge)

title: Multi-lingual information portals on “health”
excerpt:

On the portal "Zanzu" (www.zanzu.de) you can find information in 13 languages on topics such as family planning, pregnancy and health rights.  There is also a dictionary of medical terms.

title: Contraceptive fund
excerpt:
Every woman and every couple should be able to make their own decision about the timing of a pregnancy and the number of children.
For this reason, the district of Augsburg provides a contraceptive fund. This means that the district covers the costs of contraceptives for certain people. 
 
Please note: The fund is capped. A certain amount is earmarked for the contraceptive fund. If this amount is exhausted, no more costs can be covered.
There is no legal entitlement. It is a voluntary service provided by the district. 
 
For whom are the costs covered? 
These requirements must be met: 

Residence in the district of Augsburg
At least 23 years old (under 23 years the statutory health insurance covers the costs)
Receipt of social benefits:
Citizen's allowance (SGB II),
Social assistance (SGB XII),
Housing benefit,
child supplement or
Benefits according to the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act (AsylbLG).



 
What costs are covered? 
The costs for: 

The pill
Copper IUD
Hormone coil
Hormone implant
Three-monthly injection
Vaginal ring
Contraceptive patch
Sterilisation for women and men

The contraceptive method must be prescribed by a doctor. 
 
How do you apply for the costs to be covered? 
You submit your application to the pregnancy counselling service at the Augsburg District Office. You must seek advice from the centre beforehand. 
Augsburg District Office Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg  s chwange renberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de 
You can also use the virtual citizens' office. 
 
What do you need for the application?

Notification of your social benefit
ID and confirmation of registration
for the pill, vaginal ring or contraceptive patch: prescription from a doctor
for IUDs, three-monthly injections, hormone implants or sterilisation: cost proposal from a doctor
Consultation with the pregnancy counselling service
Invoice from the pharmacy or doctor (dated after the pregnancy counselling session) 

 
 
Keywords: contraception, conception, contraception protection, no baby, don't want to get pregnant, pregnancy,
content:
Every woman and every couple should be able to make their own decision about the timing of a pregnancy and the number of children.

For this reason, the district of Augsburg provides a contraceptive fund. This means that the district covers the costs of contraceptives for certain people.

Please note: The fund is capped. A certain amount is earmarked for the contraceptive fund. If this amount is exhausted, no more costs can be covered.

There is no legal entitlement. It is a voluntary service provided by the district.

For whom are the costs covered?

These requirements must be met:

  • Residence in the district of Augsburg
  • At least 23 years old (under 23 years the statutory health insurance covers the costs)
  • Receipt of social benefits:
    • Citizen's allowance (SGB II),
    • Social assistance (SGB XII),
    • Housing benefit,
    • child supplement or
    • Benefits according to the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act (AsylbLG).

What costs are covered?

The costs for:

  • The pill
  • Copper IUD
  • Hormone coil
  • Hormone implant
  • Three-monthly injection
  • Vaginal ring
  • Contraceptive patch
  • Sterilisation for women and men

The contraceptive method must be prescribed by a doctor.

How do you apply for the costs to be covered?

You submit your application to the pregnancy counselling service at the Augsburg District Office. You must seek advice from the centre beforehand.

Augsburg District Office
Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
s chwange renberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de

You can also use the virtual citizens' office.

What do you need for the application?

  • Notification of your social benefit
  • ID and confirmation of registration
  • for the pill, vaginal ring or contraceptive patch: prescription from a doctor
  • for IUDs, three-monthly injections, hormone implants or sterilisation: cost proposal from a doctor
  • Consultation with the pregnancy counselling service
  • Invoice from the pharmacy or doctor (dated after the pregnancy counselling session)

Keywords: contraception, conception, contraception protection, no baby, don't want to get pregnant, pregnancy,

title: Medical care in the district of Augsburg
Medical treatment and advice
excerpt:
In the district of Augsburg there are excellent medical treatment facilities available. Are you looking for an institution, a doctor's practice or a hospital? Then the following pages will help you:

Find a doctor:

www.aerzte-im-netz.de,
www.kinderaerzte-im-netz.de,
https://www.weisse-liste.de/de/arzt/arztsuche/,
https://dienste.kvb.de/arztsuche/app/einfacheSuche.htm

Psychiatric care in Swabia:

www.bezirk-schwaben.de/gesundheit

Assistance in old age and care, disability or mental illness:

www.bezirk-schwaben.de/soziale-hilfen

Hospitals:

www.augsburg.de (Search word "hospitals")
 
Do you need advice on the topic of "health" or "the health system in Germany"? The Department of Health (Staatliches Gesundheitsamt) will be happy to help:
Department of Health (Staatliches Gesundheitsamt)
 Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
 0821 3102 2101 or 0821 3102 2108
 gesundheitsamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
Special Social Services (BSD) are on hand to help adults and their relatives in difficult situations. The specialists are on hand to provide support in contact with the authorities and to advise on offers of assistance.
Special Social Services (BSD) for adults
 Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
 0821 3102 2780
 bsd@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
The HiFF project supports adult refugees with traumatic experiences and / or mental illnesses in coping with their life situation. For this purpose, individual psychotherapy sessions, stabilisation groups and social and asylum procedure counselling are offered. Referral to other support services is also possible.
HiFF - Aid organisation for particularly vulnerable refugees
 Auf dem Kreuz 41, 86152 Augsburg
 0821 3156241
 
You are currently pregnant or have a newborn child?
You can find counselling services on these topics in the section"Family, Children, Young People and Senior Citizens" under"Counselling for pregnant women and new parents" .

title: In cases of severe illness, addiction, trauma, and violent experiences
excerpt:
Severe illnesses, addiction, and violent experiences have a particularly burdensome effect on individuals and their families. Receiving professional support in such a situation is very important. You can take advantage of the following offers:
In cases of severe illness and addiction

The Social Psychiatric Service helps people with mental problems/illnesses (e.g. family problems, anxiety, depression or suicidal thoughts):

www.landkreis-augsburg.de/sozialpsychiatrische-dienste

The Bunte Kreis e.V. provides care for families with chronically, cancer- and seriously ill children:

www.bunter-kreis.de

OSKAR, telephone-based counselling and information service for families with terminally ill children:

 0800 8888 4711

KiYo, counselling centre for parents with cancer:

www.awo-augsburg.de (Search word "cancerous")

Self-help groups (groups of people who meet voluntarily and usually on a regular basis to talk about problems and get help):

www.augsburg.de/umwelt-soziales/gesundheit/selbsthilfegruppen/ 

Anonymous HIV test at the health office:

www.landkreis-augsburg.de/anonymer-hiv-test

Drug help Swabia:

www.drogenhilfeschwaben.de

Caritasaddiction counselling (also online counselling):

www.caritas-augsburg.de (Search word "addiction counselling")

The “Schneewittchen” advice centre for eating disorders:

 Leonhardsberg 16, 86150 Augsburg,   0821 3449 9013,  Schneewittchen-Augsburg@sos-kinderdorf.de

 
In cases of violence

via - Ways out of violence (for all those affected):

 Karlstraße 5, 86150 Augsburg,  0821 650 2670,  awo.via@awo-augsburg.de

Wildwasser Augsburg e.V., for sexualised violence against girls and women:

 Schießgrabenstraße 2, 86150 Augsburg,  0821 15 44 44,  Beratung@wildwasser-augsburg.de

 
In cases of trauma
Many people have experienced terrible things on their way to Germany or in their home countries. This can cause trauma. Psychological trauma means serious mental harm. It can result from an exceptionally stressful personal experience . If one’s own coping mechanisms are overwhelmed, trauma can result. This causes extremely high levels of stress. In such situations, people often feel completely helpless, experience severe anxiety , or are overcome by feelings of horror.
There are several places where you can get help:

Trauma support network Augsburg and Swabia - the contact point for those affected and their relatives:

https://www.traumahilfe-augsburg.de/traumahilfe-wegweiser

Nationwide working group of psychosocial centres for refugees and victims of torture:

http://www.baff-zentren.org/

title: Measles Protection Act
excerpt:
Since 1 March 2020, according to the Measles Protection Act, vaccination has been compulsory for all children before entering a community facility (e.g. kindergarten, school). This obligation also applies to children who are looked after in a children's home for at least four weeks or who are accommodated in accommodation for refugees.
Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases, which is why almost everyone who has not been vaccinated becomes infected with the virus after just one contact with a sick person.
Measles can lead to severe complications, especially in children under 5 (and adults over 20). The most common symptoms include middle ear or lung infections, as well as diarrhoea.
The 1. Vaccination should be given between the age of 11 and 14. The earliest they can be given is after 9 months of age. Month of life). The 2. Children should have a newborn child at the latest before their 2nd birthday. The child must be vaccinated against measles by the age of 18. The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.
The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and, if necessary, chickenpox.
For more information on measles vaccination, see https://www.masernschutz.de/

Measles can lead to severe complications, especially in children under 5 (and adults over 20). The most common symptoms include middle ear or lung infections, as well as diarrhoea.

The 1. Vaccination should be given between the age of 11 and 14. The earliest they can be given is after 9 months of age. Month of life). The 2. Children should have a newborn child at the latest before their 2nd birthday. The child must be vaccinated against measles by the age of 18. The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.

The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and, if necessary, chickenpox.

For more information on measles vaccination, see https://www.masernschutz.de/

title: Vaccination recommendations for children from 0 to 12 years of age
Recommendation of combination vaccinations by the STIKO
excerpt:
Currently, the Standing Commission on Vaccination (STIKO) recommends the following combination vaccinations for children up to the age of 12:
 
1. 6-way combination vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus (lockjaw), polio, pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), hepatitis B:
Other vaccine combinations are also possible, for example without Hib and/or hepatitis B.
The 2+1 vaccination schedule is intended for this combination vaccination. The 1. Vaccination should be given at the age of 2 months (from the 8th week of pregnancy). Week of life). The 2. The first vaccination should be scheduled eight weeks later (at the age of 4 months). Dose another six months later, at the age of 11 months.
At the age of five to six years, the vaccination protection should be refreshed by a new vaccination. A second course should be taken against diphtheria, polio and whooping cough. Refresher training should take place between the ages of 9 and 17. Afterwards, the vaccination protection can be renewed every ten years.
Information on the individual diseases
Diphtheria
Diphtheria is a bacterial infectious disease that can affect the mucous membranes of the throat and the skin.
Tetanus (lockjaw)
The tetanus bacterium often hides in the soil. Even small wounds or bites from splinters and thorns are enough for the bacterium to enter the body.
Poliomyelitis (Polio)
Ca. 95% of those infected do not notice their infection. About 5% have fever, sore throat and headache. With every 100 to 1000. Infected persons suffer permanent, flaccid paralysis of the arm or leg muscles, in the worst case paralysis of the speech, swallowing or breathing muscles.
Whooping cough (pertussis)
The disease is characterised by flu-like symptoms. These last for about two weeks. In the following four to six weeks, the main symptoms are agonising coughing fits that can lead to vomiting.
Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
The rather unknown disease "Hib" can be severe, especially for infants and young children. Possible consequences are meningitis and epiglottitis.
Hepatitis B
In the case of hepatitis B, a risk of contracting the disease is relatively low for infants without a family history of risk (i.e.: already known previous illnesses of other family members). Nevertheless, the STIKO recommends vaccination, especially since there is a high risk of chronic forms of progression after an illness. Chronic means that the disease develops slowly and lasts for a long time.
 
 
2. Combination vaccine against mumps, measles rubella (MMR) and, if applicable, chickenpox (MMRV):
With this vaccine combination, the 1. Vaccination recommended for children from the age of 11 to 14 months. The 2. Vaccination can be given after a minimum interval of four weeks, but at the latest at an age of 15 to 23 months.
Information on the individual diseases
Mumps
Mumps is characterised by inflammation and consequently swelling of the parotid glands. Ca. 1/3 of sick infants do not develop any signs of the disease themselves, but are contagious to other people.
Rubella
Rubella has particularly serious consequences for pregnant women. Infection can harm the woman's unborn child during the first four months of pregnancy. A high number of vaccinated persons can prevent a widespread spread. That is why the vaccination recommendation is not only aimed at girls and women who want to have children.
Chickenpox (varicella)
Chickenpox is extremely easy to transmit, as almost every contact with an infected person leads to infection. The consequences of chickenpox are fever and exhaustion in the first few days. Later, there is a skin rash with blisters on the face, body and arms and legs. Mucous membranes and the hairy scalp can also be affected by the rash.
