Currently, the Standing Commission on Vaccination (STIKO) recommends the following combination vaccinations for children up to the age of 12:

 

1. 6-way combination vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus (lockjaw), polio, pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), hepatitis B:

Other vaccine combinations are also possible, for example without Hib and/or hepatitis B.

The 2+1 vaccination schedule is intended for this combination vaccination. The 1. Vaccination should be given at the age of 2 months (from the 8th week of pregnancy). Week of life). The 2. The first vaccination should be scheduled eight weeks later (at the age of 4 months). Dose another six months later, at the age of 11 months.

At the age of five to six years, the vaccination protection should be refreshed by a new vaccination. A second course should be taken against diphtheria, polio and whooping cough. Refresher training should take place between the ages of 9 and 17. Afterwards, the vaccination protection can be renewed every ten years.

Information on the individual diseases

Diphtheria

Diphtheria is a bacterial infectious disease that can affect the mucous membranes of the throat and the skin.

Tetanus (lockjaw)

The tetanus bacterium often hides in the soil. Even small wounds or bites from splinters and thorns are enough for the bacterium to enter the body.

Poliomyelitis (Polio)

Ca. 95% of those infected do not notice their infection. About 5% have fever, sore throat and headache. With every 100 to 1000. Infected persons suffer permanent, flaccid paralysis of the arm or leg muscles, in the worst case paralysis of the speech, swallowing or breathing muscles.

Whooping cough (pertussis)

The disease is characterised by flu-like symptoms. These last for about two weeks. In the following four to six weeks, the main symptoms are agonising coughing fits that can lead to vomiting.

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)

The rather unknown disease "Hib" can be severe, especially for infants and young children. Possible consequences are meningitis and epiglottitis.

Hepatitis B

In the case of hepatitis B, a risk of contracting the disease is relatively low for infants without a family history of risk (i.e.: already known previous illnesses of other family members). Nevertheless, the STIKO recommends vaccination, especially since there is a high risk of chronic forms of progression after an illness. Chronic means that the disease develops slowly and lasts for a long time.

 

 

2. Combination vaccine against mumps, measles rubella (MMR) and, if applicable, chickenpox (MMRV):

With this vaccine combination, the 1. Vaccination recommended for children from the age of 11 to 14 months. The 2. Vaccination can be given after a minimum interval of four weeks, but at the latest at an age of 15 to 23 months.

Information on the individual diseases

Mumps

Mumps is characterised by inflammation and consequently swelling of the parotid glands. Ca. 1/3 of sick infants do not develop any signs of the disease themselves, but are contagious to other people.

Rubella

Rubella has particularly serious consequences for pregnant women. Infection can harm the woman's unborn child during the first four months of pregnancy. A high number of vaccinated persons can prevent a widespread spread. That is why the vaccination recommendation is not only aimed at girls and women who want to have children.

Chickenpox (varicella)

Chickenpox is extremely easy to transmit, as almost every contact with an infected person leads to infection. The consequences of chickenpox are fever and exhaustion in the first few days. Later, there is a skin rash with blisters on the face, body and arms and legs. Mucous membranes and the hairy scalp can also be affected by the rash.

title: Further vaccination recommendations of the STIKO
excerpt:
1.      TBE (early summer meningoencephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites. Possible consequences of a disease are inflammations of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord. Especially Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony are considered risk areas in Germany. Especially in these areas, vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO.
All children can attend from the age of 1. The vaccination against TBE must be carried out before the child's 60th birthday.
2.      Influenza (flu)
Influenza is contagious in a similar way to a normal cold (flu). Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child or via objects. Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected. Complications such as pneumonia can occur in them.
The recommendation for annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find more information about the affected pre-existing conditionshere  .
3.      HPV (human papilloma viruses)
Papilloma viruses can cause cancer in the long term. Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancers of the cervix, anus, penis and throat. Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection. Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4.      Meningococcus
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis). Children under the age of 5 and adolescents are particularly at risk. Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months. There is currently no general recommendation for vaccination against other types (B and ACWY). The bacteria are transmitted via so-called droplet infection, i.e. for example via coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5.      Pneumococcus
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen of severe bacterial infections. They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections and are especially dangerous for babies and small children. Three vaccinations are recommended against pneumococci, which should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria, whooping cough.
6.      Rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhoea and vomiting in children. The pathogen is very contagious, which is why almost all children contract it in the first five years - usually at the age of 2. Especially in infants, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration, which may have to be treated in hospital. Rotaviruses are vaccinated two or three times, depending on the vaccine. The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age, the second at 3 months and the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
7.      Corona (as of February 2022)
Vaccination against the Corona virus is currently recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years only with the vaccine "Comirnaty" from BioNTech/Pfizer. Vaccinations can be given at intervals of three to six weeks between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness. In addition, the recommendation also applies to children in whose environment there are persons with a high risk of a severe COVID-19 course, if they themselves cannot be vaccinated or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without their own pre-existing conditions or pre-existing conditions of close contacts. Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
For more information on the affected pre-existing conditions, see:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
https://www.rki.de/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2022/Ausgaben/01_22.pdf?__blob=publicationFile
Further information on the above vaccination recommendations here.

title: Information for asylum seekers
excerpt:
As an asylum seeker in Germany you are entitled to:

basic medical care (i.e. you can go to a doctor's office for acute illnesses and pain).
medical care if you are chronically ill (if you have, for example, diabetes, epilepsy or a psychiatric illness),
vaccinations recommended by the office (detailed information in 16 languages can be found at www.mimi-bestellportal.de search term "vaccinations"),
preventative check-ups,
medical care during pregnancy and birth,
medical care following a traumatic event (rape, torture, violence).

Health treatment for asylum seekers
If you do not yet have health insurance, you will receive a health treatment voucher (Krankenbehandlungsschein) from the responsible office (Ausländeramt in Schwabmünchen). . As a rule, your doctor will ask you for this medical treatment certificate. Please always take an official photo document (residents permit = Aufenthaltsgestattung, stopf of deportation= Duldung or proof of arrival) with you to the doctor.
A health treatment voucher is always valid for one quarter (3 months). For each quarter, a new treatment certificate must be requested from the doctor.
1. quarter: January, February, March2. quarter: April, May, June3. quarter: July, August, September4. quarter: October, November, December
For specialist treatment, you need a referral slip from your family doctor (for children: paediatrician). A new health insurance voucher does not have to be requested specifically for specialist treatment. Your doctor will give you a copy of the medical treatment certificate to present to the specialist together with the referral.
You can find more information here.
More information
Especially for asylum seekers, the health project MiMi (From Migrants for Migrants - Intercultural Health in Bavaria) has created a health care guide in seven languages(Arabic, Dari, German, English, Kurdish, Pashto, Russian) : www.mimi-bestellportal.de (Search term "Wegweiser Vorsorge").
If you have any questions
If you have any questions, you can contact the Office for Foreigners and Integration:
Office for Immigration and IntegrationSchwabmünchen location, Fuggerstraße 10, 86830 Schwabmünchen 0821 3102 0 auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
content:
As an asylum seeker in Germany you are entitled to:

  • basic medical care (i.e. you can go to a doctor's office for acute illnesses and pain).
  • medical care if you are chronically ill (if you have, for example, diabetes, epilepsy or a psychiatric illness),
  • vaccinations recommended by the office (detailed information in 16 languages can be found at www.mimi-bestellportal.de search term "vaccinations"),
  • preventative check-ups,
  • medical care during pregnancy and birth,
  • medical care following a traumatic event (rape, torture, violence).

Health treatment for asylum seekers

If you do not yet have health insurance, you will receive a health treatment voucher (Krankenbehandlungsschein) from the responsible office (Ausländeramt in Schwabmünchen). . As a rule, your doctor will ask you for this medical treatment certificate. Please always take an official photo document (residents permit = Aufenthaltsgestattung, stopf of deportation= Duldung or proof of arrival) with you to the doctor.

A health treatment voucher is always valid for one quarter (3 months). For each quarter, a new treatment certificate must be requested from the doctor.

1. quarter: January, February, March
2. quarter: April, May, June
3. quarter: July, August, September
4. quarter: October, November, December

For specialist treatment, you need a referral slip from your family doctor (for children: paediatrician). A new health insurance voucher does not have to be requested specifically for specialist treatment. Your doctor will give you a copy of the medical treatment certificate to present to the specialist together with the referral.

You can find more information here.

More information

Especially for asylum seekers, the health project MiMi (From Migrants for Migrants - Intercultural Health in Bavaria) has created a health care guide in seven languages(Arabic, Dari, German, English, Kurdish, Pashto, Russian) : www.mimi-bestellportal.de (Search term "Wegweiser Vorsorge").

If you have any questions

title: Current account
excerpt:
The current account
With a current account, you can make payments and receive money. Your money is always available in your current account.
With a current account you can:

Make bank transfers,
receive cashless payments (payments from public authorities (social benefits) are often made cashless, i.e. transferred to a personal current account),
set up standing orders,
participate in direct debits,
cashing cheques,
make cashless payments with the EC/Maestro card,
withdraw cash at bank counters or ATMs and
print out your account statements.

Important: You need enough money in your account for all withdrawals and payments. 
Tip: A current account usually costs money. The costs vary from bank to bank. You also get different services depending on the bank. Therefore, find out about the different conditions at the banks. 
 
Opening an account and using the account
What do you need to look out for in a bank account? And what do you need to open a bank account? You can read about this at the consumer advice centre in two languages(German, Russian): www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information"). There you will also find explanatory videos on the topic in German, English, Arabic and Dari.
 
Important information

After opening the account, you will receive an EC card with a four-digit PIN code. Sign the back of the EC card. Memorise the PIN code. You will need the PIN code for cashless payments and for withdrawing money from ATMs. Make sure you keep your card and PIN code separate!
For cash withdrawals, it is best to use an ATM from your bank. Then the withdrawal costs nothing. 
You must enter the PIN code carefully at the ATM. You only have three attempts. After that, the debit card will be cancelled and blocked. In this case, you must ask your bank about further steps.
In many supermarkets you can withdraw money from a certain purchase value.
Sometimes an EC card is lost or stolen. If this happens, you should block your debit card immediately. Use this telephone number: 116 116 (for all debit cards, 24 hours a day). Say your sort code and account number. You can then ask your bank for a new debit card.

 
 
Keywords: current account, account, open an account, cashless payments, withdraw money, ATM, bank account, EC card

title: Insurances
excerpt:
Compulsory insurances
You must have these insurances in Germany:

"Health insurance
For drivers: Motor vehicle liability insurance
For employees: Statutory pension insurance

 
You can find important information at the consumer advice centre: www.verbraucherzentrale.de. 
The information is available in these languages: 

German
English, German 
Arabic
Farsi 
Ukrainian
Romanian
Romanian French
Turkish
Bulgarian

 
Highly recommended: Liability insurance
Have you caused damage to a person in Germany? Then you have to pay compensation according to the law. Even if it was not your intention. 
 
This applies to personal injury, property damage and financial losses in the private sector.
For example, if you cause a road accident. Or if your child breaks a window pane with a ball.
 
Many landlords and landladies require their tenants to have liability insurance. 
 
Private liability insurance pays for this damage for you and your children. 
 
Liability insurance is not compulsory. You do not have to take it out. But we strongly recommend it. 
 
You can find explanatory videos with important information on liability insurance in German, English, Arabic and Dari at the consumer advice centre; search term: "Mehrsprachige Verbrauchervideos".
 
 
Keywords: insurance, compulsory insurance, pension insurance, liability insurance, car insurance

title: Contracts
excerpt:
Especially important: Never sign anything you don't understand or can't read. Otherwise, you may sign a contract or agreement under which you have to pay something. It is sometimes very difficult to undo this. Always check and compare several offers and take your time to decide. Don't let anyone pressure you into signing.
Here, you can find more information and help on contracts.

title: Employment support and securing a livelihood
excerpt:
Securing a livelihood
 People who are not in work can receive benefits from the Federal Employment Agency (BfA). In order to qualify for this, a person must meet certain criteria. The Job Centre can help individuals who are unable to finance their livelihood themselves, either not entirely or not at all.
 
Employment support
There are also various measures in place that are aimed at employment support. These measures are in place to ensure that people either do not become unemployed or are able to find work again more quickly. You can find many helpful materials on this in several languages under www.arbeitsagentur.de/fuer-menschen-aus-dem-ausland (also in English and Arabic)
 
Social welfare
Some individuals can qualify for social welfare. You can find more about this under www.landkreis-augsburg.de/sozialhilfe.
 
Federal Employment Agency (BfA) and the Job Centre
The topics of “unemployment benefit” and “employment support” as well as certain benefits relating to education are processed by the Federal Employment Agency (BfA) and the Job Centre:
Employment agency
Responsible for: Unemployment benefit I, employment support, vocational training grants (Berufsausbildungsbeihilfe [BAB])
 Wertachstraße 28, 86153 Augsburg
 0800 4 5555 00
 
Job Centre Augsburg Land
Responsible for: Unemployment benefit I, employment support, education and participation for benefit recipients as per SGB II
 Hermanstraße 11, 86150 Augsburg / Fuggerstraße 10, 86830 Schwabmünchen
 0821 99 888 0

title: Legal questions in difficult life situations
excerpt:
The district administration of Augsburg offers intensive support to people who find themselves in difficult life situations. There are the following free offers:

Specialist centre for separation & Divorce:  Counselling on separation, divorce, contact with child (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/trennung-scheidung)
Adolescents involved in criminal proceedings: Counselling for young people (in cases of suspected criminal offences), their parents or guardians (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/jugendhilfe-im-strafverfahren)
Legal advice from lawyers for young people, their parents or guardians on all areas of law (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/rechtsberatung)
Appointment of a guardian, legal guardianship and trusteeship: Counselling, support and representation in questions of paternity and maintenance as well as in cases where the best interests of the child are at risk (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/vormund-pfleg-und-beistandschaft)
content:
The district administration of Augsburg offers intensive support to people who find themselves in difficult life situations. There are the following free offers:

  • Specialist centre for separation & Divorce:  Counselling on separation, divorce, contact with child (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/trennung-scheidung)
  • Adolescents involved in criminal proceedings: Counselling for young people (in cases of suspected criminal offences), their parents or guardians (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/jugendhilfe-im-strafverfahren)
  • Legal advice from lawyers for young people, their parents or guardians on all areas of law (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/rechtsberatung)
  • Appointment of a guardian, legal guardianship and trusteeship: Counselling, support and representation in questions of paternity and maintenance as well as in cases where the best interests of the child are at risk (www.landkreis-augsburg.de/vormund-pfleg-und-beistandschaft)

title: Naturalisation
excerpt:
Many people have lived in Germany for a long time. They feel a strong connection to Germany. That is why they want German citizenship. You can obtain German citizenship through naturalisation. 
 
Why is naturalisation advantageous? 
Naturalisation has many advantages: 

You can take part in elections without restriction and thus play an active role in shaping politics. 
You have access to all professions without restrictions under immigration law. You can also become a civil servant. For example, in the police, as a teacher or as a judge. 
You have secure residence for the rest of your life. You no longer have to obtain permits from the immigration authorities or go to consulates or embassies. You can work, live or travel anywhere in Germany. 
As a German citizen, you also have EU citizenship if you were not a German citizen before. This means that you are also allowed to stay in all other EU countries without restriction and work, study or live there without authorisation. 
You enjoy state protection. This means that you cannot be deported or extradited to another country. You also have protection in German embassies abroad if you do not also have citizenship of that country. 

 
What requirements do you have to fulfil? 
Naturalisation is subject to a number of conditions: 

lawful, habitual residence in Germany for 8 years (note: there are exceptions, e.g. passed integration course, married to a person with German citizenship)
Permanent right of residence
Proficiency in the German language (German B1) 
Commitment to the basic democratic order 
Livelihood is secured through own gainful employment
No criminal offences committed (petty offences are not an obstacle)
renounce previous citizenship (except for persons with citizenship from the EU or Switzerland)
Knowledge of living conditions in Germany 
Knowledge of the legal system and the social order (test "Living in Germany")

You must also submit a declaration. With this you confirm that you are not pursuing or will not pursue any anti-constitutional endeavours. This means that you may not pursue any activities that are contrary to the fundamental values of democracy. This will be checked by the security authorities. 
 
What documents do you need?

Application for naturalisation
Current photograph
Certificate of birth, marriage if applicable, divorce if applicable (for documents in a non-German language: translation by an officially sworn interpreter)
Valid national passport with residence permit
Proof of German language skills (e.g. school report, certificates, completed vocational training)
Proof of "Living in Germany" test
Proof of family income for the last three months

 
 Sometimes the authorities need further documents. It is therefore best to ask in advance. 
Augsburg District Office
Office for Immigration and Integration Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg h ttps:// www.landkreis-augsburg.de/asyl-auslaenderwesen-integration/staatsangehoerigkeits-und-personenstandsrecht/staatsangehoerigkeit/einbuergerung/ 
Who your contact person is depends on the first letter of your surname: 
Letters A - C: Anne Graf,  082131022238 Letters D - J: Maximilian Schindler, 082131022332 Letters K - N: Leonie Schneider, 082131023067 Letters O - S: Ulrike Geißelmaier-Miesl, 082131022302 Letters Sch, St, T - Z: Ingeborg Bauer, 082131022246 
 
How much does naturalisation cost? 
255 euros per person
You can have your underage child or children naturalised with you. This costs 51 euros per child. 
You withdraw your application? Or the application is rejected? Then you still have to pay the costs. 
 
 
 
Keywords: German citizenship, becoming a citizen, becoming German, integration
content:
Many people have lived in Germany for a long time. They feel a strong connection to Germany. That is why they want German citizenship. You can obtain German citizenship through naturalisation.

Why is naturalisation advantageous?

Naturalisation has many advantages:

  • You can take part in elections without restriction and thus play an active role in shaping politics.
  • You have access to all professions without restrictions under immigration law. You can also become a civil servant. For example, in the police, as a teacher or as a judge.
  • You have secure residence for the rest of your life. You no longer have to obtain permits from the immigration authorities or go to consulates or embassies. You can work, live or travel anywhere in Germany.
  • As a German citizen, you also have EU citizenship if you were not a German citizen before. This means that you are also allowed to stay in all other EU countries without restriction and work, study or live there without authorisation.
  • You enjoy state protection. This means that you cannot be deported or extradited to another country. You also have protection in German embassies abroad if you do not also have citizenship of that country.

What requirements do you have to fulfil?

Naturalisation is subject to a number of conditions:

  • lawful, habitual residence in Germany for 8 years (note: there are exceptions, e.g. passed integration course, married to a person with German citizenship)
  • Permanent right of residence
  • Proficiency in the German language (German B1)
  • Commitment to the basic democratic order
  • Livelihood is secured through own gainful employment
  • No criminal offences committed (petty offences are not an obstacle)
  • renounce previous citizenship (except for persons with citizenship from the EU or Switzerland)
  • Knowledge of living conditions in Germany
  • Knowledge of the legal system and the social order (test "Living in Germany")

You must also submit a declaration. With this you confirm that you are not pursuing or will not pursue any anti-constitutional endeavours. This means that you may not pursue any activities that are contrary to the fundamental values of democracy. This will be checked by the security authorities.

What documents do you need?

  • Application for naturalisation
  • Current photograph
  • Certificate of birth, marriage if applicable, divorce if applicable (for documents in a non-German language: translation by an officially sworn interpreter)
  • Valid national passport with residence permit
  • Proof of German language skills (e.g. school report, certificates, completed vocational training)
  • Proof of "Living in Germany" test
  • Proof of family income for the last three months

Sometimes the authorities need further documents. It is therefore best to ask in advance.

Augsburg District Office

Office for Immigration and Integration
Prinzregentenplatz 4, 86150 Augsburg
h ttps:// www.landkreis-augsburg.de/asyl-auslaenderwesen-integration/staatsangehoerigkeits-und-personenstandsrecht/staatsangehoerigkeit/einbuergerung/

Who your contact person is depends on the first letter of your surname:

Letters A - C: Anne Graf, 082131022238
Letters D - J: Maximilian Schindler, 082131022332
Letters K - N: Leonie Schneider, 082131023067
Letters O - S: Ulrike Geißelmaier-Miesl, 082131022302
Letters Sch, St, T - Z: Ingeborg Bauer, 082131022246

How much does naturalisation cost?

255 euros per person

You can have your underage child or children naturalised with you. This costs 51 euros per child.

You withdraw your application? Or the application is rejected? Then you still have to pay the costs.

Keywords: German citizenship, becoming a citizen, becoming German, integration

title: Smartphone
excerpt:
There are two different mobile phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term. This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks). You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
With a fixed-term contract, there is a minimum contract term. This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time. The contract is automatically renewed if you do not cancel. If you do not want the contract to be renewed automatically, you must cancel in writing. Pay attention to the cancellation period.
 
Ten important questions when concluding a contract:

How high is the basic fee? Does the fee increase after a certain period of time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long is the contract for (e.g. twelve or 24 months)?
If I do not cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed. When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
What is the billing cycle (60/1, 10/10)?
How much does a minute cost (external/own network)?
How much does a mobile phone with a contract cost and how much does a mobile phone without a contract cost?
How much does Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?

 
You can find important information in five different languages(German, English, Arabic, Russian, Farsi) at the consumer advice centre: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information"). There you will also find explanatory videos  on the topic in German, English, Arabic and Dari.
 
 
Keywords: smartphone, mobile phone, mobile phone contract, prepaid contract, fixed-term contract, telephone

With a fixed-term contract, there is a minimum contract term. This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time. title: Public transport
excerpt:
There is a good network of public transport in Augsburg and the surrounding area, such as buses and trams. The Augsburger Verkehrs- und Tarifverbund (AVV) is responsible for this network.
You can find all the important information on the AVV website at www.avv-augsburg.de. For app users, both the AVV (app: AVV.mobil) and Stadtwerke Augsburg (app: swa FahrInfo) offer free apps for download.
You need a ticket to travel by bus or tram. There are often checks on buses and trams. If you don't have a ticket, you will have to pay a fine. The second time, you will be reported to the police and fined a much higher amount. So make sure you always have a valid ticket with you!
 
Fare zones and price levels
The area covered by the AVV is divided into zones. The price of the ticket depends on the number of zones travelled through. The more zones you pass through, the more expensive your ticket is. Each zone corresponds to a price level. 
Each zone is only counted once. For example, if you travel through zones 20, 10 and 20 again, you need a ticket of price level 2 or 2 stripes on the stripe card.
However, the outward and return journeys count as two different journeys. 

The city area of Augsburg comprises fare zones 10 and 20.
The district of Augsburg comprises zones 30 - 70.

You can find the fare zone maphere. The timetables with the fare zones are also displayed at the stops.
 Note: Your ticket is also valid if you change trains.
 
The most important tickets 
You can find detailed information on all tickets and current prices here.
 
Germany ticket

For 49 euros a month, you can use all local public transport and travel throughout Germany. 
The Deutschlandticket is a subscription. This means that it is automatically renewed every month. But you can cancel it every month. Always by the 10th of each month at the latest (for example: 10th March) for the following month. 
You can order the Deutschlandticket here. It will then be played on your smartphone. You will need the "meinAVV" app for this. You can find the app in your smartphone's Apple or Google store. 

 
Discount ticket for students, trainees, civil servants or volunteers

In Bavaria, these groups of people can get a discounted Deutschlandticket. 
The discount ticket costs 29 euros. It is also valid nationwide. 
This ticket will be available for trainees from 1 September 2023. Students can obtain it as a top-up ticket in time for the start of the 2023/2024 winter semester. 
The person's place of education or residence must be in Bavaria. 
To apply, you need proof of eligibility from your educational institution. 
You can apply for the discount tickethere.

 
Stripe card

9 strips for flexible use (one strip per zone)
Valid for 3 hours (no return and round trips)
No take-away options (one strip per person and zone)
You can find more information about the Streifenkarte here

 
Single tickets

Single journey from A to B
Valid for 1 hour (no return and round trips)
No take-along options
4 stops after boarding buses or trams, even across zone boundaries
Transfer possible
You can find more information about single tickets here.

 
Day ticket

Any number of journeys on the selected day
For adults aged 15 and over
For one person or groups (each additional person costs a surcharge)
Up to 4 children under the age of 14 can travel free of charge.
Valid Monday to Friday from 9:00 a.m., Saturday, Sunday and public holidays all day; valid until closing time (i.e. until the last bus or tram leaves). 
Please note: The names of the travellers must be handwritten on the day ticket!
You can find more information about the day ticket here.

 
365-euro AVV ticket for school pupils, trainees, interns and FSJ volunteers
The 365-euro AVV ticket is available for school pupils, trainees, interns and young people doing a voluntary social year. For €1 a day, you can travel as often as you like on trams, buses and trains throughout the AVV network area - around the clock! You can pay for the ticket in instalments or all at once. You can find all the information here.
 
Monthly travelcard for school pupils
Pupils do not have to pay for bus and tram travel themselves. They can submit an application. The costs for the monthly travelcard will then be covered.
For this, the journey to school must be more than 2 kilometres for pupils in grades 1 to 4. For children and young people from year 5 onwards, the journey to school must be longer than 3 kilometres. 
Further information and download of applications: www.landkreis-augsburg.de
 
Collective call taxi (AST), on-call bus
The call-and-collect taxi (AST for short) and the on-call bus operate when there are no regular bus or train connections. A taxi picks you up from the station or a bus stop, for example, and takes you to the door of your desired destination. The journey must be requested by telephone at least 30 minutes before departure. The regular AVV prices apply.
You can find more informationhere.
 
AktiVVO - minibus on demand
The minibus runs on demand without fixed stops and without a fixed timetable. The minibus journeys can be booked by telephone or in the "AktiVVO" app. Passengers can hop on and off at one of the AktiVVo stops or the AVV regional bus stops within a short space of time. The fare for the AktiVVo corresponds to the regular AVV fares.
The AktiVVO minibus commutes in these regions: 

Holzwinkel and Altenmünster, Roth- and Zusamtal 
Bobingen, Königsbrunn and Schwabmünchen 

The AktiVVO only operates in these regions. It also does not travel to Augsburg. It does not travel to any places outside these regions. 
 
Augsburg City Zone
In the city of Augsburg, you can use the bus and tram free of charge at a total of 9 stations around Königsplatz and the main railway station. The free stops are one stop in each direction from Königsplatz and Moritzplatz.
You can find more information here.
 
At night
With the night bus you are also mobile at night (0.30 to 4 am). The night buses run from Thursday to Sunday and on public holidays. Passengers require a special night ticket (also available on the buses).
Regional trains run on some routes. The regular AVV fare applies here.
 
 
 
Keywords: local public transport, AVV, avv, bus, rail, tram, train, tram, night bus, shared taxi, call bus, AVV TIcket, monthly ticket for schoolchildren, 3-trip ticket, tariff zones, AVV price levels
content:
There is a good network of public transport in Augsburg and the surrounding area, such as buses and trams. The Augsburger Verkehrs- und Tarifverbund (AVV) is responsible for this network.

You can find all the important information on the AVV website at www.avv-augsburg.de. For app users, both the AVV (app: AVV.mobil) and Stadtwerke Augsburg (app: swa FahrInfo) offer free apps for download.

You need a ticket to travel by bus or tram. There are often checks on buses and trams. If you don't have a ticket, you will have to pay a fine. The second time, you will be reported to the police and fined a much higher amount. So make sure you always have a valid ticket with you!

Fare zones and price levels

The area covered by the AVV is divided into zones. The price of the ticket depends on the number of zones travelled through. The more zones you pass through, the more expensive your ticket is. Each zone corresponds to a price level.

Each zone is only counted once. For example, if you travel through zones 20, 10 and 20 again, you need a ticket of price level 2 or 2 stripes on the stripe card.

However, the outward and return journeys count as two different journeys.

  • The city area of Augsburg comprises fare zones 10 and 20.
  • The district of Augsburg comprises zones 30 - 70.

You can find the fare zone maphere. The timetables with the fare zones are also displayed at the stops.

Note: Your ticket is also valid if you change trains.

The most important tickets

You can find detailed information on all tickets and current prices here.

Germany ticket

  • For 49 euros a month, you can use all local public transport and travel throughout Germany.
  • The Deutschlandticket is a subscription. This means that it is automatically renewed every month. But you can cancel it every month. Always by the 10th of each month at the latest (for example: 10th March) for the following month.
  • You can order the Deutschlandticket here. It will then be played on your smartphone. You will need the "meinAVV" app for this. You can find the app in your smartphone's Apple or Google store.

Discount ticket for students, trainees, civil servants or volunteers

  • In Bavaria, these groups of people can get a discounted Deutschlandticket.
  • The discount ticket costs 29 euros. It is also valid nationwide.
  • This ticket will be available for trainees from 1 September 2023. Students can obtain it as a top-up ticket in time for the start of the 2023/2024 winter semester.
  • The person's place of education or residence must be in Bavaria.
  • To apply, you need proof of eligibility from your educational institution.
  • You can apply for the discount tickethere.

Stripe card

  • 9 strips for flexible use (one strip per zone)
  • Valid for 3 hours (no return and round trips)
  • No take-away options (one strip per person and zone)
  • You can find more information about the Streifenkarte here

Single tickets

  • Single journey from A to B
  • Valid for 1 hour (no return and round trips)
  • No take-along options
  • 4 stops after boarding buses or trams, even across zone boundaries
  • Transfer possible
  • You can find more information about single tickets here.

Day ticket

  • Any number of journeys on the selected day
  • For adults aged 15 and over
  • For one person or groups (each additional person costs a surcharge)
  • Up to 4 children under the age of 14 can travel free of charge.
  • Valid Monday to Friday from 9:00 a.m., Saturday, Sunday and public holidays all day; valid until closing time (i.e. until the last bus or tram leaves).
  • Please note: The names of the travellers must be handwritten on the day ticket!
  • You can find more information about the day ticket here.

365-euro AVV ticket for school pupils, trainees, interns and FSJ volunteers

The 365-euro AVV ticket is available for school pupils, trainees, interns and young people doing a voluntary social year. For €1 a day, you can travel as often as you like on trams, buses and trains throughout the AVV network area - around the clock! You can pay for the ticket in instalments or all at once. You can find all the information here.

Monthly travelcard for school pupils

Pupils do not have to pay for bus and tram travel themselves. They can submit an application. The costs for the monthly travelcard will then be covered.

For this, the journey to school must be more than 2 kilometres for pupils in grades 1 to 4. For children and young people from year 5 onwards, the journey to school must be longer than 3 kilometres.

Further information and download of applications: www.landkreis-augsburg.de

Collective call taxi (AST), on-call bus

The call-and-collect taxi (AST for short) and the on-call bus operate when there are no regular bus or train connections. A taxi picks you up from the station or a bus stop, for example, and takes you to the door of your desired destination. The journey must be requested by telephone at least 30 minutes before departure. The regular AVV prices apply.

You can find more informationhere.

AktiVVO - minibus on demand

The minibus runs on demand without fixed stops and without a fixed timetable. The minibus journeys can be booked by telephone or in the "AktiVVO" app. Passengers can hop on and off at one of the AktiVVo stops or the AVV regional bus stops within a short space of time. The fare for the AktiVVo corresponds to the regular AVV fares.

The AktiVVO minibus commutes in these regions:

  • Holzwinkel and Altenmünster, Roth- and Zusamtal
  • Bobingen, Königsbrunn and Schwabmünchen

The AktiVVO only operates in these regions. It also does not travel to Augsburg. It does not travel to any places outside these regions.

Augsburg City Zone

In the city of Augsburg, you can use the bus and tram free of charge at a total of 9 stations around Königsplatz and the main railway station. The free stops are one stop in each direction from Königsplatz and Moritzplatz.

You can find more information here.

At night

With the night bus you are also mobile at night (0.30 to 4 am). The night buses run from Thursday to Sunday and on public holidays. Passengers require a special night ticket (also available on the buses).

Regional trains run on some routes. The regular AVV fare applies here.

Keywords: local public transport, AVV, avv, bus, rail, tram, train, tram, night bus, shared taxi, call bus, AVV TIcket, monthly ticket for schoolchildren, 3-trip ticket, tariff zones, AVV price levels

title: Bicycle
excerpt:
Bicycle
Cycling in the district of Augsburg is lots of fun! A well-developed network of cycle paths with excellent signposting makes cycling not only a sporting hobby, but also a healthy and affordable alternative to buses, trains and cars.
For those of us who love to ride their bike, here are a few tips:

Always drive on the right-hand side of the road
Do not ride side by side, but behind each other.
If there is a cycle lane, you must ride on the cycle lane (always on the right-hand side of the road in the direction of travel).
Only children up to 11 years of age are allowed to cycle on footpaths.
It is dangerous if you get your tyres caught in the tram tracks.

 
Important traffic rules can be found in a flyer of the ADFC (Allgemeiner Deutscher Fahrrad-Club) Munich in 12 different languages(Albanian, Arabic, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Kurdish, Russian, Spanish, Tigrinya and Turkish) www.adfc-muenchen.de/adfc-muenchen/arbeitsgruppen/asyl/
 
Purchase and repairs
When buying a bicycle, make sure that your bicycle is equipped as follows and is therefore roadworthy. If your bicycle is not properly equipped, you will have to pay a fine if it is checked by the police:

Light front and rear
Reflector front and rear
Reflectors in the spokes (2 per wheel)
Reflectors on the pedals
Bell
Two independent brakes

 
Addresses of used bicycle shops and repair workshops in the city and surrounding rural area of Augsburg:
TheZ Bicycle workshop
  Bahnhofstr. 18, 86420 Diedorf
 Friday 15:00 - 18:00
 fahrradwerkstatt@die-z.de
Kette und Kurbel (used bicycles, repairs)
 Memminger Straße 6, 86159 Augsburg
 Monday to Friday, 8 am till 3 pm; Thursday, 8 am till 5.30 pm 
Der Fahrrad-Laden Lechhausen (used bicycles)
 Jesuitengasse 25, 86152 Augsburg
 Wednesday and Friday, 6 pm till 8 pm (April – September) or 4 pm till 6 pm (October – March)
Bikekitchen Augsburg (help repairing your bike yourself)
 Heilig-Kreuz-Straße 30, 86152 Augsburg
 Thursday, 6 pm till 8 pm, every first Friday in the month, 4 pm till 8 pm
 
For people who like to cycle fahren...
For people who enjoy cycling, the Radverkehrsbeauftragte (cycle traffic officer) for the district of Augsburg is always ready to listen to your wishes, ideas and criticisms.
Cycling Officer
Jonas Fricke
 0821 3102 2189
 radverkehr@LRA-a.bayern.de
You have discovered an annoying or dangerous spot on the cycle path? With the STADTRADELN registration platform you can also easily report annoying or dangerous places. Help the district of Augsburg to make the cycle paths safer, at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radar or via the free "Stadtradeln" app.

title: E-Scooter
excerpt:
Anyone travelling with an E-scooter must comply with the traffic regulations, just as everyone else does.
In principle, similar regulations apply as to those for cyclists. The most important regulations and a few key tips have been compiled by the ADAC
and by the Verbraucherzentrale (consumer advice centre) (search term “E-Scooter”).

title: Cars and mopeds
excerpt:
German driving licence
You need a driving licence to be allowed to drive in Germany. To drive a car on your own, you must be at least 18 years old. You have to get your driving licence at a driving school. You have driving lessons there and an exam at the end. The exam consists of a written part and a practical part (driving). You have to pay for your driving licence yourself.
 
Foreign driving licence
You want to drive in Germany and already have a driving licence from your home country? Then you first have to check whether your driving licence can also be recognised in Germany or whether you also have to pass the practical and/or theoretical driving test again here.
For EU citizens, the foreign driving licence is generally recognised.
Driving licences from third countries such as Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan are usually not recognised in Germany. You have to take the theoretical and practical exam again.
In addition to German, the theoretical exam can be taken in the following languages: Arabic, Turkish, Spanish, French, Russian, Polish, Romanian, Italian, Portuguese, and English.
Contact the driver licensing authority:
Driving licence authority
 Tiefenbacherstraße 8, 86368 Gersthofen
 0821 3102 3333
 fahrerlaubnis@LRA-a.bayern.de
Opening hours and further information can be found at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/auto-verkehr.
 
Moped licence
Anyone interested in riding a moped must also take lessons and pass a test. You have to get your driving licence at a driving school and pay for it yourself.

 0821 3102 3333

Moped licence

Anyone interested in riding a moped must also take lessons and pass a test. You have to get your driving licence at a driving school and pay for it yourself.

title: Opening hours
excerpt:
Opening hours
Large shops are open from Monday to Saturday from 8 am to 8 pm. Small shops often have shorter opening hours. Sometimes there is also a lunch break. Opening hours are shorter in small communities in particular.
Almost all shops are closed on Sundays and public holidays.
 
 
 
Keywords: shopping, supermarket, supermarkets, supermarket opening hours, food, shops

In addition to typical high street shops and department stores, you can also buy cheap or used items, which cost much less money.
Second-hand goods in good condition (e.g. furniture, clothes, bicycles) can be obtained at low prices from charitable institutions, second-hand department stores or second-hand goods exchanges:
Verschenk-Markt (Online freebee market)

Please note: You can only get a Tafel ID card for the Tafel in Stadtbergen at the main office at Hirtenmahdweg 8 (ground floor), 86154 Augsburg.
Further information at www.augsburger-tafel.de.

title: Online shopping
excerpt:
More and more people are shopping online. There are a few things to bear in mind. 
 
 Remember:
Online shopping does not only have positive effects. Packaging material and returns are a burden on the environment. And local shops can't keep up with the competition on the internet either. That's why many shops are closing. Local shops are empty. It is therefore worth considering what you order online or buy locally. 
 
What should I look out for when shopping online?
Reputable online shop or fake shop?
Do you want to order something online? Then you should find out about the online shop beforehand. Because not all platforms are reputable. So-called fake shops offer cheap goods that you don't receive after payment or that you receive in poor condition.
 
How can I recognise a dubious online retailer?

Conspicuously low price

The goods in the online shop are remarkably cheap? This is not always a sign of a fake shop. But you should take a closer look. 

Conspicuous Internet address

A well-known website suddenly shows inconsistencies? The domain extension has been extended (e.g. instead of ".de" it reads: ".de.com")? The Internet address contains the keyword "plants", but shoes are being sold? Then these are signs of a fake shop. 

No legal notice: 

Every online shop in the EU must have an imprint. If the legal notice is missing, it is a sign of a dubious online shop. However, scammers know this too. Therefore, make sure that the legal notice includes the following: Address, representative, e-mail address, reference to the commercial register. If these criteria are met, there is a high probability that it is a reputable shop. 

Missing terms and conditions (general terms and conditions) and cancellation conditions

GTCs are pre-formulated contractual terms and conditions. They are therefore rules that apply to every purchase from this online shop. If you don't find any terms and conditions on the site, you should be careful with this online shop. A reputable online shop will provide information about the cancellation conditions. You have a right of cancellation for every purchase. 

Unsafe payment methods

Normally the rule is: first the goods, then the payment. However, many shops also offer prepayment. Prepayment means that you transfer the money before the goods are dispatched. Many payment methods are offered? But in the last step you can only select "prepayment" as the payment method? Then be careful!

False quality seals

Many fake shops use quality seals to gain the trust of potential customers. Do you see a quality seal on an online shop? Then click on it. If the quality seal is not linked to the corresponding website, then it is probably a fake. 

Missing or only positive customer reviews

Customer reviews on the online shop's website are not always meaningful. Often only positive reviews are published. Bad reviews are deleted. However, you can also search for customer reviews on other platforms. 

No encrypted connection

Make sure that the online shop has an encrypted connection. Especially if you have to enter your data or bank details. 

Insufficient product descriptions

Does the product description match the goods or services on offer? If not, it could be a fake shop. 

Defects in the offer 

Before making a purchase, you should be informed about delivery times and shipping costs. Be careful if this is not the case. 

Lack of contact options

Avoid online shops that only offer an email address or a paid telephone number as a contact option. 
 
 You can easily check whether an online shop is reputable with the Fake Shop Finder from the consumer advice centre: Fake Shop Finder. 
 
Tips for safe online shopping

Be careful when entering your details. Of course, the online shop needs your name and address for delivery. But sometimes other information is also requested. Think about whether you really want to provide them. 
Choose online shops carefully. Pay attention to the criteria listed above.
Compare the prices with offers in the shop. Not everything is cheaper on the internet. 
Pay attention to the total price: Is the price shown really the final purchase price (including taxes, customs duties and shipping costs)?
Contact customer service if you are unsure about something. 
Read the experiences and reviews of other customers. 
Check again before you place the order: Which products are in your shopping basket? What are the delivery costs? Are there any additional taxes if the product comes from outside the EU? 
Print out your order or purchase contract, the product description and the terms and conditions and cancellation policy or save them on your computer. This way, the online retailer cannot change anything afterwards. 

 
You can find more information on safe online shopping in German and Englishhere (including an explanatory video in German).
content:
More and more people are shopping online. There are a few things to bear in mind.

Remember:

Online shopping does not only have positive effects. Packaging material and returns are a burden on the environment. And local shops can't keep up with the competition on the internet either. That's why many shops are closing. Local shops are empty. It is therefore worth considering what you order online or buy locally.

What should I look out for when shopping online?

Reputable online shop or fake shop?

Do you want to order something online? Then you should find out about the online shop beforehand. Because not all platforms are reputable. So-called fake shops offer cheap goods that you don't receive after payment or that you receive in poor condition.

How can I recognise a dubious online retailer?

  • Conspicuously low price

The goods in the online shop are remarkably cheap? This is not always a sign of a fake shop. But you should take a closer look.

  • Conspicuous Internet address

A well-known website suddenly shows inconsistencies? The domain extension has been extended (e.g. instead of ".de" it reads: ".de.com")? The Internet address contains the keyword "plants", but shoes are being sold? Then these are signs of a fake shop.

  • No legal notice:

Every online shop in the EU must have an imprint. If the legal notice is missing, it is a sign of a dubious online shop. However, scammers know this too. Therefore, make sure that the legal notice includes the following: Address, representative, e-mail address, reference to the commercial register. If these criteria are met, there is a high probability that it is a reputable shop.

  • Missing terms and conditions (general terms and conditions) and cancellation conditions

GTCs are pre-formulated contractual terms and conditions. They are therefore rules that apply to every purchase from this online shop. If you don't find any terms and conditions on the site, you should be careful with this online shop. A reputable online shop will provide information about the cancellation conditions. You have a right of cancellation for every purchase.

  • Unsafe payment methods

Normally the rule is: first the goods, then the payment. However, many shops also offer prepayment. Prepayment means that you transfer the money before the goods are dispatched. Many payment methods are offered? But in the last step you can only select "prepayment" as the payment method? Then be careful!

  • False quality seals

Many fake shops use quality seals to gain the trust of potential customers. Do you see a quality seal on an online shop? Then click on it. If the quality seal is not linked to the corresponding website, then it is probably a fake.

  • Missing or only positive customer reviews

Customer reviews on the online shop's website are not always meaningful. Often only positive reviews are published. Bad reviews are deleted. However, you can also search for customer reviews on other platforms.

  • No encrypted connection

Make sure that the online shop has an encrypted connection. Especially if you have to enter your data or bank details.

  • Insufficient product descriptions

Does the product description match the goods or services on offer? If not, it could be a fake shop.

  • Defects in the offer

Before making a purchase, you should be informed about delivery times and shipping costs. Be careful if this is not the case.

  • Lack of contact options

Avoid online shops that only offer an email address or a paid telephone number as a contact option.

You can easily check whether an online shop is reputable with the Fake Shop Finder from the consumer advice centre: Fake Shop Finder.

Tips for safe online shopping

  • Be careful when entering your details. Of course, the online shop needs your name and address for delivery. But sometimes other information is also requested. Think about whether you really want to provide them.
  • Choose online shops carefully. Pay attention to the criteria listed above.
  • Compare the prices with offers in the shop. Not everything is cheaper on the internet.
  • Pay attention to the total price: Is the price shown really the final purchase price (including taxes, customs duties and shipping costs)?
  • Contact customer service if you are unsure about something.
  • Read the experiences and reviews of other customers.
  • Check again before you place the order: Which products are in your shopping basket? What are the delivery costs? Are there any additional taxes if the product comes from outside the EU?
  • Print out your order or purchase contract, the product description and the terms and conditions and cancellation policy or save them on your computer. This way, the online retailer cannot change anything afterwards.

You can find more information on safe online shopping in German and Englishhere (including an explanatory video in German).

title: Public holidays, school holidays and time changeover
excerpt:
Public holidays
No work is done on public holidays for religious or secular reasons. Shops and authorities are closed on these days.
The following public holidays are on the same date every year:

01.01. New Year
06.01. Epiphany
01.05. Labour Day
08.08. Peace Festival (only in the city of Augsburg)
15.08. Assumption Day
03.10. Day of German Unity
01.11. All Saints' Day
25.12. 1st Christmas Day
26.12. 2nd Christmas Day

Other public holidays change from year to year. You can find an overview of public holidays in Bavaria here.
 
School holidays
School holidays are the times of the year when pupils are off school. In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.

Autumn holidays: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas holidays: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter holidays: There is one week of winter holidays in February.
Easter holidays: There are two weeks of holidays in spring
Whitsun holidays: There are two weeks of holidays in early summer.
Summer holidays: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of holidays.

You can find an overview of all upcoming public holidays and school holidays here.
 
Religious holidays 
Jewish, Muslim and Orthodox pupils are exempt from lessons on certain religious holidays: www.km.bayern.de/ministerium/termine/ferientermine.html
Please inform the school if your child cannot come to school due to these holidays.
 
Intercultural calendar
The intercultural calendar provides an overview of the most important holidays of the different religious communities.
 
Time change
There is also a time change in Germany. This means that the clock is moved forward one hour from winter to summer time. From summer to winter time, the clock is set back by one hour.
In 2023, winter time begins on 29.10.2023. In 2024, summer time begins on 31.3.2024.
 
 
Keywords: public holidays, public holidays, school holidays, holidays, time changeover, winter time, summer time

School holidays are the times of the year when pupils are off school. In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.

  • Autumn holidays: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
  • Christmas holidays: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
  • Winter holidays: There is one week of winter holidays in February.
  • Easter holidays: There are two weeks of holidays in spring
  • Whitsun holidays: There are two weeks of holidays in early summer.
  • Summer holidays: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of holidays.

You can find an overview of all upcoming public holidays and school holidays here.

Please inform the school if your child cannot come to school due to these holidays.

Intercultural calendar

The intercultural calendar provides an overview of the most important holidays of the different religious communities.

Time change

There is also a time change in Germany. This means that the clock is moved forward one hour from winter to summer time. From summer to winter time, the clock is set back by one hour.

In 2023, winter time begins on 29.10.2023. In 2024, summer time begins on 31.3.2024.

title: Leisure time and recuperation
excerpt:
Whether it is with your family, or for those interested in culture or friends of nature – the wider region offers plenty of leisure time options, an interesting cultural range of activities and stunning nature!
And don't forget: Augsburg's rural area is famed for its delightful markets, courtyard and village shops, idyllic beer gardens and guest inns. There you can enjoy regional and international dishes.
We have compiled ten special highlights in the district of Augsburg for you in a leisure map (in German, Arabic, Bulgarian, English, Hungarian, Italian, Polish, Croatian, Turkish, Romanian).
We hope you enjoy the district of Augsburg!

title: In Nature
excerpt:
In the Nature Park - Western Forests

The Nature Park - Western Forests is the only nature park in central Swabia and a valuable recreational area for citizens from the city and district of Augsburg. Marked hiking and biking trails and Nordic walking routes invite you to exercise in the fresh air. For families and nature lovers, adventure trails provide information about local plants. You can find more details under www.naturpark-augsburg.de.
Lakes in the district of Augsburg - recreation and swimming fun

Whether in winter or summer: The lakes in the Augsburger Land guarantee a welcome change from everyday life. From a simple walk, to a relaxing sunbath, to sports activities such as diving or beach volleyball - there's something for everyone here!
Our lakes: Badesee Kühlenthal, Ilsesee Königsbrunn, Badesee Gablingen, Rothsee Zusmarshausen
Cycle paths in the district of Augsburg - Exploring the district by bike

Enjoy nature, explore the countryside and exercise in the fresh air? What better way to do that than by bike! This is why the District of Augsburg has a well-developed network of cycle paths. Whether you are on a family outing, an everyday cyclist or a top athlete – there is a suitable cycle path for everyone. So then: Get on your bike and discover the district!
More info at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radwege.
For people who enjoy cycling, the Augsburg District Cycling Officer has an open ear for wishes, ideas and criticism.
Cycling Officer
Jonas Fricke
 0821 3102 2189
 radverkehr@LRA-a.bayern.de
Have you found a disturbing or dangerous spot on the cycle path? With the RADar reporting platform, you can also easily report disturbing or dangerous places. Help the district of Augsburg to make the cycle paths safer at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radar or via the free "RADar!" app.
Leisure tips in nature

Bonstetten Land Art Trail - Art Meets Nature
For art lovers, the Land-Art-Kunstpfad designed by Hama Lohrmann with nine stations around Bonstetten offers a special approach to the theme of impermanence. The starting point is the first location in the centre of the village, after which the signposted path leads along a circular route of approximately six-kilometres, through the neighbouring woods of Westliche Wälder.

Land-Art-Kunstpfad Bonstetten
   Hauptstraße 9 (starting point), 86486 Bonstetten
 www.kunstpfad-bonstetten.de/

Perennial Meditation Trail - Time for Peace and Reflection
Beautiful landscape, peace and quiet, time for yourself – this is what the meditation path in the Augsburg – Western Woods Nature Park offers. Nine stations all with meditation exercises from different religions promise relaxation. The trail stretches through Fischach, Langenneufnach, Walkertshofen, Mittelneufnach to the District of Unterallgäu. On foot or by bike: Relaxation is guaranteed!

 

Geological nature trail Bonstetten - The history of the Staufenberg
Do you know why there are so many lakes in the foothills of the Alps? No? Then visit the geological nature trail in Bonstetten! The nature trail is located on the Staufenberg and is 4.5 kilometres long. Six information panels illustrate the history of the landscape during ice ages and warm intervals. The circular route begins in the centre of Bonstetten www.bonstetten.de/index.php/geologischer-lehrpfad

 

Culture and nature experience trail Deuringer Heide - nature and puzzle fun
A diverse puzzle and information trail provides information about the flora and fauna of the Deuringer Heath in an entertaining way. The circular trail with ten different stations can either be discovered independently or explored as part of a guided tour.

Culture and Nature Experience Trail Deuringer Heide
 Kapellenstraße (500 metres after leaving the town), 86391 Stadtbergen (Deuringen)
 www.eva-augsburg.de/?mp=lehrpfade
 

Barbecue sites in the district of Augsburg and the region
The smell of grilled meat or crunchy vegetables on a hot grill is simply a part of summer. For all fans of grilling who do not have a garden, there are public designated grilling areas. You can find an overviewhere .
For the sake of the environment, please take your rubbish back with you.

title: Sport, culture and clubs
excerpt:
Sport

Sport is fun, keeps you healthy and brings people together – both internationally and in your direct neighbourhood. Roughly 400 different sports clubs offer various types of sport. By visiting these clubs, you can get to know people and make new friends! Regional masters championships are held in numerous sports every year. Sporting events such as the Landkreislauf (regional circular run) or the district championships (Landkreismeisterschaften) are very popular, and bring the people of the district together.
You can find everything about the topic of "sport" in the district of Augsburghere: .
Do you have questions about sport in our district? Our sports officer will be happy to help!
Sports Commissioner
Barbara Wengenmeir
 0821 3102 2394
 barbara.wengenmeir@LRA-a.bayern.de
Regional attractions

Attractions such as museums, monasteries and historic monuments are places of great interest, and not just for those interested in culture. These attractions are also a great experience for children and grown-ups thanks to their interactive and multimedia elements.
Do you have questions about culture, history or leisure in our district? Our district curator will help you!
District curator of local history
Claudia Ried
 0821 3102 2576
 claudia.ried@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
Events

The district of Augsburg is a fantastic place to be all year round thanks to its many different events taking place. One key date in the calendar of any ambitious runner is the annual “Landkreislauf” or “regional circuit run”. Car fans and other interested visitors can come and enjoy the Classic Car Rallye. The Moussong Theater regularly offers exciting puppet performances for children and adults.
You can find more events under www.landkreis-augsburg.de/leben-im-landkreis/veranstaltungskalender/
 
Libraries

Libraries are a great place for people who love to read. On the education portal a3 (www.bildungsportal-a3.de) under "Bildungsorte" you can see where exactly you can find the libraries.
Clubs and associations
Clubs have a special social importance for many people in Germany; they offer people the chance to get together and turn goals into reality. These goals can be of different kinds, leisure activities, commitment to the needy and disadvantaged, protection of nature or contact with like-minded people.
The clubs and associations in the district and wider region of Augsburg offer numerous leisure time activity options. Take advantage of these opportunities! That is because: Clubs and associations build bridges between people. This way you can arrive in your new home faster and more beautifully!
You can find an overview of clubs and associations in the Augsburg district here www.landkreis-augsburg.de/leben-im-landkreis/urlaub-freizeit-kultur/sport/vereine/

title: Leisure time offers for families, children and adolescents
excerpt:
Children and adolescents

Children and adolescents can spend their free time at youth centres where they can work on activities together, cook together or simply chat and relax. You can find all youth centres on the a3 education portal (www.bildungsportal-a3.de) under "Places of education".
You can also find a summary of offers for children and young people in the region here www.region-a3.com/leben/familie/angebote-fuer-kinder-und-jugendliche/
Families

The district of Augsburg has many leisure time offers available for the whole family. We have put them together for you here www.landkreis-augsburg.de/leben-im-landkreis/urlaub-freizeit-kultur/familienziele/ .
You can also find additional information in the family magazine readLotte www.lieslotte.de/branchenbuch/wpbdp_kategorie/ausfluege_freizeittipps/

title: Volunteering and social engagement
excerpt:
You want to volunteer? Then ask directly at the respective institution. Anyone interested is always most welcome!
Volunteering can take on many different forms. We have summarised some ideas for you here:
Volunteer centres and agencies
The district of Augsburg is  known for a strong "togetherness" , but also for a strong "foreach other". Its people meet, for example, in volunteer centres or helper groups, in order to achieve something great on a voluntary basis. "Voluntary"/"Ehrenamt" means: You help other people for free in your spare time. Ask in your community.
You can find all volunteer centres and agencies on the education portal a3 (www.bildungsportal-a3.de) under "Places of education".
Volunteering work with refugees and asylum seekers (“Flucht / Asyl”)
Anyone who would like to do volunteering work with migrants can contact the district of Augsburg’s integration advisors:
Integration guides at Diakonisches Werk Augsburg e.V.Integration pilotAstrid Zimmermann 08234 9591896 and 0174 131 5515 zimmermann.a@diakonie-augsburg.de
Integration pilot for the area of "housingChristine von Gropper 0821 907 9937 vongropper.c@diakonie-augsburg.de
 http://integrationslotsin.de/
Volunteering in clubs and associations
Many people are involved in clubs or associations and thus contribute to the cohesion and well-being of our society. Whether sports or music club, volunteer fire brigade or water rescue: Anyone who wants to get involved is very welcome!
You can find an overview of clubs and associations in the Augsburg district here.
Bavarian Volunteer Card: A big thankyou to all volunteers
As a way of honouring the daily commitment of our volunteers, the district of Augsburg is delighted to issue the “Bavarian volunteers card”. For example, volunteers receive cheaper tickets or products at state museums, institutions and other partners (for example, shops) throughout Bavaria. You can find more detailed information at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/ehrenamtskarte.

title: Association Start with a Friend e.V.
excerpt:
For more togetherness
Start with a Friend e. V. creates personal encounters between people with and without an immigration background.
People from different countries and with different experiences can get to know each other. 
The vision is a society that lives its diversity. All people feel comfortable and have an equal say in shaping it.
Join us and work together with the SwaF People programme for more togetherness!
Who can come?
All people from the age of 18
What is on offer?

Regulars' table (once a month)
Events
Further education
Exchange of people from Germany and other countries 

Joining does not cost any money.
Start with a Friend!
Contact: 
  https://www.start-with-a-friend.de/ 
 augsburg@start-with-a-friend.de

title: Multigenerational house - meeting place
excerpt:
What is it?
In a multigenerational house or a meeting place, people meet in their free time. You can meet new people there, play, do handicrafts or learn something. The offers are usually free of charge. 
What can I expect there?

Meeting of the generations
open games and handicraft afternoons for young and old
dancing afternoons and evenings
Lectures on various topics
Play groups for parents and children
Sports activities for seniors
Language and conversation courses
Exhibitions and music events

Where?
In the district of Augsburg there are the following places:
Multigenerational House Königsbrunn
Multigenerational House Königsbrunn
  Bürgermeister-Wohlfarth-Str. 98, 86343 Königsbrunn   08231 605 86 80    info@mgh-koenigsbrunn.de 
 www.mehrgenerationenhaeuser.de/mehrgenerationenhaus-koenigsbrunn 
The goal of the multigenerational house Königsbrunn is:

To make encounters possible,
to strengthen community
to promote diversity. 

Meeting place du&hier
du&here Kirchstraße 12, 86368 Gersthofen, Germany 0821 4970 8741 du-und-hier@gersthofen.de
 https://www.gersthofen.de/seite/leben-in-gersthofen/soziales/begegnungsstaette-duhier.php
The meeting place du&hier is a meeting place for people of all generations, social classes, with and without children, no matter if they come from here or from further away. Operator is the city of Gersthofen. Here you can find the program.

title: Housing search
excerpt: The search for your own apartment is one of the biggest and most difficult tasks. There are only very few cheap apartment available. But there are many people in search of an apartment. Unfortunately, it sometimes takes several months to find a suitable flat. Therefore, it may take some time until you have found your own flat. It is important to be patient.
content: The search for your own apartment is one of the biggest and most difficult tasks. There are only very few cheap apartment available. But there are many people in search of an apartment. Unfortunately, it sometimes takes several months to find a suitable flat. Therefore, it may take some time until you have found your own flat. It is important to be patient.

title: Newspapers and the Internet
excerpt:
Search via newspaper
Many landlords offer their flats in daily newspapers. The most important local newspaper for the city and the district of Augsburg is the Augsburger Allgemeine (AZ). The AZ has a real estate section every Wednesday and Saturday. In addition, advertisements can also be called up on the Internet  www.augburger-allgemeinde.de under "Advertisements", "Real Estate".
Another option is the Augsburger Stadtzeitung and the Augsburg Extra, which are published free of charge every Wednesday and also contain a real estate section.
 
Search on the Internet
In addition to advertisements in daily and weekly newspapers, there are now a variety of online portals on which homes are offered for rent and purchase.
You can find most rental offers on the Internet on the following online portals, among others:

Immobilienscout 24 www.immobilienscout24.de
Housing exchange www.wohnungsboerse.net
Immowelt www.immowelt.de
Immonet www.immonet.de
Ebay Classifieds www.ebay-kleinanzeigen.de
WG wanted www.wg-gesucht.de

 
Search on Facebook
Besides the online portals, there are also many groups and pages on Facebook where flats are offered, such as www.de-de.facebook.com/Wohnung.Augsburg.Landkreis/

title: Social housing and accommodation entitlement certificates (WBS)
excerpt:
Social housing is housing for people with little money. This is why there are special rules. It sometimes takes several years until you get a social housing.
In order to be able to move into a subsidised (social) rented flat, you must apply for a housing entitlement certificate (Wohnberechtigungsschein, WBS for short). This will check whether you are entitled to social housing. On the basis of your application, your personal level of urgency is then determined. This level is used to choose what kind of social housing you are to be awarded.
You can get the application form from your municipality or you can have it sent to you by the Landratsamt. Only hand in the application for social housing completely filled out!
 
Your point of contact at the district administration of Augsburg:
Alexandra Geh
 0821 3102 2475
 alexandra.geh@LRA-a.bayern.de
Gerda Kugelmann
 0821 3102 2405
 gerda.kugelmann@LRA-a.bayern.de
 
You can find more information about social housing on the district's website www.landkreis-augsburg.de/sozialwohnungen.

title: WG (shared apartment)
excerpt:
A shared flat is a special form of living together. Especially if you are looking for a flat for yourself, a shared flat can be a good alternative to a flat of your own. Living in a shared apartment means that you share an apartment with mostly young people. Every person there has their own room. You only share the common areas such as a bathroom, a kitchen or a living room.
The best way to find available shared rooms is either on the website "WG-gesucht" ( www.wg-gesucht.de ) or on corresponding Facebook pages or groups, such as "WG & Apartment Augsburg gesucht".
For refugees there is a special platform called "Zusammenleben Willkommen" (https://zusammenleben-willkommen.de/) for looking for a flat share and with some explanations and insights into flat share life.

title: House viewing
excerpt:
At present, it is difficult to find a vacant apartment. It is often the case that many people apply for one vacant apartment. Obtaining important documents early is, therefore, very important and can increase your chances of getting an apartment. It is advisable to compile the documents into an "application folder".
The application folder should contain the following documents:

Cover letter (Who am I/are we, what do I do for a living, how old are my children, why would I like to rent the flat)
Tenant self-disclosure
Copy of identity card/residence permit (Attention: copy front and back)
Copy of the decision from the job centre/social welfare office if you are not working;
Proof of salary for the last three months, if you are working
Copy of Schufa information (= information about a person's ability to pay bills reliably; also explains in an Video of the consumer advice centre in German, English, Arabic and Dari www.verbraucherzentrale.de, search term "multilingual information")
Copy of freedom from rent debt
Proof of liability insurance
