  • Proof of liability insurance

title: Improve your chances by way of tenant qualification
excerpt:
Tenant qualification
You can prepare yourself for finding a flat by taking part in a tenant qualification course. In the course you will learn, for example, how to read rental offers correctly, learn interesting facts (e.g. about the tenancy agreement) and practise conversation situations with (future) landlords. At the end of the course you will have a complete application portfolio for viewings and you will receive a certificate. Both can help you find a flat.
If you are interested, please contact:
Integration pilot for the area of "housing
Christine von Gropper
 0821 907 9937
 vongropper.c@diakonie-augsburg.de
Ready-to-Rent courses in the “zib.” 
Every month, the housing project of Diakonie and Tür an Tür e.V. offers courses where you can learn basic information about finding a flat, your rights and obligations as a tenant, caring for your flat and dealing with resources. The course is free of charge. For the course you need at least the language level A2.
Those eligible to participate include:

German citizens with immigration backgrounds
EU citizens
Recognised refugees
Quota refugees

You can find current dates, registration information and further information at www.tuerantuer.de/integrationsprojekte/projekte/wohnprojekt-augsburg/ .

title: For refugees
excerpt:
The Asylum Procedure Law (AsylVfG) and the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act (AsylbLG) generally stipulate that asylum-seekers and persons with exceptional leaves to remain (Geduldete) should live in asylum seeker accommodation facilities. Some federal states provide accommodation in private homes.
In all federal states, recognised refugees may move into their own home.
In the accommodation and everywhere in Germany there are rest periods from 10 pm in the evening to 6 am in the morning. The quiet times are also regulated by law. No loud music is allowed during this time and everyone should be quieter. You and your neighbours in the accommodation and in the neighbourhood need the quiet times so that living together works and remains harmonious. You will find the rest periods and other rules in the "house rules" of your accommodation. The House Rules are there to regulate life together. Please adhere to the House Rules and always respect the rules and resting times.
Asylum seekers who, for special reasons, wish to move out of their allocated accommodation and rent a flat themselves must agree on this with the Benefit Authority (Leistungsbehörde) in advance. 30 euros per person per month are withheld from the benefits paid to the asylum seeker and the electricity is granted as a payment in kind.
Attention should be paid to economical energy consumption and correct waste separation. There are also instructions for this in various languages.
content:
The Asylum Procedure Law (AsylVfG) and the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act (AsylbLG) generally stipulate that asylum-seekers and persons with exceptional leaves to remain (Geduldete) should live in asylum seeker accommodation facilities. Some federal states provide accommodation in private homes.

In all federal states, recognised refugees may move into their own home.

In the accommodation and everywhere in Germany there are rest periods from 10 pm in the evening to 6 am in the morning. The quiet times are also regulated by law. No loud music is allowed during this time and everyone should be quieter. You and your neighbours in the accommodation and in the neighbourhood need the quiet times so that living together works and remains harmonious. You will find the rest periods and other rules in the "house rules" of your accommodation. The House Rules are there to regulate life together. Please adhere to the House Rules and always respect the rules and resting times.

Asylum seekers who, for special reasons, wish to move out of their allocated accommodation and rent a flat themselves must agree on this with the Benefit Authority (Leistungsbehörde) in advance. 30 euros per person per month are withheld from the benefits paid to the asylum seeker and the electricity is granted as a payment in kind.

Attention should be paid to economical energy consumption and correct waste separation. There are also instructions for this in various languages.

title: Rental contract (Mietvertrag) and security deposit (Kaution)
excerpt:
Rental contract

The amount of rent you pay is agreed in the rental contract. If the tenant signs the contract, he also agrees to the rental payment.
The rent consists of the base rent, additional costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.
The contract stipulates when the rent will be paid. If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the lease contract.
You have to read the lease carefully. If you don't understand everything, ask someone who can help you.
The lease contract is very important. Once the contract is signed, it cannot be cancelled so quickly!
The following points must be included in the rental contract:

Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit

If you agree with what is written in the lease, then sign the contract.
Deposit

The deposit is security for the landlord. The amount of the deposit is a maximum of three cold rents. If you move out of the flat and leave no damage behind, you will get the money back.

Rental contract

The amount of rent you pay is agreed in the rental contract. If the tenant signs the contract, he also agrees to the rental payment.
The rent consists of the base rent, additional costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.
The contract stipulates when the rent will be paid. If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the lease contract.
You have to read the lease carefully. If you don't understand everything, ask someone who can help you.
The lease contract is very important. Once the contract is signed, it cannot be cancelled so quickly!

The following points must be included in the rental contract:

  • Name and address of the landlord
  • Address of the rental property
  • Living space in m²
  • Number of rooms
  • Amount of the net cold rent
  • Amount of operating costs
  • Amount of heating costs
  • Total rent
  • Amount of the deposit

If you agree with what is written in the lease, then sign the contract.

Deposit

The deposit is security for the landlord. The amount of the deposit is a maximum of three cold rents. If you move out of the flat and leave no damage behind, you will get the money back.

title: Transfer of costs to the Job Centre
excerpt:
Transfer of costs to the Job Centre
If you are unemployed and receive benefits from the job centre, the job centre pays the rent. However, only if you are in need of assistance and the rent is reasonable (not too high). Each job centre sets its own rent ceiling, which can sometimes even vary within the same area of responsibility (e.g. Jobcenter Augsburg-Land). Rent upper limit means: The Job Centre sets a maximum amount for the rent. If your rent is more expensive, you have to pay the rest yourself.
The tables for the rent ceilings of the individual authorities can be found here :

Job Centre Augsburg City 
Jobcenter Augsburg Land

What do you need to know?
Important: If you have found a flat and the rent is paid by the Job Centre, you must not sign the tenancy agreement straight away. It is essential that the Job Centre checks and approves the adequacy of the accommodation costs prior to conclusion. This is possible during regular opening hours and without an appointment. The Jobcenter's decision on whether the costs are fair and whether it will pay the deposit will be given to you straight away in writing. This is called a "rental confirmation". It is important that a tenancy agreement or at least a rental offer with all minimum information about the flat is already available. It is important to note that the tenancy agreement must already be signed by the landlord, but not by the tenant.
The following points must be included in the rental contract:

Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit

Deposit
The Job Centre can grant the deposit on a loan basis upon application. On a loan basis means: You get the money and have to pay it back.
As a rule, this is unproblematic and is granted for reasonable accommodation costs. The deposit is usually paid directly to the landlord by the Job Centre. The repayment of the loan to the Job Centre is automatically deducted from the monthly standard benefits (normally max. ten percent of this) and retained.
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Job Centre, you have the possibility to apply for initial equipment for furniture and furnishings. You will be paid a lump sum according to the number of people, the size of the flat and the equipment required. The initial equipment includes furniture, curtains, mattresses, cooking utensils, crockery and, if not available in the flat, a cooker, sink, refrigerator and washing machine.
It is important that the application is made before the furniture is purchased. You can find a list with an overview of where you can buy cheap and used furniture "here.
Caution: It may take a while before the money is paid out! In addition, the Jobcenter has (and uses) a right to inspect the flat to check what is needed for the initial outfitting. If it is found that, for example, furniture is already in place, and you cannot prove (in writing!) that it has been lent to you (e.g. an emergency bed from SKM), you will no longer be entitled to a Starter Kit for those items.
Info for refugees
When you move out of accommodation, you are not allowed to take the furniture of the accommodation with you. That's why you need new furniture. You can apply to the Job Centre for initial equipment.

title: In Your Own Home
excerpt:
Having your own flat also means taking responsibility for it. When you have moved into the flat, you should remember this:

Write your name on the bell and on the letterbox so that you can receive mail.
Register your residence in your municipality.
Report the new address to your employer, your bank and health insurance company, etc.
content:
Having your own flat also means taking responsibility for it. When you have moved into the flat, you should remember this:

  • Write your name on the bell and on the letterbox so that you can receive mail.
  • Register your residence in your municipality.
  • Report the new address to your employer, your bank and health insurance company, etc.

title: House regulations, household waste separation and saving energy
excerpt:
House regulations
The cohabitation of many or more people in one house requires mutual consideration and tolerance. The landlord has the option of defining certain rules for the coexistence of tenants in a block of flats. These rules are then laid down in the house rules.
The main contents are:

Quiet times/noise
Waste disposal
Use of common areas
Ventilation

You can find detailed house rules in different languages here www.allbau.de/kundenservice/hausordnung
Waste separation
Waste must be disposed of in the designated bin. There are different bins for plastic, paper and cardboard, fruit and vegetables (organic waste) and other waste. Please adhere to waste separation, as much of the waste is reused and it is an important part of environmental protection.
What goes in which waste bin? When are the waste bins emptied? Where is there a recycling point? Information can be found at www.awb-landkreis-augsburg.de. You can also use the waste app.  Should you have any further questions, please contact the Waste Collection Advice Centre operated by the district of Augsburg.
Waste Collection Advice Centre (Abfallberatung)
 0821 3102 3221, 0821 3102 3222
 abfallwirtschaft@LRA-a.bayern.de
Information on waste separation can be foundhere .
Saving energy by way of ventilation and proper heating

Make sure you ventilate regularly (at least open the window fully three times a day for five minutes) and heat properly. This way you prevent mould from developing and save energy.
You can get detailed information and helpful tips in German, English, Russian, Arabic and Farsi at the consumer advice centre: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (Search term: “Multi-lingual information”).

title: Electricity
excerpt:
Normally the new tenants are automatically registered by the landlord with the electricity supplier. However, you are free to choose your own provider and can usually change the electricity provider after a two-week period of notice.
An overview of providers and price comparisons can best be found on an independent energy consumer portal: www.energieverbraucherportal.de.
content:
Normally the new tenants are automatically registered by the landlord with the electricity supplier. However, you are free to choose your own provider and can usually change the electricity provider after a two-week period of notice.

An overview of providers and price comparisons can best be found on an independent energy consumer portal: www.energieverbraucherportal.de.

title: Internet, TV and Radio Licencing Fee (GEZ)
excerpt:
Internet and TV

Providers can also be freely chosen for this. It is important to note that the minimum contract duration is usually 24 months. Termination is only possible in special cases.
Internet, TV and Radio Licencing Fee (GEZ) – mandatory

In Germany, every household must pay the broadcasting fees (GEZ). This provides funding for public broadcasting media in Germany. However, people can be exempted from this obligation to pay fees under certain circumstances, for example, as soon as you receive social benefits or can show other reasons for exemption from the broadcasting fees.
More information (also in other languages) is available here www.rundfunkbeitrag.de/welcome/index_ger.html
Note for asylum seekers

You have no legal right to television (TV) in your asylum accommodation. That means that there does not have to be a TV in their accommodation. If you have a TV in your accommodation, you may be sent a bill for the broadcasting fee (GEZ). So if you don't pay the bill, you show the bill to your accommodation manager.

title: Services of the Jobcenter
excerpt:
Electricity

The electricity costs are not covered by the Job Centre and must therefore be paid from the standard benefit. Normally, the new tenants are automatically registered by the landlord with the electricity provider (i.d.R. Stadtwerke). However, you have freedom of choice of supplier and can change electricity providers after a notice period i.d.R. of two weeks.
The best way to find an overview of providers and price comparisons is via the independent energy consumer portal www.energieverbraucherportal.de.
Tip: After moving in, financial support recipients can receive free advice on their energy consumption through the Stromsparcheck—SKM Augsburg team. You can find all the information here www.stromspar-check.de.
Internet / TV

Internet costs are not covered by the Job Centre.

title: Save energy
excerpt:
How and where can energy be saved?
Saving energy means achieving the desired "performance" with less final energy (electricity, combustibles and fuels). But it also means simply doing without something. We can save energy everywhere: in the home, in industry and commerce and in transport. Sooner or later, this will pay off through the energy costs saved. The benefits are twofold: for the environment and for your wallet.
This checklist will show you how you can minimise your electricity and hot water consumption and save money. Correct heating and ventilation are essential to prevent mould from forming in your home. The checklist is available in German, English, Arabic, Kurdish and Dari.
 
 
Keywords: save energy, save energy, save less energy, save energy costs, save money

title: Help with the threat of losing your home
excerpt:
Outpatient emergency housing help from Diakonie
Are you afraid of losing your flat? For example, because of a notice of termination, eviction proceedings or an eviction judgement? Then you are not alone! 
 
Diakonie's outpatient emergency housing help centre can help you. The advice centre will advise you on all questions relating to housing hardship. The specialists there will support you and refer you to further help.
 
Important: Get help as early as possible! That way you can meet any deadlines. And avoid additional costs. 
 
Outpatient emergency housing assistance for the district of Augsburg

 Inneres Pfaffengäßchen 14, 86152 Augsburg
